author: ac96984b69b55f73b15c4f86a76f3c5d
content:
I personally feel like spinoffs don't exactly have the best of reputations. Often derivative and lacking creativity, they never seem to hit the same as the item they were based off on. Persona is obviously no stranger to spinoffs - if you're reading this you're on a spinoff title right now - and they're definitely on the more meh side of games. The Persona Dancing games range from awful to pretty good, the P4 Arena games were ok, and though I've not played the Persona Q games, I hear that they're not the best. Perfectly average can describe most Persona spinoff titles, so I went into Persona 5 Strikers with the same idea in mind.

Honestly though, perfectly average would've suited me just fine. I had just come off of the high of P5R and desperately wanted to be with these characters more, so a game of any quality would've been fine. God, did I get that and more. While obviously not as good as P5R, P5S is still an extremely good game (a 11/10 to a 8.5/10). P5S has more heart and soul put into it than I ever expected; it really does feel like an actual sequel sometimes. From a enjoyable gameplay to a gripping story to excellent themes and characters, P5S really blew my expectations out of the water. *spoilers from here on out*

To get the gameplay out of the way first, it's fun! It trades the typical turn-based gameplay of normal Persona games for a more action-based hack-and-slash one. Combos that weaved in melee, guns, and of course Personas, there were tons of different moves that kept the gameplay relatively fresh. Each character also has their own unique movesets, all of which are extremely distinct from one another, which only adds to the fun of combat. I will say though, once into NG+ and just grinding for that final achievement, the gameplay began to get a bit repetitive. While the other characters are fun, it's simply more efficient to stay on the main character Joker for the entire time while grinding which ended up getting on my nerves. Overall, the gameplay is a surprising yet pleasant shift from the typical gameplay of the Persona series.

The story is really where P5S begins to get elite. While a bit derivative from previous Persona games, I was extremely engaged and invested in the story of P5S. Similar to P5R's Palace rulers are P5S's Jail rulers, and I'd go to argue that some of the Jail rulers are better than most of the Palace ones. Akira Konoe of P5S really stands out as an excellent villain (he has the best soundtrack out of ANY Persona game). He's simply written so well, with believable motivations and a truly heartbreaking backstory. What P5S does more than P5R is really humanize its villains. While there is merit in simply having an irredeemable villain, I prefer ones which are more complex and serve as foils to the heroes. I truly do think that P5S accomplishes this better than P5R. They're not perfect, almost nothing is (though I will say Maruki in P5R gets very close), but the villains are still all extremely good.

The themes of the game are also heartfelt. "Finding what it means to be human" is a common trope in media, though I'd argue that it's common because it's a great theme. I do think it's often overlooked what this theme means to the human characters of the story. P5S starts with all the characters coming off of their P5R arcs, yet this theme somehow gave even more growth to all these characters. 

Speaking of characters, god I love them all SO MUCH. The main cast are as good as ever, if not even better. While everyone gets to shine, the game puts a priority in giving characters who got less screen time (Ann, Yusuke, and Haru) full arcs to really flesh out their characters. I somehow feel even more connected to this goofy group of kids than I did before, and I'm overjoyed about that. But the real stars of the show are the new characters: Zenkichi and Sophia. I'm not sure why they cooked so hard with these two, but I'm so glad they did. I won't spoil anything about these two, but just know they're absolutely amazing characters.

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers surprised the hell out of me. It's, in my opinion, the standard to which all spinoffs should try to hit. There was clear effort put into it, and it shows in the final product. From fun gameplay to an amazing story and cast of characters, I feel that anyone is guaranteed to have a good time. 8.5/10; if you like Persona, you have to play this game.

author: c557a4e197a9545bbb01d9cdc4d5288f
content:
A sequel to the original non-royal version of the Persona 5. The combat is snappy and responsive, gameplay offers a vast variety of personas, all with different quirks and skills. If you played past Persona games, especially Persona 5 of either version, a lot of weakness and skills are still the same.

As per Persona's and or Atlus's track record of UI design. It's gorgeous, very flashy and showoffs. I just wish I can buy multiple things at Sofia's shop without she thanking me for each and every purchases I made. I got about 60 hours of gameplay out of this game which I think is pretty fair and nice. Do I think it's worth 60 dollar? No. The game doesn't really evolve over it's runtime, the story is pretty meh, it doesn't offer anything than what you can see in screenshots and trailers.

I would wait for a sale in case you're interested in this game. Nonetheless, highly recommend, I had a fun time playing through the game.

content: As a spin-off sequel to the original Persona 5, this game was good. The soundtracks were as great as the original. The new characters in the main cast are really great, and their pacing when it comes to development is well-balanced too. I'd say the battle system is better than the turn-based ones—it's much more intense. The story wasn't as amazing as the prequel, but it's still good and decent nonetheless. author: c7a0b16ce9ae5f849d23288d24ed790e
content:
Do not play this game until you play at least P5 Vanilla or P5 Royal.

Unfortunately, This is not a turn-based RPG like most usual Persona franchise. If you good at playing Kingdom Hearts style gameplay then this shouldn't be much issue for you..

The story start after the event of Persona 5 Vanilla Ending and it very wisely to play the P5 first before this game base on chronological order. The story flow is pretty good just like OG Persona 5 while some NPC in P5 wont appear on P5S however they only do mention some characters in Persona 5.

The game itself quite buggy to be honest. Sometimes I got softlocked due the event not triggered end up you get stuck and can't progress any further without loading the safe file again. You need to make sure you keep saving everytime you have a chance to save the game. You don't want to lose 2-5 hr progression if you happened to get bug or softlock.

I have i7-12700 and this game really hate that CPU due to E-cores. The game will get stutter so frequently which impact the game since it's a different battle system. Lucky to those own 12th Gen Intel CPU. All you need to do is enable all CPU affinity on task manager but you have to do everytime you launch the game.

Graphic is slightly downgrade compare to OG P5. Sometimes even Graphic option is buggy for some reason.
Use Hardware Graphic settings to set your game settings like eg. Nvidia Control Panel.

TLDR;
+ Story is Good
= Require player have read a P5 Summary storyline or completed P5 Game.
= Different battle system ARPG
= Some P5 NPC is not appear in P5S however will introduce more new character in story progression.
- Hardware issue on Intel 12th Gen+ CPU due to E-cores.
- Game can softlocked you anytime. Require you consistently save the game when it possible.

author: 14051a2c1a4c57a68c802df4f60d698a
content:
The game itself seems solid but I can't recommend it due to technical issues.

I didn't have issues booting up the game but many others have reported it and the game is simply unplayable without an external tool to make performance anywhere near playable. Without Project Lasso, you can hardly get past the intro sequences.

However, while the above may be fixed and there are many tutorials for it, I encountered another gamebreaking issue that I have not seen discussed anywhere else.
At unpredictable intervals (I assume it's tied to loading into a new zone but I'm not sure), the game's bounds simply stop work. Any up-ground area is no longer pathable and you end up walking through walls. You can't use the boost points and, by some extremely inconvienient design, you are unable to reach most checkpoint areas because they are built in an upper area of the level. It doesn't affect proper progression as much, due to the fact you can still clip through terrain to reach objectives, but it breaks the flow of the game and ruins the experience.

It can be fixed by simply restarting the game from what I have seen, but good luck doing without losing progress.

It's an honest shame, Strikers seems like an excellent spin-off but you have to brute-force your way through it.

author: d345be29356850499b71c6e9e9f263d3
content:
It’s time for another persona review and I’m ready to shoot so let’s go:

Story:8/10(this has a pretty strong story for a spinoff that follows up after the orignal(not royal) but I can’t say it holds as strong as any of the mainline persona games. I feel it lacks the full oomph that persona usually has. I will say though that it does pick up after the third jail and it gets a load of more fun and interesting after that)

Setting:10/10(You’re going on a roadtrip all over Japan, that’s a weebs wet dream! Seriously though the real world locations AND the jails are greatly well done. I have no complaints on the actual jails/dungeons. My favorite jails would have to be sapporo and kyoto)

Art:9/10(Now the art should be a 10/10 and if I didn’t have technical issues that ruined gameplay and how my game had ran the whole time then it would have but that isn’t the case. Judging the game itself though,the art is pretty much the same,no improvements and there didn’t have to be so no complaints really)

Music:10/10(This is persona,of course the music is stellar and perfect. There’s alot of original songs but they have a couple of remixed songs from base persona and that’s cool. Lyn is back for singing because of course she has to be. Perfection!)

Characters:10/10(The gang is back and it’s better than ever with (spoiler alert) TWO new members to add to the phantom fray! Sophia and Zenkichi. I really got attached to Sophia the moment she was introduced. She’s such a sweetheart and her character arc is amazing to see. As for Zenkichi…….He’s also pretty cool. I don’t like him as much as Sophia but he’s still a phenomenal character and he has his own character growth. Two new characters getting a whole character arc in the game where the rest of the cast already has had theirs is a neat plot Device to put in. It really helps someone like Sophia have a foundation when she falters or needs a helping hand, she’s surrounded by people who know what she’s going through and can help along the way.)

Battle/fights:8/10(I am not really the Musou type of gamer. I don’t like them at all but persona and fate are an exception since they’re IP’s that’s I’m Familiar with and not just familiar, i love both franchises ALOT. I started the game kind of frustrated with the gameplay since I’m not fond of it but by the third jail I was having a grand ole time. Compared to fate/samurai remnant I think this is quite a bit better) 

Overall:9/10
Great game. Definitely recommend if you love persona 5 but make sure you play this after playing persona 5 if you wanna play this but haven’t played base persona 5!!

author: 1b229f4293115f66a4eb74838462c59f
content:
A much shorter game than its prequel, and lacking a lot of what made the first game unique. It feels more like a traditional Action-RPG, and the PC port is bad, especially if you play it with a mouse and keyboard. I did not enjoy the combat because of it - having one button do more things is a restriction that makes sense on consoles, NOT on PC, but at least playing on the easiest difficulty made it bearable. 
All that being said, the Mask progression is MUCH smoother, the additional commissions add some diversity to the game, and being able to go back to "dungeons" you've already finished any time you want was a great change! 
It's a bummer that we don't get to spend as much time with individual characters, and even more so that anyone but the Phantom Thieves is left out of the game - no hot nurses and teachers, sadly :( What's also sad is that your choices don't carry over, naturally, so even if you got a girlfriend in the prequel, it won't matter :(
BUT the new characters they introduced are nice, and Sophia is just the cutest little A.I. ! 
It's a fun game IF you want to spend more time with the cast, but keep in mind that it's MUCH shorter, even doing all the side quests and grinding a bit won't get you more than 35-40 hours, so I recommend buying it on sale, since the asking price of 60 Euros seems a bit steep, especially when compared to the amount of content the prequel offers for the same price point.

author: 533a9237f88d5a62b95c8e376bb47f17
content:
SHOWTIME !

Persona 5 Strikers might interest you if:
- You have completed and enjoyed P5 (P5S was released before P5R, so no Yoshizawa :/ )
- You are not averse to a fast-paced, real-time, and demanding gameplay style
- You are inclined to do even more dungeon crawling (grinding)

Otherwise, steer clear; this game has no appeal.

Compared to P5, the story is less engaging, and the life management aspect is gone.
Some game mechanic simplifications are welcome, such as the removal of Mementos.
What interests us here is the fusion between the MUSO/Hack'n'slash and the turn-based gameplay of Persona.
It's quite successful and refreshing compared to the classic Persona formula.

The game obviously has many flaws, but they are not deal-breakers. (camera, phantom dashes interrupting one more, etc...). What I don't understand is why they didn't embrace the idea of it being a sort of 1.5 sequel? I would have liked to continue from my P5 save and see the repercussions of certain actions from P5. Missed opportunity.

Clearly not the game of the year, or even of the last six months but this spin-off exceeded my expectations, and I am pleasantly surprised. A good "secondary" game while waiting for a major release.

SHOW'S OVER!

author: bae7f315dec658b38216c0049fd7e922
content:
I loved P5R and i love the combat in this game. I had originally played it on Switch just before going on vacation so the aspect of joining the Phantom Thieves on vacation was really fun. Recently I got the itch to play the game again and relive the story once more. This game is 100% better with a controller over the keyboard and despite my favorite detective not being in it, I'd happily play it over and over again.

As of writing I just started NG+ on Merciless and it's a different beast. The difficulty spike is insane compared to Merciless in Royal being barely different from the regular difficulty. That level 2 Pixie and Jack-O'_Lantern in the tutorial are now level 87~. Dire Shadows are more like Souls Bosses if you're not prepared for them, good luck not getting one shot.

Playtime Hours, how long you can expect the game to be if it's not your first rodeo

40 hours to beat the game paying attention to story. Time progresses with the story so you dont have to wait a thousand years for something to happen and the boss fights are pretty easy if you bring the right teammate

50 if you do all the quests along the way

60 to finish what you started. I would say "Grind to completion" here but honestly it's much easier to grind completion once you start a merciless run since 100%ing the compendium would take so much longer without the xp boost from being able to fight higher level enemies out the gate.

100+ if you want to suffer with the Merciless difficulty, but in order to even unlock it you must do all boss refights and their EX refight quests along with The Reaper. 

Getting the last handful of achievments is a lot easier here since you can quickly get anyone you didnt originally use to level 70 off the first few enemies in the Jail. Your main team may be around level 80-85 but anyone you didnt use may be stuck in the level 60 limbo. Dire Shadows also don't respawn in regular difficulties but on Merciless they will and are a fantastic source of BOND XP. Grinding points to fill out the last 5 personas in the compendium may be a huge pain in the rear before you get to the next Jail due to it requiring personas that were originally level 20-30. Since everything is at a higher level, it's more worth it to just grab those little guys as you progress the story while saving your points on the higher level guys that only need 2-5 levels.

I hope you'll enjoy this game just as much as I have. Remember to fuse Personas along the way unless you're like me and decide that Arsene is clearly the best (I never got rid of him, he's been at level 34 the entire game and yes I'm still using him)

author: 3cb3655eff655d45a1bec1174f6fcc91
content:
[h1]WARNING THIS GAME SUCKS ON MOUSE AND KEYBOARD. [/h1]
Persona 5 Strikers is a fun game that unfortunately had not been adapted for mouse and keyboard in any way. This is evidenced by the bizarre default control scheme (how's pressing two buttons on the opposite sides of a keyboard to activate showtime?), on-screen prompts always prioritizing keyboard bindings over mouse buttons, the fact that it's impossible to figure out how to break out of a stun when using mouse and keyboard, dysfunctional lock-on system that changes lock-on target the moment you touch the mouse and, most damaging of all, the absolutely ridiculous camera controls with [b][i]inverse[/i] mouse acceleration[/b] that cannot be disabled. That's right in Persona 5 Strikers the speed with which you move the mouse is inversely proportional to your camera speed, meaning that the slowest and tiniest of mouse movements will make your camera twitch erratically, while the fastest flicks will barely move it at all.   

I wish someone was there to warn me about this before I bought the game. Seriously, guys, if you're releasing the game on PC, could you put at least the barest amount of effort into making sure that it's actually playable on the most popular control device on that platform? 
You'll probably enjoy the game if you have the gamepad to play it, but if you don't you're better off skipping this one.

Amazing music, lovely continuation of the plot (though it's based off of vanilla, not royal, so anything to do with Maruki, Akechi, or Yoshizawa isn't touched on), and decent gameplay, but it is still a spin off. author: c6efda2ce8a85e6282ed30e000409bc9
content: Persona 5 Strikers is a satisfying and entertaining follow-up to its predecessor which successfully builds upon everything which made Persona 5's story so engrossing. The Phantom Thieves' individual characterizations and their story arcs are developed even further, over the course of a whirlwind main story full of action and excitement. The real-time combat system takes some getting used to, it's a big departure from the first game, but it's a lot of fun once you've got the basics down. The new characters are all unique, adding further diversity to the Thieves' lineup, and the story maintains consistent stakes throughout which will keep you engaged. If you liked Persona 5 and you want more of the Phantom Thieves, you absolutely need to play this game.

author: c351741343bb51d2ac53382553c15535
content:
Persona 5 Strikers isn’t just a spinoff it’s a true sequel that brings back the Phantom Thieves for another road trip full of heart, rebellion, and flashy combat. Unlike the turn-based battles of Persona 5, this game leans into real-time action with some RPG mechanics still intact. The story feels like a natural continuation, giving each character new moments to shine while introducing memorable new faces like Sophia and Zenkichi.

That said, Strikers has its fair share of criticism. Some fans dislike the shift from turn-based combat to a Musou-style system, calling it repetitive or chaotic. Others feel the game lacks the depth of the original, especially with the removal of daily life mechanics and social links. The story, while engaging, doesn’t hit as hard as Persona 5 for some players. But if you go in knowing it’s more of a road trip action RPG than a full-fledged Persona experience, you’ll still find a lot to enjoy.

author: d19014e16a795dfd8f2016ad815047cc
content: The first two arcs are kinda boring and slow, but from the third arc to the end it's straight up peak. The story is great, you unlock all the important game mechanics by the end of the second arc, so the gameplay is great from there till the end. If you played dynasty warriors or any other koei tecmo game and didn't like it, I still recommend playing this. The game is just great. Combat is fun, fast and stylish, while still not straying too far from persona gameplay, The characters are all fun to play as and have movesets that fit their personalities. The story is on-par with the original P5 and the social segments are great, although they have been moved from optional side content to the main story. The only parts I didn't like were the first two arcs cause they're lighter on story, the gameplay is far more shallow here due to not having cooking and side quests which give you more stuff to do and just make the game seem bigger. These arcs are also very over-tutorialised. There's a lot of walking for 5 seconds, only to then stop and listen to the characters explain a mechanic or objective that you really could have figured out on your own, or at the very least doesn't require the entire game to stop to tell you. Other than those first like 12-15 hours the game is great. I should also mention that this game can be quite challenging if you play on the harder difficulties and requires an understanding of both the action and RPG elements of the combat system. If you liked the original P5 you should definetly play this game too.

author: b9481715e6ed52c78a379125ba2ddeb8
content:
As a sequel to P5 Royal or Vanilla, Strikers is disappointing. I am a big fan of Atlus games, I've beaten P4, P5, P5D, P5R, SMTV Vengeance and Metaphor from start to finish. Unfortunately, beating Strikers felt like a chore.
I'd give this game a 5/10  
TLDR story was mostly rehashed, the gameplay is repetitive and it clearly lacks the polish and love that the previous games had. I'd only recommend this game for its slice-of-life moments outside the main story. Only buy it on sale. You could even save money by watching the story on YouTube instead. If you do buy it, play it on easy mode to avoid boring HP sponge bosses

VISUALS:
Pros: 
The pre-rendered cutscenes are better than Royal's. I would love to see more of this quality for future games. There are new anime cutscenes and those are stunning as well. It's wholesome to see the Phantom Thieves in a 1 year time skip with different outfits.

Cons:
The in-game graphics are a big downgrade. I guess this is a given because it's a spin-off, this was made by a different studio and they had to make the game compatible with the Switch. It is very jarring to go from Royal to Strikers. This is evident if you examine the screenshots provided by the Steam advertisement (screenshots 7/8 or 8/8 specifically) or watch 10 minutes of any gameplay footage. You can see a lot of jaggedness in the models and environments. Even the calendar UI in the top-left corner is a clear downgrade. The best fix I could find was changing my rendering scale to 2.0 but that only fixed the models. The best assets in this game are likely reused from Royal or P5 Vanilla, such as the face assets when a character is talking. All-out attacks do not have the flashy art they once had in Royal and instead use the ugly in-game models.

STORY
Pros: 
The best parts are when the Phantom Thieves need to stall X days for the main story to progress or celebrate main story progression. I enjoyed these parts more than the overall story because they actually felt brand new and watching the interaction between characters was very charming. There are some moments in the main story that tugs at heartstrings. The new party members are enjoyable and wholesome too.

Cons:
The story felt too similar to its predecessor, a lot of the plot felt the same but reskinned. I think I could summarize the plot as the same as P5 but with AI as a plot device instead of the meta-nav app.

MINOR STRIKER AND P5/P5R STORY SPOILERS SKIP TO GAMEPLAY SECTION
The following is a list of rehashes that all happened in Royal: Ann gets a greater narrative focus because of her emotional connection to the villain in the first palace. Yusuke gets a greater narritive focus in the 2nd palace. You befriend a new character who doesnt remember their past (Morgana rehash). You even befriend an older person who has a job involving the law (Sae rehash) similar to Royal. Phantom Theives are framed for cognitive murder. Palaces, palace rulers, and change of heart with a calling card are present but the game labels it as something else when it clearly plays out the same. This makes the writing feel lazy and makes the overall game feel like a cash grab.

There's also some plot inconsistencies. Joker unmasks himself on a jumbo TV for the first palace and the biggest Phantom Thief fan that makes YouTube content about them doesn't recognize him face-to-face in-person. Phantom Theives don't really bother to hide their identity when confronted with cops, Ann literally saying "“we’ve cleared our names”. There's no plot concerns about going into the metaverse in a public park with multiple witnesses present. Cops calling concepts of the metaverse "crazy" when Joker was arrested for such a case a year ago. 

GAMEPLAY
Pros:
You get to finally walk around as a Phantom Thief that's not Joker. It was so fun to run around as Morgana (I love his swirly circle leg running animation) and punch and kick as Makoto. They took the time to have the Phantom Thieves play differently and I love that. Pressing Y on Ann vs pressing it on the rest of the cast does different things. So each Phantom Thief has their own gimmick and it was fun to learn each of their combos. If you do X combo you can finish it with Y persona spell at a reduced dmg costing no sp. I really liked that combo system, it is a very unique approach because it integrates elemental weakness directly into combat, rather than relying solely on Persona spell casting.

Cons:
The biggest con is the optimization, I have a NVIDIA 3080 RTX with a Intel i7-10700k CPU and experienced around 6 crashes due to 99% cpu usage spikes. These cpu spikes didn't even make sense because I would hover 10-25% cpu usage during a story cutscene and then magically, in the same cutscene, spike to 99% and crash.

For some reason, Joker's walking speed is nerfed, this is annoying because there's a lot of walking around.
More times than in Royal, I felt like my dialogue options didn't matter. There was a time when I picked a dialogue option and I got a response that was more obviously geared towards a specific option that I didn't pick.

The gameplay quickly became repetitive because bosses had too much HP. Boss fights became 4 minutes cycles of mash combo/magic -> refill sp -> repeat until boss is dead. This got so boring that 3/4 into the game, I changed the difficulty to easy to finish fights faster.

The game puts an emphasis on playing all the Phantom Thieves equally but there is no "back-up" xp to give to the people that are benched. This unfortunately sometimes made me grind xp for 3 people at a time instead of progressing the main story. 

There are annoying side quests. Most quests are "backtrack to X place and kill Y amount of Z thing". Sometimes they ask you to kill it with X environmental gimmick. This caused me to backtrack more times than intended because my teammates killed them before I could kill them with X gimmick. There are also stealth side quests that require you to go from point A to point B without getting seen. I dont like stealth missions. These side quests occasionally locked important shop or skill upgrades, making them feel mandatory instead of optional.

The ambush targeting is awful because your ambush range is not made very clear. Sometimes there isn't cover and you have to quickly run up in knifing range behind an enemy to ambush. Other times you hide behind cover and you can suddenly leap out and ambush in 2x the range. There were even times when I could press the ambush button and ambush an enemy, even though the prompt wasn't there. I also had this incident where Morgana is extra short, so when you crouch behind a window and plan to jump through it to ambush an enemy, he comedically dashes into the wall under the window and breaks the animation instead. 

The game reuses a certain boss. At first, it's cool because it's new, then you fight it again but this time it's holding shields instead of swords. Then after fighting it with shields around 3 times, they make it hold bazookas instead....

The animations for some of the gameplay are sloppy too. You'd have a character ledge shimmying, but their model isn't even touching the wall they're shimmying on. There was also hiding behind a window but the character model is 7 inches away from the window (this is most noticeable with Morgana's model)

The velvet room felt unpolished. When registering, you only have the option to "register all" else you have to manually register personas 1 by 1. There is only the "Fuse By Result" method, the "Normal Fusion" method is not present. "Group Guillotine" is present but doesn't feel specific and special anymore, you'll see many different Unicorn persona recipes using 3 different personas in each recipe. There are no sorting options when scrolling through the list of personas to summon, it is default sorted by level. 

MUSIC:
Pros: The music is great, and the new tracks are decent too.
Cons: A lot of the music is reused from P5

author: 1c5063140771538d96b348e7868b6913
content:
Ideally I would give this a mixed review, because it's not really a *bad* game. I played it to the end and had my fun with it. Nevertheless, it's not a game I would necessarily recommend. 
Like all titles of this franchice, the story is rather bad, overly in-your-face about saying what it wants to say, too little nuance, spoiling all mayor moments before they happen and so on. The thing is, this games's writing was bad even for a persona game. Especially the majority of enemies are just, in lack of a better word, lame pathetic losers. When you think of people like Kamoshida or Madarame, you think of truely dispicable evil villains who were great at being villains. But in strikers they tried to make them "relatable" and in doing so gave them the most pathetic motivations ever. "I got bullied, so now I'll be evil too." "I'm a bad writer and then I heard someone say that I'm a bad writer! so now I'm evil!" Naturally the big bad evil is once again the same flavour of nihilism that seeps out of every Japanese media ever. "If there were no people, then nobody would suffer". And instead of that notion getting truely challenged, all you hear is "no, because I have friends". Only the third boss had a truely interesting premise and motivation, but of course we wouldn't get an actually morally interesting discussion or anything.
Obviously the amount of thinking you have to do is 0. Yes, there is a dialogue giving you an explanation of where to go, but why listen to that? everything gets marked on the map. Yes, the dungeons are actually quite cleverly and intecrately designed again, but just like in P5, there is no reason whatsoever to explore or look around how to overcome obstacles. the minimap and NPCs spoil everything. And of course when there are riddles or anything close to that, the NPCs tell you the solution too. "hey, this door is green. Think we should push the green button to open it?" yes, even riddles like that get spoiled because you cannot be trusted to think on your own aparently.
Mechanically I have to say that I don't really have anything to compare this game against. It's so far the only game of its genre that I have played. I got through quite well, so I would say it's really welcoming to newcomers to its genre and offers a lot of fun there. However I imagine avert players of this genre won't find much enjoyment in it. I played it on hard and despite being new to the genre my experience was what I would describe as normal and even merciless wasn't all that hard. if this is a newcomer's perspective, surely experienced players will find it boringly easy.
Sadly most of the time I found my AI controlled teammates to be more of a liability than allies. They die to heavily telegraphed attacks, waste their mana on healing you even if you can drain the element the enemies attack with and so on. In some fights I spent more time trying to prevent the AIs from dieing than actually fighting until I eventually decided soloing the boss was easier.

All that said, I wouldn't say it's a bad game. But you only have 24 hours in a day. your day is precious, so fill it with masterpieces instead of games that are jsut "alright". nowadays there are enough masterpieces that you don't need to settle for anything less than top.

author: 163cb0fa3a8f559db42360768f6582b0
content:
As another review I saw said, their attempt to translate all the mechanics from Persona 5's turn-based combat into real-time hack-n-slash combat really doesn't work. It's sad because some of the adaptations, like the baton pass system, are pretty fun and would be great if fleshed out more, but others like the damage type strength/weakness system just serve to make the combat overwhelming and confusing.

Now, just like Persona 5 this game's strength is much more in its story, and although not as well written as Persona 5, it is still quite enjoyable. It's just not quite solid enough to make up for how much of a slog the gameplay is.

Also, the game has many technical issues, from random crashes to some cutscenes being jittery, and there doesn't seem to be any way to fully address these issues.

author: 0d30557d540b58b48b6cb9f5a883bc9a
content:
As a sequel to Persona 5, P5 Strikers is a good game, providing a fun, if ultimately inessential, glimpse back into the lives of the Phantom Thieves, giving the player another chance to spend time with them after the mammoth of a game that Persona 5 is. The shift in genre from JRPG to musou is a curious one, but ultimately the format and general template of Persona 5 translates surprisingly well to such a drastically different genre, never feeling all that much out of place. The end result is a game that asks you, in a way, to meet it where it is, and if you can do that, you'll get a lot of value out of it.

I'm not really a musou guy - I've never really seen the appeal, and even after a full playthrough of Strikers, I can't say that I'm a convert to the genre. Keeping that in mind, though, I did have my fun with this game, ultimately, though it definitely offers a learning curve if you've never played a game like this before. It's important not to try and assert your will and your own conception of how to play on the game - let it teach you, work with its systems, and you'll really get the most out of it. Every character feels expertly translated, playing the way you would expect them to play in a real-time combat system, and though the parts of the game outside of its major battlefields are sparse and mostly just to provide short changes of pace, they still feel well-considered for what they are.

Story-wise...well, it's a summer break road trip story, ultimately. I don't think the core narrative is all that gripping or vital, but ultimately, I don't really think that sequels to Persona games need to have deep, evocative stories the way the core games do. What they do need to do instead is provide great character interactions and, frankly, fanservice in spades, and Strikers absolutely delivers on that front. Everyone feels just about pitch-perfect, if reduced a little closer to core traits, and Sophia in particular is an absolute delight of a new character. Zenkichi is fun as well, providing an oppositional force for much of the game while managing to be the butt of most of the game's jokes in the process. Basically, Strikers does a good job of adding flavor without overloading or adding weird traits to its returning cast, and that's really all you can ask of a game like this.

If Persona 5 is going to get milked to death the way 4 was, then the least Atlus could do is do it right, and do it in a satisfying way, and I think Strikers shows that they're absolutely capable of that. I appreciate the exploration of other genres via these main game spinoffs, and it's clear to me that care is put into making sure these spinoffs don't screw with the appeal of the root games. If you liked Persona 5, you'll like Strikers. Give it a go.

author: afa5b917b6ca59be94c863d13ffd5f88
content:
Persona 5 [strike] Sequel [/strike] Strikers is an excellent follow up to Persona 5 base game (not royal since there is no yoshizawa). The overall vibes of the gang and their journey stayed true to the original; comfy, lo-fi, and of course, the power of friendship. The game has its ups and downs, here are some I noticed as I played:

Pros:
- The story does not beat around the bush. It assumes that the player has played and experienced everything from its prequel. This is good because we don't have to deal with a slog segment such as reintroducing the characters. Sadly, this means that players who have not played Persona 5 will miss out greatly. 
- The animations are really smooth and stayed similar to the formula of the prequel. 
- About the gameplay. ALL team members have unique skills, movesets, and playstyles which is AMAZING. 
- The menu screen is dynamic and exciting
- The auto function in dialogues is very smooth and makes you feel like you're watching an episode with its pacing
- OST is straight up FIRE, in-battle, character themes, boss fights, story scenes, fire all-around.

Cons:
- Some dialogue in the story feels unnatural or forced
- There are some voice lines that are very inaudible (especially Ryuji's) but its only in the first portions of the game
- It is very sad that most of the confidants we met in the prequel (e.g., Iwai, Takemi) are not in this game and the reason for their absence doesn't even make sense. I guess you could argue that this game takes place in a timeline where we didn't max out our confidants in the base game, but still sad nonetheless. 
- [spoiler] Sophia's phantom thief name is seriously "Sophie". No creativity, but that's just a nitpick [/spoiler]


Overall, this is a beautifully-made game that stays true to the spirit of its predecessor. Its story and dialogue may not be the same, but for a spin-off game? Its quality is way above average. 8/10!

author: 27368232c028559e959b286f8c247b65
content:
The story is ok. The core is more of the same as what we got in P5 but with new characters, a few twists, and, surprisingly, a couple of P3 references.
It looks stylish and the music is nice.
The gameplay is not bad. The numbers go up which makes endorphins in your brain go brrr, but there are a few annoying things that make the experience worse.
For example, you know how in the previous persona games you had a choice of spending some SP to use skills to kill enemies quicker, or you can conserve SP to use later in the run, but risk being hurt now. Strikers provide you with another option – use combos which trigger a skill. And it's the first issue. What is the reason to use anything but shortest skill triggering combo? So, most of the move list is barely used.
Another strange design. Remember how you had a choice trying to push a bit further but risking losing progress, or ending the run now but you won't be able to return to combat until the next day, which in combination with tasks deadlines could create interesting situations? Forget about it. You can return to the "real world" as many times a day as you like. If it's not a limitation anymore, why won't they let a player to just restore HP/SP at checkpoints? It's 3 loading screens and a bunch of menus to get to the real world and back. And even if you don't want to return you can just restart a battle as many times on any difficulty.
Difficulty is another issue. The game actively discourages playing on hard: it warns you upfront that there’s no reward for it, then repeatedly asks you to switch to normal if you die. Grinding or improving gear feels unnecessary when the game practically begs you to take the easy route. Yeah, some dmc games did that too. You die 3 times, get a notification that an easy difficulty is unlocked, but it happens only once, not every time. Why did they do that?
Probably, because they knew something is wrong with that. Some side quests are harder than the last battle. I understand final boss should be beatable even if the player didn't finish all the side things but it shouldn't be easier than the first one.
Bosses are boring, with 2 exceptions. There are jails instead of palaces now. And they are repetitive and "stretched". Capture 3 towers with mini-bosses, fight the fourth mini-boss, fight the jail boss.
There are a few minor things also, like Joker's quick shot automatically aiming at the strongest enemy or something, trying to lock on a specific enemy is pain when there are dozens of them on the screen, the characters clipping through the hiding spots. But the worst thing is, let's say, the performance issue. Check the discussion in the steam community, check the suggested solution, and ask yourself "why would I buy this game here to get worse experience than someone who got it with 100% discount from an alternative retailer?".

author: ce4aea6a409b507e99ffadc7e6f6f033
content:
If you plan to enter Persona 5 (P5) series, you should play Persona 5 Royal (P5R) first. Persona 5 Strikers (P5S) should be played after playing P5 or P5R, especially if you plan to enter P5 series due to its story and characters.

[h2]Story[/h2]
Even though P5S released a year earlier before P5R, P5S story takes place after P5R's normal ending rather than royal or true ending. The overall story is just so-so, where there's little mention of side characters and story from P5. But I'm satisfied with the character relationships, including 2 new side characters with good character development. The villain remains mixed bags though, where I just want to beat them as soon as possible.

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
I simply don't like the hack-and-slash combat, it feels crude and unpolished for a game with $60 base price. After trying it a bit, I decided to play on lowest difficulty while cheating the amount of money, so I could buy lots of HP/SP items and spam skills. I also feel annoyed by some gameplay mechanics that are introduced halfway or later during the story.

It's also worth to mention P5S is less friendly towards casual or story-only players. Unlike P5R, P5S doesn't offer Satefy Difficulty which offers many conveniences such as option to retry if you're defeated and enemy takes longer to spot you. In addition, it doesn't let you summon high-level Persona at the beginning of the game. And just like P5R, P5S doesn't have auto-save feature either.

[h2]Other[/h2]
If you use Steam Deck or other Linux devices, P5S probably wouldn't run or run properly without a bit of tweak. By default, P5S probably will only show a black screen, unable to play video cutscene, unable to show phone UI or some of those issues. And since P5S uses Denuvo DRM, it may lock you for 24 hours while you're still trying which Proton version and launch parameters work best for your device. It's one of some cases where DRM punish legit buyers.

[hr][/hr]
Seeing Phantom Thieves back in action alone makes P5S worth it, although you better grab it during the discount. But it's less polished than P5R despite the same base price.

author: 6624568fcce25413a87f4c9ff9a79a1d
content: honestly, it is quiet a disapointing game, they took out the social sim aspect out of the game which is one of the things that makes persona games so good. I wouldn't have a problem with it if the games combat was engaging but it just feels like a lazy port of the turn based element combat to a hack n slay one which just didn't feel good, which is basically how you can describe this game. It just doesn't feel good, from the free roam to combat to the story telling and exploration, everything just feels very mid and boring. I loved the persona games and have played hack n slays before so its not really the genre that is the problem, its just the game. Not to mention that this game on PC is just not a good way to play, resolution scale doesn't work unless you edit a specific xml file which you have to find yourself, the anti-aliasing sucks which a problem with the proprietary engine that is used, the game cant be played at above 1080p which is detrimental for a game which has anti aliasing this bad, which is also dumb since console version did get above 1080p quality options, only 30 and 60 fps is avaiable, likely because of the game logic being frame based,the somewhat lazy optimization and frequent crashes. All these points combined make a really dissapointing experience, which is sad because this game could have been executed a lot better, but just felt really dull which is why i quit in the middle of the second dungeon, i really tried but it just feels like a chore. To sum it up, dont buy this game,

author: d5a1a1661e3e57ba9b68d9325f9719ca
content: A fantastic addition to the P5 universe. If you finished Persona 5 craving more, this is the perfect game to get next. The combat may be different, but it retains the charm the original game had! While the story elements are spot on, there is a few things that I would warn any new player about. First, the game has this really annoying bug where you might get stuck on a black loading screen, so make sure to save your game a lot (especially when exiting the dungeons.) Second, this might be a bit nit-picky or a skill issue, but one of the boss fights is so horribly designed in my opinion. When facing it, I felt that I had to "cheese" it in order to beat it. It also isn't balanced around normal game mechanics like the other ones (which I had no problem with those ones.) Despite these complaints, I would still recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed Persona 5. This game is very fun and is a nice continuation of the original story.

author: f4757b176585595e87ef75e55a485dfc
content: persona 5 royal was great. i played it start to finish in about a week and a half, i loved the style and whole concept of the game, everything was perfect and nothing was to be complained about. so i decided to buy the sequel, thinking itd be basically the same thing and was really looking forward to it, but after a few hours of playing, it just gets really boring. a lot of aspects about this game are low quality, it looks very rushed. the maps and the icons look bad, there is a lot of the 'arial' generic font used, and you dont really get to do much with the characters or anything at all... it just seems like most of the budget went to the fighting aspect of this game. the fighting is cool and all but you lose sp very quickly and all the different tutorials bombarding you in the first hour of playing the game is just very overwhelming, and confusing. the keybinds are weird, even after changing them and trying to adapt to them. i cannot get behind the new fighting style either, its very uncontrollable and very confusing to me. if you like fighting where youre just destroying a bunch of enemies that are swarming you, then this is the game for you. but if you enjoyed the original fighting style of persona games then i wouldnt reccomend this. the character designs are cool, the story is great, and overall its an amazing concept, but i just wished it was in the same ballpark as the original. the whole game just took the charm out of persona 5 royal, in my opinion.

author: 74034ba94d1e5535b1b4e3256693322e
content:
ive tried to give this game a couple of chances, and while i do love the other persona games and loved p5r, this game really doesnt hit the mark for me.

maybe a skill issue on my end, but the combat is really f'ed up. they straightup took nearly all of the combat mechanics from p5r, a turn based game, and crammed it in with hack and slash mechanics. a turn based game and hack and slash are so fundamentally different, you may already see where the issue is. you get no time to think or plan stuff out as you would with a turn based game, because you are getting absolutely swarmed and bombarded with so many enemy abilities. this jerry-rigged combat system really falls apart once you get a bit into the palace and start to fight stronger personas and bosses. youll get 3 strong personas that spam you with sleep abilities, keeping you hard locked on the floor, then they spam their damaging abilities that burn your health within 3 seconds. you could switch to a party member, but the enemies almost always immediately target whichever character the player is controlling, which puts you back into that same loop of being completely locked up. the other issue with this system is, in other persona games (again, turn based games) you get a chance to breathe and think after each turn, and a chance to navigate menus to use items or switch personas. that whole concept of navigating menus is also a part of this combat system.. a hack and slash game wants you to open your menus to use items while you get murdered in 3 hits or get sleep locked.. i did play this on normal difficulty and again maybe just a skill issue, but this system is not fun at all.

aside from that, theres some new soundtracks that are cool tho some are just taken straight from p5r. The artstyle is good.

the story, for the 8hrs or so that i played, wasnt that interesting. its basically "hey remember the events from p5 or p5r? yeah that didnt really matter heres a new palace, rotten adults!" so not that interesting.

honestly, this game isnt really meant for the average persona fan imo so just skip it.

author: 1e2787a998c25c7892fd5ff872741b0c
content:
A fun sequel to Persona 5 without the social sim aspect and with Musou style combat.

The game takes place a few months after P5 and assumes you already know the events that transpired in P5 with the original cast. It's a much shorter game than P5/P5R; and while the story didn't reach the highs of its predecessor, it's still enjoyable. The AI theme also still feels quite relevant today.

I prefer the turn based combat of mainline SMT and Persona games, but the Musou style combat was definitely an engaging new experience for these series. It also features two new playable characters aside from the originally playable main cast from P5 (not P5R).

The music and graphics maintain the style of P5/P5R, so if you enjoyed those elements from the prior game you will feel right at home.

author: 6b4142a4175552919d66f802551a9a47
content:
Solid Spinoff with more Adventures with the gang as they explore japan in their summer trip across a variety of locations which is unique to the series where they usually are contained to one location and the jails and monarchs are very reflective of the setting which adds a lot of variety to the level design and the aesthetics,

The Cast have their small arcs in relation to the monarchs of each jail Like Haru, Yusuke, and Ann which adds a lot of personal stakes to the conflict and all the villains are very tragic and you can understand what drove them to be the person they are

 Sophie was Cute Addition and her character arc of learning the human heart was very cathartic where she throughout her advantages connects with the cast and gains her own form of heart and being inspired to do the same for someone else despite being an AI,

 Zenkichi was really dope and a lot of Persona fans being complaining too much how they want adult protags with Personas when he is right here, His Arc with his Daughter and being Cop are very similar to Persona 4 with the MC host family struggling to connect with each other but where P4 focused more on the family aspect, P5 strikers is more focused on the cop side of the relationship where he questions where he stands in the force and his own sense of Justice and that made him so engaging and he really fits in with the cast despite having shady intentions and his abilities are really dope where his Persona is mainly buffs and almighty damage ,
 
Gameplay of being Action RPG transitions a lot of Royal mechanics really well, A lot of your items such as Weapons and Protectors matter a lot here since you have to rely on that more and the persona skills SP gauges would dry quick if you do not place important on the combat, The Enemy variety between the jails is very consistent and stylized to reflect on the location and you need to make sure you have different personas to deal with all types of weaknesses and you have incentive to use all the characters with the Master arts system where they get combat buffs and bonuses to more you use them in your team and they can be really useful

There aren’t any social links but there is a bond system where you level up passive skips for when you are exploring or in combat which each interaction with the cast and this is really cool like upgrading damage for everyone, HP and Sp increases, etc
 Sticks to Core Ideas, 

High 7

Considering this is just a spinoff, this game is amazing.
Overall the story has a very slow start, but it gets better after a while. Near the end the story did lose most of the momentum in my opinion, but it was still very good.
The gameplay gets really repetetive in my opinion though. Overall this game is great and you can get it for incredibly cheap on sale, so I can definitely recommend it to other people.

author: c66c46c9f20d52ca95bb8466e8f5d366
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an action RPG which continues the story of Persona 5 Royal, where the Phantom Thieves reunite to face a new threat involving a suspicious Artificial Intelligence mobile phone app, while taking a summer road trip to several Japanese cities.

I’m still relatively new to the Persona franchise, having only previously played Royal earlier this year, although I plan to play more games developed by Atlus in the future.

[h1]Gameplay (medium quality)[/h1]

•	While Royal featured a typical JRPG style turn based combat system, Strikers uses a real time with pause system instead. You’ll choose a party of 4 characters and can take direct control of any character. Each member of the Phantom Thieves can perform magical attacks focused on a different type of elemental damage, and the gang’s leader Joker can switch between multiple personas, giving him access to every type of magic.

•	While exploring each dungeon in the metaverse (in Strikers they’re called “jails” instead of “palaces”, but they’re functionally the same), you’ll have to defeat shadows which take the form of various monsters, each having their own elemental strengths and weaknesses. You can run around the battle arenas using melee attacks to take out weaker enemies, but ideally you’ll want to use magic attacks to target stronger enemies’ weaknesses, making them vulnerable to powerful all out attacks. Most magic attacks can hit multiple enemies, and the action will pause while you select a spell and aim at the desired area.

•	I wouldn’t say the combat system is bad, but I personally didn’t really enjoy it. Royal’s turn based system was much better and more tactical. In Strikers, most fights feel really chaotic, with large numbers of enemies and lots of magical effects on screen, making it hard to see what is actually happening, so I felt like the only way I could consistently avoid enemy attacks was to frequently mash the dodge button between my own attacks.

•	SP management is also a constant problem. Because of the high volume of enemies, you can very easily burn through all of a character’s SP (used to activate magic attacks) in a couple of fights. Meanwhile, bosses have huge health bars, and mini-bosses seem to have infinitely respawning waves of minions. You’ll definitely need to buy as many SP restoring items as possible from shops.

•	Strikers has less side activities than Royal. Each city you visit is really just a couple of streets with a few shops, and no significant NPCs or side quests. Strikers’ equivalent of side quests mostly involve returning to previously completed jails to kill certain enemy types or collect junk items, to unlock new weapons and upgrades. On the plus side, at least it won’t take forever to complete this game (I mostly enjoyed Royal, but I eventually felt that it was a bit too long and bloated).

[h1]Story (high quality)[/h1]

•	Story is well written, although several of the jails and bosses have similar themes to those found in Royal.

•	The Phantom Thieves, including a couple of new allies, are interesting characters.

•	English voice acting is good for the whole cast.

•	I strongly recommend playing Royal first, because the story assumes the player is already familiar with who the Phantom Thieves are, how the multiverse works, and other events which took place during the previous game.

[h1]Technical (high quality)[/h1]

•	It took me 42 hours to complete the story.

•	I didn’t have any problems with bugs, crashes or framerate.

•	Controls worked well on my Xbox 360 gamepad.

[h1]Recommendation[/h1]

Persona 5 Strikers is a good game, but because of its strong focus on story, I’d only recommend it to fans of Persona 5 Royal who want another adventure with the Phantom Thieves. As this is an older game, you should be able to pick it up for a big discount on a sale.

author: 962549ce6a9d5a58896d67338e999d90
content:
Persona 5 Strikers plays like the elements of Persona 5 Royal distilled. Narrative-wise, it's a smoother experience.; its themes, in my opinion, are a much better fit for the modern sensibilities. It is the Modern Persona (starting from 3) even more modernized.

For context, the director of Persona 3, 4 and 5 Katsura Hashino left after the completion of 5. There has been a noticeable shift in the games' style from then on. It is not so significant where it ceases to be Persona, and it may even just be a phantom thought perpetuated by confirmation bias. But "something" is different. Ideas are grander; characters are more sympathetic and complex. Themes are somewhat more nuanced. I vastly prefer Maruki to Shido, and I enjoyed the characters in Strikers as well as their moral dilemma. However, the details and the atmosphere do not feel as distinct as the three games helmed by the previous director. Sorrow, self-doubt and rage. The details of the story feel less fine-tuned, and while I like the plot, the actual delivery often feels questionable. Not enough to cause any actual complaint, just enough to make me go "huh, wait a second" afterwards. But enough blabbering, onto some actual review stuff.

Plot: The themes shift from 5's rather straightforward "let's go f up some baddies who are stand-ins for somehow actual real-life people (which is more messed up since we don't have a group of highschoolers changing their hearts)". Striker focuses instead on once well-intention people who have become cruel due to past trauma. So you have actual likable villains with sympathetic motivations. Mr. Zephyrman's theme song counter-strike is honestly so good. But the details don't exactly hold up since said "becoming twisted" is part of the villain's design which takes away accountability to a degree (it is revealed that the monarchs were intentionally chosen, and becoming a monarch demonstrably has negative psychological effects. This detracts somewhat from the theme of good people turning bad from trauma.) The game also never goes far enough into the theme for my liking. For example, the main cast acknowledges the enemy's sympathetic motivation and tragic past; they proceed to judge said enemy which is perfectly fine. But they never address the root cause of said trauma - the people who created the toxic environment that made these good men go bad. There is also the other theme of blind reliance on technology/ giving up their desire. This is a repeat of the demigurge story beat in 5 but done not as well since it fails to connect itself to the rest of the story as well. (I love Ichinose as an idea, but she barely does anything. Boo) The plot is more evenly distributed so every character gets their chance to shine at one point.... except Mona? (Yay Haru though) The cast is as enjoyable as they were in 5. So there's that.

There is a dungeon quality drop-off in the middle where things just don't feel as well designed after the first few dungeons, but it manages to end on a strong note which is good enough for me.

As for gameplay, I'm surprised a hack-n-slash game managed to incorporate in Persona's feature gameplay mechanics. The start is a bit rough and takes time getting used to, but I can confidently say that this is my favorite musou game alongside Dynasty warriors 2.

author: 44b17ab5ca625d5f910b971b3dbf3bc2
content:
As a huge fan of the Persona franchise, especially Persona 5, I was ecstatic to find that a new Persona 5 game on which I want to dive into. I have finished the original Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal, with over 400+ hours of playtime for both games. (can you tell that I really love the franchise? lol)

At first I was hesitant to try it for after reading about that game, it swaps out the traditional turn-based combat for a hack-and-slash gameplay. I was unsure if this change would work, but the transition feels surprisingly seamless. Persona 5 Strikers still retains the strategy elements, allowing you to pause and plan your next moves. 

One of the most enjoyable aspects of Persona 5 Strikers is reuniting with the beloved Phantom Thieves. The game picks up after the events of Persona 5, and the story feels like it's really well crafted. The characters are just as vibrant and relatable as before, and the addition of new faces adds fresh energy.

The visuals! Oh the visuals! I first remembered playing Persona 5 for the first time and I could just look at it all day. Especially the menu screen! Persona 5 Strikers are just as stylish and visually striking as in the original game, with that signature Persona aesthetic still front and center. The design is sleek and intuitive, and the soundtracks are just awesome. It brings a hint of nostalgia, while different, continues to deliver with remixes of iconic tracks alongside new ones that fits the games's more action-packed tone.

Overall, Persona 5 Strikers is a fantastic continuation of the Phantom Thieve's journey. I have played for about 10 hours of the game and I'm really loving it! I cannot help but smile while playing this game. (A really huge fan of the game, right?) The game offers an engaging blend of action, strategy, defeating a lot enemies (hack-and-slashed),  and of course a heartfelt story. If you're a really big fan of the franchise such as myself, this game is a must have.

author: bbbc149c3e635bd280e9e8599159f48d
content:
Pretty decent sequel to an already amazing game. It's certainly not perfect like Royal, and unfortunately with some issues in this game I can't help but see it as the inferior version. But if you are able to ignore them, it's still a good game. If you loved the story and characters of this game, I definitely recommend it. But if you enjoyed only the turn based combat, then it won't be for you. It's completely different, but a change is refreshing.

The combat is... interesting. I actually didn't like it at first. It felt complicated and overwhelming. I originally thought the battling had little to no strategy but the more I played the more I realized that's wrong and it's not just button smashing. Right after the first Jail is when I started to enjoy the game a lot. Though, embarrassingly, I only really started to learn the combos by the last Jail. I didn't realize there was so much move variety depending on how many times you press Attack before you press Special. I also really enjoy how each Phantom Thief has their own moveset, and speaking of, I love that you can play everyone!

All the new characters, both Phantom Thieves and bosses, are really well written. My favorite part of P5R was the social aspect, so I was kind of bummed that social links weren't present in this title, but I enjoyed how they implemented the social aspect in this game too. The most unfortunate part about this is the new Royal characters are missing.

Speaking of great characters, the story is really good, as per usual in the Persona series. Some spoilers ahead: [spoiler] I was curious how the Metaverse was going to return, and I enjoy how it was implemented here. [/spoiler] Also, as I mentioned in the previous paragraph, the characters and their developments are just so good and I really hope we get to see more of them in future P5 titles. ([spoiler] Specifically Zenkichi and Akane!!!! [/spoiler])

The new environments are really refreshing, and speaking of(again), I really love the investigation phases before going into the jails. Being able to explore the new areas and talk to all the phantom thieves while they just hang out in the area is awesome. 

Speaking of the jails (again again), It's cool how they take over a whole city, but that makes them less memorable/detailed. My favorite parts was the last couple minutes of the jail, and the boss of each area. Though with some negatives also comes positives... There's a ton to explore and it's kind of just fun to have a sandbox to just mess around in. It's also a GREAT QoL change that you can go in and out of Jails without time passing (the calendar system is basically not important at all) and jails NEVER go away. And you can re-fight the bosses! So awesome. (and forgot to mention, all bosses are really fun.)

The new request and bond systems are really nice. The requests feel a lot more unique to the system in Royal. Instead of every single request being tracking and then defeating the enemy in mementos, there's something different to do each time. Whether that is killing an enemy with in a specific way, or getting items for people, it's refreshing. The bond system is also pretty nice. It's almost like the social-link/stat upgrades but you have a little bit more freedom with it. (but I gotta say... the achievement maxing the bond's is quite a grind lol)

I've already mentioned a couple negatives in my previous paragraphs, but I just want to go over them all now. 
-The new engine doesn't feel great when moving around in the overworld. Metaverse feels fine though.
-Voice acting is pretty quiet. Turning down the SFX & music helped. Still disappointing though.
-Anti-Aliasing is basically non-existent and most characters and models look horrendous from far away.
-Lack of Royal characters, story arcs, and QoL changes is disappointing. (Both Royal and Strikers was in development at the same time sadly)
-The game didn't even run on Steam Deck without Proton, and then the cutscenes had no voice acting in it. (Which you can fix by putting GST_PLUGIN_FEATURE_RANK=protonaudioconverterbin:NONE %command% into the launch options.)
-Controls being completely swapped is a minor annoyance, but still,
-And worst of all, barely any patches for this game. I feel most of the stuff I mentioned above is fixable... But only 2 patches since 2021. Really disappointing

Regardless, even though I just mentioned a TON of negatives compared to my Persona 5 Royal review, I still think this game is good. But I'm unsure if I'd recommend it to everyone like how I recommend Royal. If you enjoy the characters/story then most definitely. It's just such a different game. I know the dev teams that made Royal and Strikers are completely different, but I kind of wish ATLUS gave the Strikers team a bit more time to cook before releasing.

author: e08ca83cc35c5834a5966afea54274b5
content:
This game is currently in the Humble Choice for October 2024, and this is part of my coverage of the bundle. If you are interested in the game and it's before November 5th, 2024, consider picking up the game as part of the current monthly bundle.

It’s Persona Warriors. 

This game was made by the Persona team, as well as Omega Force, which is better known as Koei Tecmo’s team that does the Dynasty Warriors titles and pretty much all the Musou games, so what is this one? Well, it’s either a Persona game that has combat very similar to Musou titles with large battlefields and tons of enemies, or a Musou game with a lot of RPG elements and non Musou gameplay. 

Truthfully, I think the former is correct. This is a Persona game telling more Persona tier stories. You don’t choose a level, instead there’s an obscenely long opening, like every Persona game, and there’s a lot of time spent outside the dungeon. The dating system isn’t here, but this title is still heavily based on Persona 5.

Which is also potentially a downside. You totally can start here if you want to skip the first game, but there’s a hundred hour game that comes before this that’s a typical JRPG. If you’ve played that and want to see more of those characters, then this exists. But there are, of course, spoilers, even just who is in the cast is likely a spoiler for Persona 5.

Pick this up if you want another Persona 5 story, or you just want every Warrior game. I like Persona, but I have this because it’s Omega Force, and I’m very happy with that. It’s not a Dynasty Warriors game, in the same way Hyrule Warriors wasn’t a Dynasty Warriors game, it’s a merging of the two franchises, and that makes it something unique. 

Also, this is like a 40 hour title, so be prepared. This will take a long time, especially if you go through all the dialogue.


If you enjoyed this review or want to know what I think of other games in the bundle, check out the full review on or subscribe to my Youtube channel: https://youtu.be/m9hzsr75eQQ

author: 62142159039b559a9b005f8fefbadaf4
content:
It's fine for what it is. It didn't wow me in the same way that P5R did, but it was nice to get some more time with the characters and I really enjoyed the soundtrack and some of the environments present in the game.

For gameplay, I am not experienced in the hack-and-slash genre at all, but I can safely say that I had fun. The game can be cheesed somewhat easily once you figure out the main combos, but I thought that the difficulty was overall fine. Controls are smooth and once I figured out the groove it was very fluid and satisfying.

As for the story, it has its ups and downs. There were times where it felt slightly contrived but I didn't mind it that much and I did appreciate some of the tropes, one of which in Okinawa I personally really liked but will avoid saying more as to not spoil it. The soundtrack is VERY good and has its own unique identity compared to P5R (less funky jazz and more rockish, which I think fits the hack-and-slash well). Art and visuals are of course still stellar.

Overall its good and fun but don't expect it to be on the level of P5R.

author: 40cce370dd6c5d82ae24d9d5845fef3a
content: I like Persona 5 and One Piece Pirate Warriors. For some reason I can't get into this game, and have tried on multiple occasions to get into it, but can't get more than an hour or two into the game without getting tired of it. I think it's partially because there's not much character exposition as Persona 5, or because the instances are longer than Pirate Warriors (Jails take around 2 to 3 hours it seems to play through, whereas Pirate Warriors instances are over in less than 30 minutes). The game looks pretty, but it's too much action for too long. There are no breaks and it requires too much sustained focus. I'm getting too old for games like this, I'm a lazy gamer who works too much as an adult to put this much energy into a game. It's a great game for somebody, and if I'd picked this up five years ago I probably would have liked it, but being the crustifying aging adult that I am with almost zero excess energy, it is too much for me. I admit defeat.

author: ef39d3cd2ce7522b9cc53dc9a5e06a9b
content: I didn't expect this game to be so good. The combat is very fun, but I have not played many combat games similar to Persona 5 Strikers. It was hard for me to get used to the combat, since I was not used to this sort of game, but after picking it up after a while, I got a handle of the characters' skills and fighting style. The plot of the story is very heartfelt and emotional. The antagonists of each Jail relate to the Phantom Thieves in some ways, and that allows an extremely touching moment between the two parties. I enjoyed every arc. It's really nice how they are able to balance hype, emotion, and wholesome moments so well. If I had any qualms, I would say how some controls would unexpectedly stop working during combat, and I would have to tab back in the game to get it working again. Other than that, very fun game. I love Sophia. Her arc really reminds me of how it is right now in 2024 with AI.

author: 054fde696dee5fe7994cc573139abad1
content:
Not usually my type of game but honestly good fun if you enjoyed P5R. Some really annoying and lazy interface decisions (like, if you fail a challenge it gets cancelled, meaning you have to leave the mission, leave the mission hub, then navigate through a bunch more menus to reactivate it before re-entering the hub, reloading the map, and trying again; like not being able to access the general game menu during a fight, -- just general QoL shit, the absence of which is basically disrespectful of your time.) Some of the basic game mechanics are flawed too -- there is no penalty for withdrawing from a mission at any time, and you go back in with your HP and SP fully restored, so seemingly to compensate there's a chronic shortage of SP items, essentially forcing you to quit out on the regular and leaving you short for boss fights. The challenges are some tedious rubbish as well, with useless rewards, the later Jails feel a bit more rushed than the first few, and in some (well, quite a lot of) places the performance really chugs. 

But the gameplay feels good, once it clicks, the story is goofy fun, the difficulty curve is okay with no major roadblocks, and at the end of the day it's more Persona. One to pick up on sale.

author: 902f02b38a665122ae587d50862bf8dd
content:
[i]Persona 5 Strikers[/i] was a big let down for me. The combat is fine, but feels too slow during boss fights and doesn't fit the Persona series well. The story is boring, it has some standout moments, but most of them are over a dozen hours in and getting to that point was painful (switched to easiest difficultly purely to make the game faster). There is a ton of pointless exposition as well. The music is great, as usual, but most of the tracks were already in [i]Persona 5[/i]. At this point I'd consider myself a big Persona fan, having played P3R, P4G, and P5R. I enjoyed those games because they are stellar industry-best-level JRPGs, and have interesting stories with some lovable characters. [i]Persona 5 Strikers[/i] is not a top tier [i]Dynasty Warriors[/i]-style game, or hack and slash game, the story takes criminally long to become interesting, and the writing is significantly worse than the main series games. If you're deep into Persona fandom, then maybe [i]Persona 5 Strikers[/i] will work for you, but even when I tried to look at it through that lens I was bothered because there were countless moments where the writing ignores the the entire year Joker has already spent with the Phantom Thieves. 

[b]Not Recommended[/b]

[i]If you found my review helpful, please consider following my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44234346/]Steam Curator page[/url], where you can see more thoughts and recommendations[/i]

author: f8b260d40c0959e4815dd1af2d4d4058
content:
I loved Persona 5 Royal so much that I played it twice back-to-back. This is a sequel spin-off, but it's not quite the same as P5R, it feels a bit hollow. The main cast is back, and it's great to spend time with them again. Most of the side-characters are not, but since this game covers a road trip summer break, that makes sense and I can live with it. The story is interesting and is the main driving force that keeps me playing, because the combat is not good or fun, at all. 

**Edit: I did end up lowering the difficulty and that made the combat much more bearable. The story is essentially a re-tread, but enough is different that I feel it's worth it to play for story alone. 

I've seen this game compared to the musou Warriors games, but that is a lie - this game is far more punishing than a Warriors game, even on normal. The average enemies usually aren't too bad, but when there's a lot of them it becomes hard to keep track of what they're all doing. They don't always telegraph their physical moves, and dodging their magical moves can be difficult sometimes due to the damn camera moving the way it wants and not the way I want. It's very easy to keep getting destroyed by named enemies or bosses (who are very spongy), then for some reason things go your way and you succeed - until the next one comes along and repeats the process. Every time I thought I had a handle on the combat, the game proved I hadn't. All your characters can die in seconds before you have time to react. This is annoying, frustrating, and a real fun-killer. 

I don't mind difficult games when they're fair, but this game does not feel fair. People say it gets better after the second dungeon, but even if that's true it's terrible game design. And if it doesn't get better, I don't think I can force myself to keep playing (even on easy) no matter how good the story is.

author: df36c7f365db521e890a4fddc80786ec
content:
If you're looking for a sequel, this will do quite nicely. The story line is fleshed out and also enjoyable.

Those who aren't fans of hack and slashers like me can just set the difficulty to easy to enjoy the story. Those with proficiency should set it to hard for a proper challenge. Great use of the difficulty levels. (And no, none but the most proficient should try merciless, only available on NG+. I didn't even get out of the opening battle.)

The only complaint as it is was the ultra long grind to get the final achievement for 100%. That took a significant portion of the listed playtime.

author: 33883459085959e69e53a93f8c4097cd
content:
A great Persona 5 sequel. The story was neat, and its writing improved greatly from the last entry. The new characters are amazing, and I was happy to see some previous characters had more screen time.

The soundtrack was peak; mind-blowing and remarkable, they nailed it with its acid-jazz, rock, and obviously with Lyn's astonishing performance!

It was cool to see the “Persona-fication” of the hack-and-slash genre. The gameplay was good, but it still has some room for improvement, so I hope they look forward to improving it in the next entries of the Persona series.

I recommend it, as it was such a fun and exciting experience.
