author: 17f7fa9896b25aa7b74668b228b21f92
content:
6/10. Pick it up on a sale. Not worth it full price. 
TLDR: Gameplay is OK. Story is.... don't think about it too much. Characters finally have a moment to breathe which they kinda lack in P5. Cool vibes. Sometimes funny writing. Not too serious game. 6/10.

As to why 6/10: Stikers sorta exists in this wierd space in between Vanilla P5 and P5R but technicaly plays after the events of P5R.
The character portrais are all still Vanilla P5 (big deal, I know). Everybody ignores what happened in the third semester. Sumi and Maruki never existed. That sort of stuff. 
Also, a lot of the story beats and new characters feel ripped out of and copied from P5 and wierdly P4 (which is funny coz' P5 already straight up took some stuff from the P4 story). 
Zenkichi feels like a copy Dojima but ordered from Temu. At least his gameplay is nice.
The actual Persona mechanics feel a bit tacked on. The Hack&Slash feels kinda basic (and also some attacks look like they ripped the animations straight out of DMC5 but we don't talk about that). The Combination of the two hold each other back.

I think that's enough for a Steam review.

author: 318e1cecc8df5b64b37274f096506483
content:
If you loved the Phantom Thieves so much you just need another adventure with them, Strikers will do the job just fine. it's a sequel story with hack&slash gameplay that manages to translate some of the mechanics of the original P5 to action combat in a fun way. However, there are plenty of problems with this title and it really feels like a lower production qualiity product. Which it is, which is fine for a (sequel) spin-off, but it does get in the way of fun sometimes.

First off, there is no time management aspect at all. You're on a set schedule and there is no way to run out of time. If you're facing any difficulty during the game, you can always get back to the car, heal up and get back into the action. If you were looking for the time-limited life-sim gameplay of Persona games, you can turn back now. There are no Social Links, let alone any dating elements. You can do optional Bond scenes which are a far cry from the Confidants.

The introduction to the combat can be overwhelming. The game constantly throws new info at you and gives you almost all the playable characters very early on. I recommend taking a time for yourself to play around with available Phantom Thieves, pick your favorites and learn to use them before rushing into the story. However, once you figure out the basics, the game actually does a decent job of incorporating Persona mechanics. You can chill on the Easy difficulty if you just care about the story or beat the game on Hard and then move onto Merciless if you want to test yourself.

Strikers messes up Persona fusion pretty badly though. The cast of demons is limited, which is understandable, but the actual act of fusing up new demons feels very restricting. Eventually you're going to need to grind up levels of old demons if you want to unlock a new Persona to use. This made engaging with the mechanic a chore, completely unlike the addicting nature of sitting in the Velvet Room and fusing stuff in the original P5.

The story feels like a rehash of most of the story beats of Persona 5. While sometimes Strikers uses this as an opportunity to show how the Thieves have matured, a lot of the time the story will just feel like the same thing all over again. Most of the old characters have their moments, especially Haru, who was poorly treated in the original. The new additions to the cast are surprisingly good and feel right at home with the OGs.

The game was developed by another studio and used a different engine, which worked well for the action gameplay, but exploration in city areas was sometimes very clunky. Joker could not sprint and navigating familiar areas like Leblanc felt like a cheaper experience. The UI, while definitely stylish, did not feel as smooth to click through. You often had to wait for the animations to play out before being able to move to another window, meanwhile in the original game, you could move through the menus pretty quickly if you remembered your way around the UI.

Lastly, grinding the Bond level is a giant chore. You can either farm the same thing on Merciless, replay the story or use repeatable spots which give small Bond boosts. All of which will bore you eventually. It's decent for mindless playing while listening to a podcast or whatever else you prefer.

in summary, if you want more Phantom Thieves, get the game on a discount and just beat the story.

author: 2559b6456cb252cd86fa5bed94e78ac1
content:
Do yourself a favour and skip this one. It's not a terrible game by any means, and might even have been decent as a stand-alone experience, but as a follow up to Persona 5 of all games, it falls quite flat. I would even say that it somewhat takes away from the Persona 5 experience, given how high a note the original game ended on.
This game basically has Dynasty Warriors gameplay with a coat of Persona paint, the same characters as Persona 5 (not Royal) but with a lot less depth than before, and a tedious and slow storyline with boring and repetitive quests tossed in. You could play it if you just want more Persona 5 no matter what, but I wouldn't recommend it.

author: 8fa8921e0ef45770bcce010326dfa6e6
content:
A bit disappointed in this one, which is a shame because I think the core of the game itself is good but there is just a bunch of small issues I have with it that stack up to lessen the experience for me.
Probably my biggest gripe with this game is the gameplay. For the most part, Strikers's gameplay is fun, frantic and engaging. It adapts a lot of Persona usual mechanics and gameplay like All-Out Attacks, 1 Mores and Persona skills really well into the hack-n-slash genre. I really did enjoy this game's combat... for the first 10 or so hours. After a while the combat just turns into repeat the same few combos over and over again until all the enemies die. There's barely any challenge and it starts to get really repetitive, especially if you're doing the requests. Another small gripe I have that turned into a pretty big one was that, out of all things that were brought over from the original Persona 5, the game did not bring back sharing EXP from battles with all the benched party members. This leads to nearly all of the characters aside from the three you pick for your party and Joker to be very underleveled, which is a bit of a problem in some bosses, especially the final boss which requires you to use all of the party members for it.
Other than the gameplay, the story this time is pretty uninteresting. A lot of the story's themes just feel like a retread of the original Persona 5's themes, which I know sounds like a stupid complaint considering this is a spin-off of P5 but other Persona spin-offs like Persona 4 Arena also had similar themes to its original but also added more on top of that. The only other message this game offers other than rebellion is that AI can be used terribly in the wrong hands, which is a nice message but it doesn't really correlate back to or add on top of Persona 5's already existing themes like P4A
There is one thing I do really like about this story though and that's interactions and chemistry of the Phantom Thieves. This might be a hot take but I much prefer how the thieves act as a group here than they do in the original. They feel a lot more like an actual group of friends, where as in the original Persona 5 they felt like people who were only friends because of their connections to the Phantom Thieves. It's probably because of this game's more chill setting of a holiday but the characters are able to shine a lot more as friends than they ever did previously.
I know I've sounded very negative in this review but if you did enjoy Persona 5 and want a follow-up on its story with some faster gameplay then I would definitely recommend this game. Just lower your expectations a bit when jumping in.

author: 7d2c2d0a3f345980a41d603ad6a2625a
content:
While I'm not usually a fan of hack-and-slash combat in games, I found this to be quite enjoyable, even though it was pretty difficult at first. I ended up getting all the achievements, which is high praise for a genre I generally dislike.

I love the Persona series, but I approached this game somewhat half-heartedly. As a spin-off of Persona 5, I didn't expect it to offer much beyond some story content. However, I was pleasantly surprised by how well the game turned out. The fusions have unique mechanics compared to Persona 5, and the game did a great job making hack-and-slash combat enjoyable for me.

The story was also quite good, and I thoroughly enjoyed it. Overall, I think this is a great game to try if you're looking for more after beating Persona 5. (Yeah, you should play Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this.)

author: fce5f4585af2590abab24dccf53c6f4e
content:
CONS:
- Frames drop insanely in this game! I tried turning the quality and everything else on "low" but nothing seems to work. The only thing that worked for me was someone's suggestion online to install "Process Lasso". With this, and only this, was I able to play the game normally. 

- Game is so repetitive and dull fight wise. This is probably my fault cuz i came into the game expecting it to be something like Dynasty Warriors since I saw the game tagged with "musou". So i was like "WOW, a JRPG and musou, gotta try that". Welp, no. It didn't do it for me xD

- Most times, the dialogues are boring and just unnecessary, like they talk way too much when there's no need for that.
An example:
-Person X is feeling down-
-The friend group tries to cheer X up- :
Person A: Hey dont't be sad, it'll all turn out well.
Person B: Yeah we'll all work together to solve this issue, then you won't have anything to worry about!
Person C: Eactly, what Person B said! We shall stick together and never leave you alone in this!
Person D: Ohohoho, dont't forget, we're the Phantom Thieves after all. We help all those in need!
Person X: Aw you guys ;-;
Person E: hehe, cmon cheer up already!
Person F: Yeah cheer up!
Person G: Cmon X, a smile suits you best!
Person X: Thank you guys <3
-Now Person A to G all start replying one after the other-
Like literally why does the whole group have to reply on every single thing T_T This made me skip like 75% of the dialogue. and only read main parts and story explanations. Oh, sometimes even the explanation and plan discussions take TOO LONG so i skip that too x). At this point i started not giving a fuck about the story too, sadly, hehe :^)

- The way they set up Achieving the side quests is messy imo and made me feel like it's such a chore..
and the rewards for them weren't .. rewarding.

PROS: 
- Game brings back personas and skills from Persona 5, so yay. That didn't change when it switched to musou, hack n slash.
- Makoto.
- I liked the fact that they move from a city to another. I'm always excited to know which place is next.
- You can buy ingredients and cook :D
- Think it had a decent plot twist.

CONCLUSION: 
Of course Steam doesn't have a neutral rating button. It's either a YES or a NO xD and I'm more of an in between here :^)
It's not all that bad if you speed run throughout the game like I did xD If you wanna buy it, then do so on sale and never on full price ._.
Btw, I spent about 35 hours on the game, the rest was afk ops x_x

author: d5967010d13c53e9b3be19bbf277c26a
content:
Simple warning. While this game has the "Dynasty warrior" gameplay, you only get short fights without territory control mechanics. it's basically an action rpg with heavy emphasis on the hack'n'slash. 
While a sequel to P5R it is not required to have played the previous game. But it will help to know who's who and what everyone is able to access. Also some plot-related spoiler.

why does it take hours to finish the intro?
...because you get interrupted every 5 second of gameplay. the only time you aren't stopped right in your track while doing something is during cutscene. 
I got four separate pop-up window, stopping all gameplay, to tell me I can use a special attack when the enemy is down.
One for the basic information... cool. thanks. I'll make use of that. 
second to tell me I can do the same when I down an enemy with an attack... well duh, I pretty much got that from the first one... why not tell me at the same time?
third to tell me I can do the same when I down the enemy with a status effect.. Couldn't you just include this in either of the previous pop-up or as followup information? no? why wait 5-10 seconds before telling me this. why tell me at all? I thought this was an ACTION game...
Fourth to tell me I can do the same when I down the enemy with an attack using their weakness... ARE YOU FUCKING SHITTING ME?! Is this game for children with ADHD so severe they can't read or press buttons?

This is just an example. Those four didn't come at the same time. I managed to get half a combo in between each. And to make matters worse, I got ANOTHER pop-up in the NEXT battle saying the same thing, but this time it was to tell me I can down an enemy and look up tutorials to know more. 

This is a sequel.

Sure, the genre change a lot. Some of the mechanics are pretty different. You can actually do the special attack on ANY downed enemy and it will also hit any enemies near the target.  (NEVER MENTIONNED/SPECIFIED IN ANY OF THOSE STUPID TUTORIAL leaving players of the prequel thinking they might need to down more than one or all of them... one try is enough to know those facts, but I needed four tutorial to know I can do the same attack on ANY kind of downed enemies? After the first one said pretty much that?) 

I am annoyed.

And this is the SAME GAME that throws you in a fight the very moment you start, with no explanation of any kind. Throw the cub down the cliff, dont say anything and leave. Sure, I'm a gamer, I can figure out the very basics on my own. Move, attack, trial and errors style... also the HUD show some buttons so I pressed them to see what it would do. etc. 
That's how the very first fight starts. it's not until you defeated a bunch of enemies that you finally get a clue on what to do.
With a big fat interruption pop-up. Jump there, do this, go there. Progress, sure...
then mindless banter and "press forward" moments for like 20 minutes. not so bad considering...
You know... I've had countless DOWNED enemies, Used a lot of special attack on them. Got all out attacks, special animation, weird combo. but it's only 2h in that they give me the pop-up... WHILE TRYING TO INFILTRATE MID-JUMP. ofc I miss the target, it insta-drop me as the one ambushed.
then interrupt after my first hit (nothing got downed). ok, got it, do the same as I did so far. good talk tutorial. I get a few hits in, the second oen pops up. go away, I don't care anymore. i kill a few enemies. another pop up. and then another mid-combo.

you know what kind of tutorial pisses me off the most? THAT KIND. Don't interrupt gameplay, dont force a pause in the middle of the action. don't take away my focus. I almost finished the first chapter or whatever and I still have not had a full fight without pop-up interruption. story or progress-related ones are fine, but those pop-ups are a plague.

Screw this. I shouldn't have bought this even if it was 70% sale. it's not fun.
Loved the prequel, this sequel is stupid. bypass any logic previously established. Two of the character have different voices. Ann looks like a beach bimbo rather than a student and/or fashion model. Social is BOUGHT, levels are BOUGHT. Velvet room is cruelly lacking (the attendant is a cutie but that alone is not enough). 
As for the plot... you are immediately pointed at BEFORE you even get into town for some similar-looking crime as before. I know Japan IS ACTUALLY THAT DUMB when it comes to accusations and believing said accusations, but come on... So go play with the obviously deranged pastel-colored queen-wannabe and the two obviously swapped AI. Can't say more than that as I've yet to progress further. Most is actually speculations but whatever. Getting a tutorial pop-up to tell me how to fucking press a button 2 hours in when I've been doing that nonstop since the start is hella dumb and annoying.

author: da2fe62a44995a65b53d9169be4cab81
content: As a big fan of Persona 5 Royal, I went into this game with high expectations. Those explectations were not met, but I would say I still had an enjoyable time. First off, every aspect of this game that replaces a mechanic in P5R is worse. I was not a fan of the combat in the game. Fights on higher difficulties are a slog to get through due to the amount of health enemies have. Changing it to easy definitely made me enjoy it more since I could easily kill enemies. If enemies had even less health and it played like Vampire Survivors, I think I could've enjoyed the combat. Easy difficulty got me close, but not close enough. There are no confidants in this, instead there is the bond system. While the bond system isn't bad, it is nowhere near as good as the confidants' system. The Jails felt less varied in mechanics than the Palaces, which was a bummer. I believe the jails also had fewer sneaking opportunities than P5R and forced you into a lot more fights, but I may be misremembering P5R. Even though all of these aspects are worse than P5R, they aren't bad either. Once I changed it to easy, I had a fairly neutral time interacting with these mechanics, not good or bad. But, the reason I still quite enjoyed this game is because of the characters and writing. I love the Phantom Thieves so much and getting to see them again was great. Their character interactions and scenes of them hanging out were all very enjoyable. I also really like the new characters introduced, I love Sophia so much and Zenkichi is also great, they really feel like they fit in with the rest of the Phantom Thieves. I also really like Akane, and Konoe was easily my favorite villain. Overall, even though I didn't enjoy the gameplay that much, the characters and writing made this game an overall net-positive experience. Still not sure if it's worth the $40 I bought it for, but it was great reuniting with the Phantom Thieves, 7.5/10

content:
+

author: bbf1447384c7550e9e088cd14ebc39a5
content:
THE GAME DOESN'T WORK RIGHT! The game is neat itself but you have to do so much to achieve meh performance. The game is very poorly optimized. I'm running a 3060 12gb w/ i7 and 16gb of RAM with the game on an SSD and I'm lucky if I can reach the 60fps lock. At least, I used to be until I downloaded Process Lasso and did some other tweaks which brought me to a semi consistent 60. Still though, before I did that, I was getting maybe 20fps. Like playing GTA Online in a full lobby on an original PS4 that's never been dusted. This game will make your computer beg for mercy. Not really, but it'll at least seem like it.

And because of all that, I can't recommend the game. I only recommend working games. This works less than 7 Days to Die walking alongside a pond with water FX turned all the way up. This game is like trying to play R6 Siege w/o the latest drivers, or like trying to launch any Ubi game that isn't compatible with the newer Uplay. It's like trying to play the launch release of Fallout 4 w/o any patches, minus the hard crashes. You won't crash when playing this game but you will soft lock if you try to load the 5th boss fight. Isn't that neat?

This game's resolution always looks bad, too. I can't really tell what's wrong with it but the menus always tend to look like they're a quarter of the resolution they should be. Looking at the menus is similar to trying to read a book through a glass jar.

If that game goes on sale for $5, go for it. It's still a pretty cool game. My problem is that the development team was clearly lacking in the technical department and they've decided to let players fix most of the problems they encounter which is unacceptable. They pulled a Bethesda real hard too, considering their DLC bricks that one boss fight.

author: fc968024a70a5de58d41118763684b61
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an electrifying fusion of action RPG and the beloved Persona series. As a fan of both, I was thrilled to dive back into the Metaverse alongside the Phantom Thieves.

🎮 Gameplay: 5/5

The combat system is a delightful blend of real-time action and strategic planning. Swapping between characters feels seamless, and executing stylish combos against Shadows is immensely satisfying. Plus, the inclusion of the Showtime attacks adds that extra flair we all love.

🌆 Story and Characters: 5/5

The Phantom Thieves are back, and their camaraderie remains as endearing as ever. The plot unfolds beautifully, weaving together personal struggles, friendship, and the overarching mystery. New characters like Sophia bring fresh dynamics, while familiar faces like Joker and Morgana feel like old friends.

🌸 Visuals and Music: 5/5

Persona 5 Strikers retains the signature aesthetic of the original game. The vibrant, stylized visuals pop off the screen, whether you’re exploring Jails or enjoying a quiet moment at Leblanc. And the soundtrack? Pure bliss. Shoji Meguro’s compositions continue to elevate the experience.

🌟 Overall: 5/5

Persona 5 Strikers captures the essence of the original while introducing exhilarating gameplay twists. Whether you’re a Phantom Thieves veteran or a newcomer, this game is an absolute steal. So grab your mask, summon your Persona, and let’s steal some hearts!

author: 385ddad8867d57e4b20844baea9510af
content:
edit: Just 100 percented the game. Maxing out my level in NG+ after doing all the extra boss rematches was a little grindy, I guess. The best goofy AA action game I've played in years, all said and done.

This game is a little strange. It feels much lower budget than Persona 5 itself, but stays so close to the uber-polished presentation style that you almost don't notice it. The writing overall is a little... off or cheap feeling, but the writing of the main characters is so incredibly on-point that it really won't bother you. The dungeons seem extremely formulaic, but just when you start to get bored with the pattern things start changing up on you -- the Kyoto boss was really fun.

And the combat... I can't think of a better way imaginable to present Persona 5 in a real time hack and slash. Once you get into it, it's AMAZING. It takes the best of the Warriors series, the high points of P5, and creates a strange but pleasant amalgamation of the two.

It's not what anyone could have expected Persona 5 Two to be, but it sure does feel like that's what it is.

author: de67ae96759e5747a665c7609dc81e8c
content:
This game is extremely poorly optimized for PC. There is constant stutter throughout the game. The game freezes up randomly and MAY start playing again, otherwise I have to close out of the game, and sometimes the game will just straight up crash on its own.

I really wanted to enjoy this game, I was just starting to get a feel for the controls and seemed like it was going to be fun but the bugs I am running into are making it entirely impossible for me to play.

And don't get me wrong, I have attempted to fix this game on my own. The most common solution I have seen is running Process Lasso. Everyone seems to say "I just installed it and ran it in the background and it fixed everything". Good for you, that doesn't work for me though. I have tried numerous different fixes, searching through forums and watching videos on youtube but none of it has been able to resolve these problems. This game has been on Steam for around 3 years and it still runs like this. It's a joke and I can't believe this hasn't been fixed already. Perhaps I'm just the unlucky one where my system is perfectly designed to not run the game right and you'll have more luck running than me, but given my experiences with this game, I cannot recommend this game to anyone

author: 619334134d225f9b9dd30d5161c712bb
content: Persona 5 Strikers was a big let down for me. The combat is fine, but feels too slow during boss fights and doesn't fit the Persona series well. The story is boring, it has some standout moments, but most of them are over a dozen hours in and getting to that point was painful (switched to easiest difficultly purely to make the game faster). There is a ton of pointless exposition as well. The music is great, as usual, but most of the tracks were already in Persona 5. At this point I'd consider myself a big Persona fan, having played P3R, P4G, and P5R. I enjoyed those games because they are stellar industry-best-level JRPGs, and have interesting stories with some lovable characters. Persona 5 Strikers is not a top tier Dynasty Warriors-style game, or hack and slash game, the story takes criminally long to become interesting, and the writing is significantly worse than the main series games. If you're deep into Persona fandom, then maybe Persona 5 Strikers will work for you, but even when I tried to look at it through that lens I was bothered because there were countless moments where the writing ignores the the entire year Joker has already spent with the Phantom Thieves.

author: 8226707f05c25d8ab1c3a974b9235261
content:
It's not a bad game, it just looks that way because it's a direct sequel to Persona 5. One of the "I wish steam reviews had a "meh" option".

The story acts as a direct sequel to Persona 5 (not Royal) so the characters are all there and are as great as before. Unfortunately everything else about the game is lesser in every way. 

The world is a lot more linear with the slice of life aspect being almost completely absent, the combat is a nice change IMO but best played on easy so enemy health and damage work well with enemy density (any difficult above the lowest turns even basic mobs into damage sponges and powerhouses), the story is "what if Persona 5, but again?" but held up well by characters both new and returning. 

It's these cons that make it very difficult to get into nearly as much as Persona 5 which is required reading if you want to get what's happening in the plot.

author: 45c7550794565e92bb6e1be13b3cecf3
content:
THE STORY IS A SEQUEL TO P5's MAIN STORY, PLAY P5 OR P5R BEFORE YOU PLAY THIS.

It's pretty fun, story feels like a legitimate sequel to P5 main story instead of how most Persona spinoffs work outside of the Arena games (kind of) and it is canon to P5's story as a whole so it's not pointless like PQ's story. Keep in mind it is a Dynasty Warrior styled game, I feel it is more Persona than Dynasty Warriors, but just keep in mind that if you don't like Warriors games you probably won't like this game. Story is good and fun, music is great as per usual, the new characters are great, specifically like Zenkichi, hope Persona games have more characters like him in the future.

Merciless difficulty is more similar to something like Ultimate Vault Hunter mode from Borderlands 2 than it is to Merciless from P5 or something like Maniac mode from P3P (though it is closer to Maniac than P5 Merciless). It's very much a mode where you test not only your endgame Persona builds, but also just your general understanding of the combat, it is not for everyone and it is also NOT a requirement outside of only starting it for an achievement. I saw someone else review the game negatively purely because of Merciless mode and I don't think that's fair at all, as Merciless is purely an endgame challenge mode for players who want the challenge, you can also just do a regular NG+ without Merciless mode difficulty.

Overall it's a fun game. Only reason my playtime seems low is because Steam didn't log my playtime correctly due to internet issues, my playtime is closer to 70-80 hours

author: d6e684bfb6ff5826a87e1b2adc8bd293
content:
P5S gives us the chance to stay around the Phantom Thieves a little more and that's already a wonderful thing in itself. I loved P5 and its cast so much that I'm really glad to have a sequel. The gameplay is pretty much what you an expect from the Musou Series, but there is an incredible attention to details on this one. It's fun, it's fast, the story is awesome, the new characters are really cool and the INCREDIBLE music is still there... but with an action twist now. 
Really, P5 is a masterpiece, and P5S is the perfect game for those, like me, who wants more.

author: 549e9235da275632a73d9d0afb168847
content:
For a Persona game it's definitely out there with the new combat style. But it definitely works for what it wants to be. The story itself is good as well as the music being fantastic as always But I do have my problems with it. 

Comparing to persona 5 I much prefer the system they have for fusing personas. Having multiple ways to fuse, item fusing and generally how its laid out. The jails themselves while being fun I feel are a little too short in the game. Personally I would prefer the game having a run time of about 50/60 hours without doing a completion run just to fill it out more. A little more interaction with the characters as well would be nice, having maybe a 1 to 5 confidant level for your group to hang out with them and learn some new tactics or something. Having the new tactics learnt by playing those specific characters in game just seems a little cheap. Also the controls for the game are not that great and to get a playable control setting for yourself does require quite a bit of fiddling.

Personal Nitpick - I would love if in P5 if you romanced one of your teammates they remember it in game and there is some story too it there. It feels like a huge miss for the folks that romanced Ann for example and then she makes no mention or interaction whatsoever about it with the player. 

All in all though the game is great and I do recommend it to people, but if your wanting a more  normal persona experience either play Persona 5 Royal or new game plus. 7.5/10 would be my rating for this.

(Also not enough time with Coffee Dad)

author: 41dfa35c8eab509daf3129d7e82a5429
content:
I could never tell you this game was bad by any means. In fact I enjoyed most of my time with it, but it also feels kinda out of place in an RPG series. It's blatantly a Dynasty Warriors clone that takes place in the Persona universe with RPG elements shoved in to make it feel more at home. As such, fans of that series are going to love this, I'll wager. I'm not one of them, and if anything my holdups felt like reasons I wouldn't enjoy that series.

But that said it is a very focused experience which (again, unlike most RPGs) will not give you any chance to explore much outside the path the story gives you (which as I think about it is quite ironic considering the themes of the series and this game in it in particular), so if you are the kind of player who gets lost in side stories and never actually finishes the game despite wanting to see it through, this is probably for you. In addition, this game is about as true to the Persona 5 experience without remaining the same game as is possible due to it's presentation, so fans who wanted to visit Joker and his friends again will also get exactly what they wanted out of it.

If there is anyone who should avoid this game, it's ironically the people who came here wanting an actual RPG experience. That is not what this is despite the series, and furnishings of it included. So if that's what you want, you will likely find what you are looking for starkly missing. 

Oh and unless it's a cheap way to get the background music from the rest of the series into battles, SKIP the deluxe edition. The extras are absolute trash beyond that.

content:
I'm addicted to P5 cast, so I couldn't help it.

The game itself is meh. The story didn't work for me: computers are magic, I get it, but this is just ridiculous. It's like "weird science", only it takes itself seriously. Combat is just bad. It's fast and cluttered, visual effects cover the screen, you don't see what you're doing most of the time, so just mash the buttons in pattern of your favorite combo and hope that you're doing something useful.

The one redeeming factor are the social interactions within the group. P5R already fixed that to some degree by adding some group events, so our cast looks more like a real group of friends. author: 802115e2123b5c34b5cac265fd27807c
content:
I don't know what everyone's talking about; I love the combat in this game. I can admit it is a bit button-mashy, in that the optimal way to deal with enemies is to farm for 20 hours and simply spam their weakness, but you really don't need to play this way. 

Dishing out a few combos, perfect parrying the boss, baton passing all around and executing even more combos with characters who play totally differently, obliterating everything with a Showtime attack, using the environment objects, getting actual helpful helping help from Oracle to remember how to hit technicals, taking advantage of stagger windows and long windups to do longer combos which then deal a crit, which leads to an All-out-attack, which charges everybody's Showtimes up again and... and...  It's all so well thought out and it very cleverly combines Persona's style with a real-time combat system. 

[spoiler] It's not perfect, of course; SP drain encourages you to leave and instantly re-enter to refill it after each combat at the cost of real life time spent in a loading screen and nothing else. [/spoiler]

Now, one of the side effects of combining Persona with not-Persona is that, despite it being possible for the player to no-hit every fight (every enemy has immaculately telegraphed attacks and it's brilliant), you're still fighting with a team. If you neglect your team's armor, or their level, or try to go up against end-game opponents early on, they just get annihilated, leaving you with <1/4 of your DPS, and you need that DPS, unless you're down for a 30+ minute solo fight. Strikers is [i]hard[/i], and if you play [i]on hard[/i], every big enemy is a tank, and they hit like one. So, you still need to go through all the preparations that you're used to from Persona to be up to par for a fight, and you also need to be good enough at the combat to win. I kind of hated this at first, but I also hated Persona 5 for this at first, so it makes perfect sense.

Right, onto everything else, in no particular order:
The time management and social stuff is much less of a focus (Like, almost not a focus at all)
The characters and their dialogue are what you'd expect, except one that was neglected in P5 is greatly improved
The music is bonkers. Outstanding. Insanely good.
The non-Palaces are less interesting (I didn't find them interesting previously, so no big deal for me)
Menuing can be a bit sluggish (Still looks cool, though)
Visual clutter during big battles can be a problem
Literally zero performance issues...? I'm not sure if they were fixed or if I'm just lucky

author: 3a653c819dcc59e2bb69fef3712277e5
content:
***READ THIS IF YOU ARE IN THE SAME POSITION I WAS WHEN BUYING THIS GAME***
 ^ that being very skeptical but needing a definitive answer

TL;DR: You need to play this game if you played Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal.

I want to start this review off by stating that Persona 5 and Royal had and still have me in a choke hold. There is not a day that goes by that I do not think of P5, and if I do, it is because I do not have the cognitive function to even know where I am. Because of this, I was extremely skeptical of this game. Sequels, as many know, tend to drop the ball and have it shatter into thousands of tiny pieces for things like this. Not all the time, but a definite handful of times. This game is weird with how it handles that ball. Characters and story? Spit-shined at every moment so when you take a look at it, there is always a cartoonish sparkle to it. Gameplay? It has some scratches that seem a bit too deep to buff out.

If you are like me, then you can understand a game's value by it's price tag. Ignoring gems that should cost more, or ones that should be less than they are worth, quality and price still have a slight tendency to go hand in hand. For what I am about to say, put yourself in the mind of yourself when you are 10 years old, you go to the game store to buy a game, and box art and price is all you have to go off of. 

This game should be worth $40. I know that is so much words for such a weird way to put this, but for the people who understand what I am saying, will have a brainblast when buying this game and understanding exactly, TO A T, what I mean. 

So, enough of this useless obscure gaming blog rambling, here are my thoughts straight up ***NO SPOILERS***

***IMPORTANT THINGS TO KNOW BEFORE PLAYING***

     Time does NOT progress unless the story says so. You can leave and re-enter jails (this game's palaces, theres a good reason for the name change) at any time. Hanging out with friends also takes up no in game time. 
     You have all the time in the world to finish requests up until the VERY end of the game. Even then, when you finish the game and save, you have a post-clear game that is not new game +, but you have to playthrough to get NG+. It sends you back riiiiight before the last fight with some new requests
     Persona fusion is WHACK. Don't expect what you get from Persona 5.
     There is NO EXP SHARE. You gotta have each character in your party if you want them to level up. 
     There are no confidants/social links in this game. It's replaced with a BOND meter that fills up over time in the story, by cooking food, hanging out with friends, and fighting. its not at all, and the way its used is honestly awesome

***THE BAD, AND ANNOYING***
To start with the bad, this game's gameplay loop is repetitive most of the time. It is enough to cause it to genuinely becoming grating over time. A bell curve is pretty much the best way for me to explain how this game feels to play. Of course, this is the nature of hack and slash games, but still. It does a lot very well with the hand it is given, though it can get annoying at times. 

Character balance is a mess. You will primarily have the same-ish team for most of the game, because the other characters are just mediocre at best. Imagine 3 teammates as Persona 5 Royal makoto, the rest as Persona 5 Royal's Morgana. 3 teammates are literally busted. you will feel it, the most busted one is one that i can only describe as legitimately, no DLC end game persona 5 royal Joker. genuinely insane skills + heat riser + debilitate + enduring soul + a collection of damaging skills that is BONKERS and genuinely should not be on one character. Theyre a character that is what feels like end game P5R akechi should have been. 

The fusion system is bad. Some personas you need to level up other personas to ABSURD levels in order to fuse them. King Frost is one of them, requiring a level 40 Pyro Jack and Level 40 Jack Frost (both of which are no where close to that level) in order to fuse. I'm too lazy to go back and reword this whole part of the review to add in how the fusion system works. But its just you choosing from a list, not you choosing a persona and which to fuse it with. Its gross.

There are plenty more bad things in this game to be aware of, but it is 12:48 am on a school night, I have a show in the morning and frankly, i just want to explain what makes me happy about this game. 

***THE GOOD, THE GREAT, AND THE FANTASTIC***

If you skipped to this part of the review, then hell yeah. i gotchu, i know what you want and ill give you it.

When I tell you how this game handles characters is phenomenal, i mean it. if you can believe it, the characters in this game have so much more personality than Persona 5. It feels like a real group of friends. By repeated mentions of in-jokes that dont just feel like "haha look fans! remember this funny reference! love us for the fact that we are faithful to the source material!". And additions of new on-going bits and jokes, this game genuinely is what Persona 5 fans needed for the continuation of this story. The voice acting is SO good (for the old cast, im not a fan of 2 of the new characters' voices until the very end of the game). While on the topic of this, I would love to bring up the fact that while the persona 5 anime is not great, the voice acting is terrific. ESPECIALLY Ryuji. The delivery of jokes could not have been better and were done perfectly every single time. You could feel the raw energy and power in the scenes you needed to feel that. 

The best way I can describe this game's characters is like it feels as though is it just one really damn big improv session with the voice actors. To the people who get what I am saying and know how real those feel: yeah. I know what I am saying and I am telling you it feels just like that. There has never been a game that has caused me to laugh out loud by the jokes. There has never been a game where I scream at my screen for a character to do something, and they do it, and have me flip out. There has never been a game that could get me to genuinely feel something even with the most cheesy of lines. This game is phenomenal in all of those regards, and my mom could probably testify that this is the only game ive ever played that has had me this excited and vocal. 

Now shifting down a gear to say something that I like but not as much, the story is good! its really enjoyable, and the game is predictable enough for you to know where it'll go soon, but just a bit unpredictable to have you still be excited and have a lot of fun and have you being like "wait what?!?!" in so many places. Its the prefect blend of predictability that causes you to feel smart for piecing things together while also not feeling like when you do so you are an adult destroying the questions in Dora the Explorer. 

What I like about this game is that since Morgana is now new to this to, you actually get to theorize WITH the characters, instead of having a question that you have IMMEDIATELY answered. There is another exposition mule in this game though, like how Morgana was in Persona 5, but it is not nearly the same. They come in just when you need it or whenever you need something to push you to getting more clues.

Didnt know there was a character limit to steam reviews, so lets rap it up.

(one quick thing before TL;DR 2, the music isnt as good as persona 5. its generic action game music with a hint of persona 5)

TL;DR 2: This game is a love letter to Persona 5. This game also gets annoying to play, then it gets bearable, then enjoyable. It is worth the frustration and annoyance. Buy this game only when its on sale, however. anything above $40 is too much for this game.

Thank you so much for reading this review. I have comments on, and Im more than happy to answer any questions. I hope that this review can help at least ONE person who is on the fence about buying this game. Thats all i care about.

Take care everyone :)

author: eb8d16a4d1815c5891edadd923ce53c8
content:
First I do recommend this game, but there are a lot of caveats. 
I'm pretty sure you can find from other people why this game is good so I'm just going to write the problems I found with this game despite recommending it.

1. The pacing, it's kind of slow. It goes from exciting to then you eat a meal, then exciting, then you do this. There is no countdown of days to the end of a palace and feels like it is dragging out towards the end.

2. The gameplay. This is not a fun game. This isn't like other Musou games where the enemies are all on screen, this game has enemies spawn after you approach a shadow. This means you have to start and stop combat constantly which can get annoying.

3. The combat is stiff feeling. Doesn't have a satisfying feel like most other hack and slashes. Dynasty warriors has a better feel than this game. In a turn based RPG, you'd normally plan each move strategically, in this game is basically an attack spam fest of weaknesses with some dodging.

4. Getting upgrades is a pain in the ass since you have to revisit other dungeons and move around them.

5. The game has a cutscene around every corner. This isn't like the original game where an action causes a cutscene, or it occurs in important parts in dungeons. This cutscene often happens randomly, you never know how long they are and watching a shadow morph into some demon every few seconds is annoying after a dozen or so times.

With that said. I still do recommend this game if you can deal with the shortcomings on design.

Damned fine game, a worthy sequel to P5/P5R. Game/Story/Music Quality is up with and sometimes beyond that of P5/P5R. The Dynasty warrior style gameplay is fresh and very fun, although a minor issue is that the keyboard bindings aren't very good. Highly recommend playing with a controller for this one.

Chronologically, this is the timeline for all P5 games so far:

P5/P5R until before the ending of the 6th Palace > P5T: Paint the Heart > P5/P5R until Christmas > P5R Third Semester after the palace but before March > P5T main story > True ending of P5R > P5S 

My enjoyment of the games:

P5R > P5S > P5T: paint the Heart > P5T main story

P5S is very close to P5R in terms of quality, and is a must have for all fans of P5, just make sure ot get a controller. It was my first game with the PS5 Dualsense, and it was a very enjoable experience.

author: 3c7e5e64a0d15d57a4056e32d3acfd34
content:
"Persona 5 Strikers" is a title I wholeheartedly recommend, albeit with an essential piece of advice for fellow fans: revisiting the original "Persona 5" will significantly enhance your experience with "Strikers." This isn't to suggest that "Persona 5: Royal," with its expansive narrative alterations, should be your precursor. Instead, the authentic and unaltered journey offered by the original "Persona 5" sets the perfect stage for what "Strikers" has in store.

Having journeyed through "Persona 5 Royal" myself, transitioning to "Strikers" felt somewhat jarring. The expectation to continue the enriched narrative of "Royal" made the shift to "Strikers," which follows the original's storyline, feel disjointed. This experience highlighted the unique narrative paths of each game and the importance of aligning with the original "Persona 5" narrative to fully appreciate "Strikers."

Despite this initial dissonance, "Strikers" captivated me with its compelling story and engaging gameplay, embodying the spirit of the "Persona" series. It invoked a sense of nostalgia and a desire to revisit the original "Persona 5," not just as a return to its roots but as a way to bridge my experiences between the original game and "Strikers." This revisit isn't about recapturing the unfamiliar but rekindling the familiar and deepening the connection to the "Persona" universe.

The presence of "Persona 5 Royal" on Steam, with its enhanced gameplay and narrative depth, makes the idea of going back to the original "Persona 5" seem less appealing, especially considering the hardware switch back to the PS4. Yet, the narrative continuity and the charm of the original game hold a special place that "Royal" can't entirely replace, particularly for those of us looking to complete the journey into "Strikers."

In conclusion, "Persona 5 Strikers" offers a rich and rewarding experience for those who have traversed the world of "Persona 5." While "Royal" presents a polished and expanded version of this world, the unique storyline of "Strikers" calls for a reunion with the original narrative. This game is a testament to the enduring allure of the "Persona" series, inviting veterans to re-engage with the past to fully embrace the present.

author: 20a68bd07d7d50198b2da81c8dc2b830
content:
To the point
==================
A stylish Musou style game that Persona 5 fans will love, but others might not know what they're buying

Good Stuff
==================
++ Cleared on Hard Mode ++

- I'm a fan of JRPGs who played P5 a long time ago and I can confirm that the story here, which is a canonical continuation, is great. Feels like a natural evolution of the already strong narrative and it was nice to catch up with familiar characters.

- The game really incentivizes you to keep your team rotated by changing up the vulnerabilities per dungeon

- Without the timing system from the first game, you can be a lot more leisurely with going into and out of dungeons to explore and level up without worrying about missing things

- The soundtrack is really great, most of the classic tracks from P5 have been remixed and match the more frantic pace of the game.

- Battles are just quick enough where they're fun to grind and try out new strategies.

Bad Stuff
================

- If you do NOT like or have a low tolerance for Weeb stuff, pass on this one cause it hits every trope

- So this was initially pitched to me by a friend as a Musou or a dynasty warriors style game. It is absolutely not. It's more or less an action game with an explorable map. For me this didn't hinder my enjoyment but if you came here looking for a Musou style game you'll be disappointed.

- Normal is incredibly easy, as in you can let you AI teammates do a lot of the work while you hang out. Hard is very punishing in the first dungeon but evens out later, just keep in mind even with grinding you'll be getting 3-4 shot through a majority of the game.

- The bosses, which are the centerpieces of games like these normally, are kind of sad here. They look interesting enough but you're given lots of tricks to defeat them (that you can choose not to use of course). There are a large majority of elite enemy encounters that are much harder.

author: 60384f3759265e21aab505183044020c
content:
Persona 5 Strikers successfully captures the essence of Persona 5 while offering a refreshing twist with its action-oriented gameplay that’s found in Koei Tecmo’s Dynasty Warriors series. It’s Persona 5 with real-time combat.

The stylish scenes and vibrant art style remain true to the series' signature aesthetic, delivering a visually captivating journey.

One of the standout features is the game's soundtrack, which not only pays homage to the acclaimed music of Persona 5 but also introduces new tracks that complement the dynamic battles. 

The well-written story is another highlight, seamlessly continuing the narrative from Persona 5 and introducing new challenges for the Phantom Thieves to overcome. The character development and interpersonal relationships maintain the depth and charm that us fans have come to expect from the Persona series.

In my opinion, Strikers is a worthy addition to the Persona 5 universe. More so than Persona 5 Tactica.

Plays well on the Steam Deck at 60 FPS.

author: 1d0aa8aefb485e26b290ecc2c206f0ac
content:
It's an interesting game in that it shows how the persona series would play if they were action games instead of an rpg. However, since it's just a spin-off, it doesnt compare to the greatness of the main titles. Nonetheless, the story is good and there are enough elements from persona 5 to make you feel invested and finish the story. 

The actual gameplay feels really smooth sometimes, gets boring other times with you just pressing a single button to ambush and insta win, and other times it feels like you are just avoiding tons of stuff flying at you while your teammates die because the AI decides to tank attacks instead of moving away. Joker is the weakest of all the team, which is a problem since you can't bench him, and while fights are generally fun, some are really tedious, bosses being difficult only because they are damage sponges and have millions of hp. This gets compounded in merciless difficulty with mobs being able to one shot your team with a single ability. Did not and will not try to grind anything in this game or complete merciless, unlike in persona 5. 

Also, there's really no choice in interacting with your team, other than 3 or 4 events where you choose to hang out with  one of them and get a cutscene. Understandable for a spin-off, but these interactions were part of what make the persona games great. 

Music is good. 

Overall good game, would recommend getting on discount if you want more persona after finishing 5.

author: d17545178060544d82f47f65bbad8f99
content:
This being a "Spin-off" or even calling this is a "Spin-off" should be enough to distort your heart

For someone that played the original Persona 5 and its currently playing Persona 5 royal together with a buddy
this is everything but a spin-off

It actually does the opposite of what you expect from a spin-off, it enriches the cast while making the new characters just as equally interesting and enjoyable,BUT I AM SO SAD I WILL NEVER SEE ZENKICHI IN ROYAL :(
+1 favorite character to my book alongisde Yusuke and Ryuji (THE BOYS!)

Sophia story as a AI gave me (for the lack of better word in my vocabulary) new light on how i see AI in real world and giving AI atleast the benefit of the doubt despite how its being used in today's world
not gonna lie, her speech gave me tears (don't wanna spoil so i will say its the speech she gives when in "mementos")

Ichinose while you could say was lacking screentime in the early game even after she's been introduced, the end of the game really expanded more her reasoning and personality, made me like her alot more, also sad i won't be seeing her in Royal...

Oh,i forgot about to talk about gameplay...uh....

for joker i sticked with arsene to the end as best i could, after the twins/[spoiler]Lavenza[/spoiler] opened the option to level up your personas and their individual starts, i never bothered to level up other personas BUT arsene, yes i had other personas for either buffs or magic abilities that i would need, but priority number 1 persona was arsene and arsene only
How i built arsene was to be flexible
1 gun skill
1 melee skill
1 Ailment skill (preferably sleep)
1 Buff/debuff skill
3 passives (1 to nullify his ice weakness)
and i had no problem with this setup


I had no problem, in the begginign i was overwhelmed by the amount of different movesets and playstile each characters had, Morgana and Haru are extremely strong when it comes to technical attacks, too me over half the game to understand how strong their technical attacks were, so for morgana i always tried to have either Ann or Joker with a fire persona to burn the shadows (Sleeps also works too, ironic)

Skull,Fox,[spoiler] Wolf [/spoiler] and Noir are like your melee/gun damage thugs

Fox more about Combos that last for almost forever and countering attacks while also dishing alot of strong criticals, if there was a boss-shadow that none of your current thieves could deal with effectively, Fox Constant active damage thanks to his Counter-mid combo always ensured you could keep attacking so long you timed your counters and combo counters
and if shadow does not have any weakness, just crit it to the ground!

Skull is the most likely the "Bruiser" of the thieves as he has the highest burst damage on charged attacks while also boosting the highest base defense,or endurance in this case, Flinching being non existant with his personal buff (Not the "charge" ability, although it just makes him even more absurd in burst damage)

Noir is kind of odd, she has acess to both Technical damage and gun damage, while also having both PSY, Ailments and Gun boosts, i still haven't cracked down her playstyle, but i can say from the time i played with her she is indeed very strong with both PSY, ailemnts and Gun attacks, she definitly shouldn't be played with endurance in mind, shes can't really take a punch like the guys (Morgana even less so, but balances out by having the highest agility to dodge attacks)

[spoiler] Wolf is a "high risk-high reward" playstyle with his Fury mode, atleast before he unlocks a art that reduces the HP-draining during fury, His attacks are always wide swings that have higher chance of dealing critical damage, not to mention his persona is almigthy based with some Melee and gun skills, focusing on buffing himself and landing criticals to keep the refreshing his current buffs, goes very well with his "Heat riser" ability he learns later on, if you wanted to destroy a boss-like shadow, wolf is your man, also can i say his outfit alongside the awakened of choice are FREAKING AWESOME?, A CLAYMORE?!, I LOVE YOU! [/spoiler]

Phanter,Mona,sophie and Queen were the "supports" of the thieves, Ann less so since she is much more focused on FIre damage with a twinkle of healing sprayed

i honestly haven't cracked down Queen playstyle yet, but i can say her buffs and healing were very helpful, alongisde her easy to access Combos with innate Nuke affinity, think of her as a "Spellsword" or "Battlemage" of the thieves, also just as durable as skull

If SKull is the Thugh, Phanter is the Wizard, being able to apply burning by either basic attacks or persona abilities really goes well with Queen and Morgana for Technical damage, while also having atleast some small way of recovering SP unlike the other Thieves that canno't recover SP unless you use Items or support from Oracle

Mona has the highest Technical damage and the best "oh shit everything is going wrong!" healing ability by about level 70
Reviving, healing to full, cleansing ailments all in one package for when shit goes wrong, mona pairs very well with fire or sleep de-buffed enemy, as sleeping enemies can be technical hitted from everything they are not immune to

Sophie is likely the best healer all around, but she lacked the means to revive teammates, to be frank, i din't play enough sophie yet to be good enough with her combo game, but i was not ignoring her gimmick of catching her yo-yos mid combo (not counting the times i had her in my party as AI, she was very useful, ALSO THOSE THIGHTS)

Ailments, unlike Persona 5 royal and original, CAN affect bosses (except the last boss) and makes them VERY strong
Haru being able to FEAR a friggin Dire shadow is HUMONGOUS of a help, you do however need to get the bond skills to trigger more realibly, alongside some luck boost

by level 5 in ailment rate trigger chance, you will trigger ailments 100% of the time, no exceptions, and its kind of nuts how strong a 10-12 sp cost ailments can be since they affect not just 1 enemy

I'm gonna finish this by saying this: i also loved the gimmick on the last boss fight, TAG TEAM WITH SKULL AND JOKER NEVER FELT SO SATISFYING AND CINEMATIC

author: 590fe0e2afc4583287ec4bb8dac0ca53
content:
Persona 5 Strikers continues its story after Persona 5 Royale, bringing back its lovable original main casts for another tale which takes them across Japan.

Omega-Force (Koei) has a hand in developing this, hence Strikers possesses a mixture of Dynasty Warrior and Persona 5 mechanics. The overall gameplay sets you off in exploring huge areas called Jails, which are the equivalent to Persona 5's Palaces but with its own set of rules. There is more emphasis on counter-dodge, baton passes, and elemental switching in combat. This makes battle exciting and keeps you on your toes, rather than the usual hack-and-slash that are seen in many Koei titles. Essentially, enemies will knock you down hard on mindless button mashing.

Music is a big part of enjoying Persona 5, and Strikers did a great job in not only arranging the base Persona 5 tracks, but also has outstanding original vocal tracks of their own. It very much fits the style of Striker's gameplay and enhances them.

Overall, Persona 5 Striker's is a great spin-off to Persona 5 Royale. There are gripes such as the loss of QoL that are present in Royale, the content outside of battle is minimal, and a lot of menu-ing, but that didn't deter me from enjoying it.

author: 1ce6cee5970a5044950afa40016a7846
content:
Love the combat in this game! Story's not as good as Persona 5, but it's still enjoyable. Plus the Phantom Thief theme just fits so well as an action game!

Biggest gripe from me is that the combat feels like it's held back by trying to shove in too many Persona 5 mechanics. You can play this like a musou game, but the most efficient strategy is to spam Persona skills to take advantage of weaknesses, technicals, etc. And even if you're not doing that and decide to play it like a musou game like I did, you still need to bring in other characters to maintain buffs and debuffs, or else combat just takes so much longer without being more fun.

You also need to actually buy gear for your characters (and it's [i]really[/i] expensive to buy that stuff!) so you're basically committed to using 1-2 characters at the start of each dungeon, which actively discourages you to try out other characters. It's especially bad for Joker whose viability is based on how much you're willing to fuse Personas for him. It was a fun thing in Persona 5, it was [b]not[/b] fun in this game!

Overall, still a lot of fun despite all my gripes. I would just see myself enjoying this game more if it had just taken all the extra effort from forcing in all the Persona and RPG elements like Persona skills, fusions, gear, elemental weaknesses, etc, and put all that effort into doubling down on Mastery skills to make combos more interesting and rebalancing bosses accordingly.

author: 627716feedaa57ffa1bbe8717df4c3d7
content: The game is good, nothing more, nothing less, just good. If you're looking to spend time with some more time with the beloved characters from Persona 5, I say sure go for it, but don't expect any drastic or meaningful interactions with them. The general premise of the story is very similar to the original game so far. The combat is fun! Reminds me of the old Dynasty Warrior games. My only complaint with the fights are that it can feel clunky at times with limited movement during combos and the camera movement does not help either. Have not finished it yet, and I don't know if I will, but I still recommend it if you love the world of persona and it's themes. 6.5/10, not worth the full price, would wait for a generous sale to buy this one.

author: 073dac9799da5134bcf66c8deae4d79d

This is like the halo ODST of Persona 5, but even ODST has more worthwhile content than this game. Is this game worth the full price? No, the gameplay is really flat compared to its predecessor. Every world is pretty formulaic, but the story is serviceable with it taking the experiences from Persona 5 and having the characters relate to the villains through their own shortcomings. The combat is the biggest difference in this game and at first it feels a lot better than Persona 5's combat, but after a while it can get pretty stale and even sluggish at times if you don't have the right team comp. I wish this game had the exploration and depth of Persona 5 to be charging for a fully priced game. I got it at a steep discount and even then it feels like a chore playing through the game.

author: 994848d70bd751f783de6bc09196a2b0
content:
As a followup to Persona 5's story this is really fantastic. I wasn't sure if I was going to like this game, but the story sucked me in and it carried me to the finish line. The gameplay was pretty fun too.
First off this game is not a turn based JRPG like Persona 5. This is more akin to the dynasty warrior games where lots of enemies are on the screen and you do lots of attacks to defeat the enemies. The thing is that this game works in so many systems from Persona 5 that it truly feels like a sequel despite not being the same type of game. Personas level up and learn new moves. There is a bonding system for you and your party that gets worked into a skill tree. It just feels like the creators cared and really tried to work in as much as they could from Persona 5 into this game.
I personally don't really care for dynasty warrior style games and I still loved playing this and had a great time. I wouldn't pay full price for it unless you like dynasty warriors style games, but if you are a Persona 5 fan and this is on sale then I can highly recommend it.

author: 12c402bab957529a84c206da0f229e48
content: The Best way I can describe Persona 5 Strikers is a throw back to the Spin off games of the late 00's that were on Portable Systems.  In fact if someone told me this started out as a PS Vita game in development and moved on to PS4/PC when that system was ended.  I would have believed them.  The first thing that came to my mind when playing it was KH Dreamdrop on the 3DS with its love of open parkour.  If could forgive them if that was the case but when those games like KH portable titles or Crisis core were made by in house Devs.  Strikers is a Keoi Techmo spin off so if you don't know that means.  Butts and the same tired Dynasty warriors power fantasy game play from 20 years ago.  If you like way to many crap filling your screen and jumping in head first.  You will like this game.  The best parts for me are the Parts from Persona 5 that carry over like the dialogue.  The charm in the characters and new characters are right out of Original game.  It doesn't take long to see though that corners were cut.  Characters are mentioned but don't appear.  The relationship system has been removed.  Royal is treated like it doesn't exist even though it came out a year before this.  Beside the characters, this really isn't a Persona game but takes itself far to seriously to be treated like the spin off Dancing titles.  Oh and this game claims to have anti-aliasing but you could have fooled me.  If you want to play this, treat it like a Portable game and play it in small  doses when you need a laugh.

author: 1b79815abfac583f97b2c5c32d6ea803
content:
A super strong extra chapter in the story and characters of the Phantom Thieves.

I think if you loved Persona 5's world, story, characters, music etc. you will enjoy this game.

This game does't feel like "just a spin-off" it really feels like a Persona 5: 2. One of my favorite parts about the narrative is it really does feel like a full road trip/adventure with the gang you got in P5. All too often in JRPGs you get all your party members assembled at the last moments and can feel their chemistry for a only a short few hours. Since this is a continuation of P5 story the whole game has that full team chemistry through it. But still retains the character growth with new characters.

The only thing that might turn you off of this game is the combat. It seems to be hit or miss for a lot of people. I personally found the combat fun after a few hours, I'm not a huge fan of chaotic beat em up type combat but it still felt well designed and still captures the feel of persona combat.

I'd say this game is worth you're time, just don't try to compare it to base Persona 5 / Royal too much. Just sit back turn that OST up and enjoy the ride.

author: ff724bd4723f5a90ad824b0b88ea8066
content:
Gameplay is good BUT the performance on high end PCs is poor.

The exact cause of the stuttering on high end PCs have is due to the game artificially limiting itself by not using all the cores of the CPU. This issue apparently has existed since release. A simple fix of going into task manager and manually selecting all cores exists but a game that sells at £55 shouldn't require going into task manager to make it function.

A few other things like not automatically going full screen & mouse camera movement not locking during dialogue are present. Also all settings are locked until a certain point in the story when some unlock then even later do the entire settings unlock.

You'd be best buying during sales or on PS4.

author: c4c6a06b31cc55b6b885f8aeab9c4ccd
content:
Solid followup to the original game, and a true sequel. Expands on themes of the heart, justice, and incorporates new topics such as AI. Gives much needed spotlight and development to underused characters, and handles the group dynamic perfectly. Action combat is a fun blend of Musou style mania and SMT strategy, and knows how to deliver impact. Every character feels unique and you're given almost everyone right from the get-go, so there's lots of time to master every single moveset. Every fan of Persona 5 should give it a try, it is absolutely worth every second.

AND DON'T EVEN GET ME STARTED ON THE MUSIC-

author: 183e4a199ab253749a421e8bef164978
content:
Koei Tecmo has a history of reskinning Dynasty Warriors with a popular IP for easy cash, so when I saw Koei Tecmo in the startup splash screens, I was cautiously optimistic. After all, I hadn’t played Dynasty Warriors in two decades and had fun with it for a while, and Atlus had a lot of control over the design of Persona 5 Strikers. So, as someone who recently completed Persona 5 Royal and found this game waiting to fill the emptiness of finishing such an outstanding game, I gave it a spin.

The combat, first, is more intricate than Koei Tecmo’s other musou games. The incorporation of the large roster of personas and their strengths and weaknesses gives it a complexity that the SMT/Persona series is known for. The combat, however, is still Dynasty Warriors to the core, and has the same problem that has plagued it since the beginning: The combat has no sense of impact or energy. You face hordes of enemies that mimic the experience of waving a feather duster at bad actors who were directed to jump back as they see the feather duster waved at them. They fade in, get subjected to a plastic-on-plastic whacking noise, then fade out. They either don’t react at all to being hit or go flying out of range with most of their health remaining.

Secondly, every enemy in the horde will focus fire whichever character you control. This means that when the game gets more difficult, most of your activity will be evading multiple rushes/projectiles while your AI teammates whittle down enemies with minimal use of weakness exploiting mechanics. Combine this with tedious health bars on bosses, and your worst enemy in most encounters will be your own patience. I found myself pounding potions and face-tanking bosses just to get it over with. I couldn’t help but wonder if more modern teams like Platinum Games or Team Ninja wouldn’t do a better job translating Persona from turn-based to action combat.

So, Persona is known for its story! Let’s look at that. It appears as if the developers of P5S were given the impossible task of writing a story that didn’t spoil Persona 5 and consequentially avoids any character development of the original cast. In this respect, it’s as annoying as any fan faction. “Hey! Remember how impulsive Ryuji is?! Remember that Morgana hates being a cat and continues to simp for Ann [spoiler]despite learning that he has never been human and is a wizard’s familiar in the form of a cat[/spoiler]?! Remember how Futaba loves to reference video games?!!?!?” That’s right, just lean into one dimension of each character. That’s fan fiction done right! And typical of the most annoying parts of Persona, they often add too much dialogue such as, “Awesome we unlocked this door! Now we can get further in!” Wow, no kidding? Thanks for the commentary, especially when we have twenty lines of dialogue explaining the most obvious puzzles in gaming. A moveable crate to access a high elevation? We’re going to need two cut scenes to explain this never-seen-before game mechanic.

All respect to Zenkichi, though, he’s well-written, but let’s get into Sophia, the AI, that after leaving the metaverse, gets unrestricted access to the internet. The internet, unrestricted, meaning she can see all the tourism videos, all of Shakespeare, all of Dostoyevsky, every dictionary in every language, then two lines later asks, “What does that word mean?”, then proceeds to act like a naïve child through the entire game, trapped in a smartphone connected to the internet, asking to be dipped into the ocean to learn about fish? Why are they falling for this hot garbage? Why are you? Sophia already has access to almost all of the knowledge there is. Atlus, if you wanted her to be a closed-circuit robot, don’t make her an AI. I had to finish the game to see if they redeemed her as a ploy to exploit foolish high schoolers who never wondered for a second why an AI connected to the internet was being asked to be explained and shown things that it could have searched at light speed but left disappointed.

So, should a Persona 5 fan play it? I don’t know. I personally don't recommend it. The last half felt like a chore. I only finished it so I could see the story to its conclusion because Persona 5 Royal had such a great ending. Persona 5 Strikers did not and is mediocre fan fiction at best. It is fun for a while, though.

author: eb00f5f8987a50a9ae8dd4b4a82d0877
content:
The Game is a 8.5/10 in my opinion.
The story doesn't beat the P5 or P5R stories, neither the character development of returning characters (they were already developed in the previous games), but still the story is pretty good and well the returning characters are developed a bit more, they concentrated on the new characters stories (especially the cop) and it is a great follow up to the P5 story, for me the story is a 7/10.
While the story is not better than the previous games it compensated with a great and smooth gameplay, combining the turn base style of the first game with a hack n slash gameplay perfectly, it feels good, fun and rewarding for hitting combos and the persona fighting system is just perfect (ik that this is a controversial opinion bc people did not like the change of gamplay but for me is great, I hate turn base games, the only one I liked was the P5 bc is different from the others and actually fun for being turn base) and the fact that you can switch characters an have a totally different fighting style is great as well, for me the gameplay is a 10/10 they could not have made it better (I played on controller).
Now the music department I don't need to explain 10/10 as always
Art design, personality and charisma is the same 10/10 
For me the only thing lacking in the game is the overall story, I mean is great but is not up to the first game, but gameplay, music, character development, art style and personality it is all there (also something i wish it was different is merciless mode, it starts REALLY hard but as you progress it isn't challenging anymore)
I absolutely recommend this game to anyone who loves persona or that loves hack n slash games bc it is really fun to play and in the end that's what you want in a game.

(This has nothing to do with the review but I hope some day someone makes a JOJOs BA game with the gameplay of this game, I mean Personas are just like a stand and the game is heavily inspired by JOJOs)

author: fc0cde5fa527535d9dd393331f253883
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an amazing game and a great sequel to the original game. It goes further beyond what Atlus achieved with Persona 4 Arena and presents a true continuation of the story in both plot and themes. It is a shorter experience compared to P5 but for some it might be a blessing, but even so it’s still worth every second of your time if you really enjoyed P5.

[h2] Story [/h2] 
First off, it’s worth noting that this game requires you to have played through either Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal. All of the main cast are post-character development so don’t expect any of that here. It’s also worth mentioning that all story additions done in P5R are ignored in this game. That’s because this game and Royal were developed at the same time and since this game is a sequel, I guess Atlus didn’t think enough people would have played Royal within the 4 months in between the two releases. The story is a perfect continuation piece, with every boss connecting to a different member of the Phantom Thieves. You get these moments where the game essentially presents the bad endings of the whole cast through these new enemies and it’s outstanding use of themes of the previous game. Where P5/R was about finding yourself and believing in your ideals regardless of what society believes, this game presents the bosses as people who’ve lost themselves in society’s chains. Their ideals and true selves corrupted to desperately fit in with the rest, creating this parallel with the main cast. Unfortunately the game decides to recreate the last section of the original game in its own way and aside from a key plot twist during this section the rest of it falls flat due to giving a much worse version of P5’s final boss. Imagine the game as one 45~ hour long social link, reuniting with friends and seeing them do the stupidest and funniest things ever.

[h2] Gameplay [/h2] 
It’s a mix of Warriors gameplay with Persona abilities accessible on the fly. This game is probably the best example of Persona as an Action RPG, as it carries over the Persona abilities with nothing cut. You aren’t restricted to four abilities like in other warriors games, you actually have the full arsenal of abilities and you aren’t restricted to a single persona. Persona summoning is brought back with it functioning the exact same way it does in P5, but the amount of person available this game is severely cut and it’s probably for the best because there isn’t much reason to mix and match here. Bosses are subject to the Persona element system and so are you depending on what Persona is equipped but the way it’s transitioned over into this game is perfect. My only gripe is that because it’s a Warriors game there’s no need to ever use the wide range versions of the element attacks because the regular range is already enough and the sacrifice in attack power isn’t worth it. Being a full-fledged sequel it means that traversal hub worlds are also available here and the new locations look really good. The game also makes a deliberate choice to avoid the locations of Persona 3/4, so don’t expect anything from that. 

The point in all of us is that this game is a must play if you loved Persona 5, hell you’d be doing yourself a disservice avoiding this experience. Even if you think you don’t like the Warriors gameplay, this is very easily one of the most friendly games in the series as it honestly just feels like Persona as an Action RPG. Who wouldn’t want another adventure with the best friend group you could find in gaming.

As someone who's an avid enjoyer of Atlus's Persona franchise, despite this spin-off's combat resembling more of a Dynasty Warriors-esque game versus the traditional mainline turn-based RPG style, everything you'd expect from say the Persona 5 base game (excluding social links) is retained here but just executed in a more action-RPG like fashion. Story telling is still superb that's 20+ hours (it's a continuation directly following after Persona 5, but I personally played this game before Persona 5 and was still capable of following along with and enjoying the story), "palace-like" dungeons are still present and persona fusions are still in place, but be aware it's just in a different package that may not be for everyone in terms of combat.
