author: f0563bc27a8d54869d41194d68af0ac6
content:
[h1]A surprisingly high quality, dedicated sequel to P5 let down by a half-baked narrative and flawed combat[/h1]

Let me be clear that my issues with this game aren't with the change in gameplay style, but for those unaware, unlike the original P5, this game is an Action/Musuo RPG where you mop up hordes of enemies and have access to movement at all times.

Commenting on further changes, the game has.
No bonding events[spoiler],at best, there's two scenes where you can pick a person/group to hang out with which is purely up to preference[/spoiler]
No Confidants to gain unique passives/abilities
No time management, you can enter and exit the new Jails as you please with no repercussions
And no references to P5R.
None of these are necessarily negatives, just things to note.

[h1]To be positive before everything else[/h1]
The games style is still fantastic!
Despite not being a new mainline entry, it doesn't feel like they had to sacrifice production values to make the game feels on-par with the original P5.
I absolutely loved the new characters, they feel like great additions to the main cast and their interactions make me really happy they're around.
The new skill/bond tree is a pretty alright replacement for confidants, much less absurd in what it offers, but it's still relatively good progression
The music, both new and remixed, is REALLY great, absolutely loved the new battle themes.
And lastly the act of making new Personas is still as satisfying as ever.

But moving onto the negatives.
[h1]The story feels like a speedrun of the original P5[/h1]
A lot of it just feels like a retread of plot points from the original P5, except instead of well over half a year, this is crammed into the span of a month with issues getting resolved on average, within 3 - 5 days.
This means that a lot of the plot is typically told to you instead of shown, with the cast just kind of stumbling into problems instead of having them be something that personally affects them.
There's definitely more personal issues at points in this story, but I would say you could remove nearly half the Jails and I think the plot would probably be better for it.
Regardless, for what is there, I feel the villains are rather lacking, even if some of their confrontations with certain characters are pretty well written.
I may have enjoyed the ending of this adventure, but the actual final act gave me a sense of "been there, done that".

My biggest complaint however is that the combat just never clicked for me, not because it's different, but because of how poorly it mixes with Persona mechanics.
Enemies are about as mechanically simple as their turn-based counterparts, the problem is that in this gameplay style, you have far more options to damage them and negate damage entirely.
Even with the most basic interaction of Persona management, you can often find a Persona that lets you negate an enemies attacks entirely, such as negating or absorbing attacks.
This sadly extends to bosses which while they're usually far more aggressive than your average enemy, they also usually only have around three moves, and if you bring a Persona that absorbs their element, they might just heal you more than they can physically harm you.
The combatants in this game just don't have enough variety to mess you up if you approach them with basic preparation, and I feel that's its biggest misstep.

Furthermore, I would genuinely just recommend avoiding Hard Mode for a first playthrough, while you can most likely handle the absurd damage outputs and healthpools at some point, your companions have no idea how to deal with it.
A lot of the time they'll just die in one hit, hold onto heals unnecessarily, and overall just feel like more of a hindrance than a help with how many items you'll be pumping into them just to keep them active at points.

[h1]If none of this sounds bad to you, or you just want a continuation of P5, get the game!
It's still a quality product that definitely has appeal and it's absolutely not a bad game[/h1]
I wish I enjoyed this more than I did, but I really do respect the effort that went into this.
It absolutely deserves an audience despite my grievances, and I hope this helps.

author: e64600589c0f55edbc5e5d8154c854f9
content:
I've been quite around the block with Persona titles. Persona 3 FES & Portable, Persona 4 Golden, Persona 4 Arena Ultimax, Persona 5 Royal, the dancing games, Persona Q, the list goes on. And while its obvious that the mainline Persona games will always be a lot better than the spin offs, that doesn't mean the spin off titles are bad or not worth playing, unfortunately Persona 5 Strikers just isn't one of those titles.

P5S is a spin off of the vanilla Persona 5 storyline as it came out before Royal did in Japan, so no Kasmui or Maruki talk (or even Akechi for some reason) but what really hurts the story in my opinion is the fact the story just isnt as impactful or even as interesting. It feels like you're watching a really long list of filler in an anime you really like but its a 40 hour game instead of 20 or so episodes. It's like if they made a video game of the Infinite Tsukuyomi for all the Naruto Shippuden fans out there. A lot of the dialogue, villains, and even pacing feels like all that, and while its initially refreshing to see the Phantom Thieves return in their glory, the magic fades a lot faster than expected because of this. A lot of the story often repeats itself by doing the same thing after every dungeon is completed, or it straight up reuses ideas from the original Persona 5 game.  Not to say there isn't any funny and cool scenes to look at here or there, but it just isn't enough to save it, especially compared to Persona 5 and Persona 5 Royal.


As for the gameplay, they went for a completely different route by using a dynasty warriors beat em up in hordes apporach while using persona mechanics. You can still collect and fuse Personas, cast spells and status aliments, and even the other PT members are fully playable which all sounds really nice except for the fact that the main gameplay doesnt really work as well as you think it does. The dungeons are LONG with really weird and confusing areas as youre climbing, jumping, and running all over the place just trying to figure out where you need to go while shadows try chasing you down. It's really easy to get lost in naviagation because of the weird layout these dungeons have, There's gonna be a lot of "Oh we're here now but the path is blocked, we're gonna have to find the key to open this block so we can use it, but first we gotta defeat hordes of shadows or protect Futaba while she's hacking in order to get to the other area that has the key we need and then go all the way BACK to open the spot we found originally." That's more or less, exactly what you'll be doing in almost every dungeon, especially the later ones. It gets boring after awhile, combine that with the annoyingly long and hard boss fights and the time it takes for you to get used to the layout of the dungeon of where you need to go, this game will soak up a good chunk of your time the first time around. 

The actual dynasty warriors stuff is actually great since they added the persona spice onto it, and I actually enjoy other dynasty warrior games like Hyrule Warriors and One Piece Pirate Warriors for example, which is why I thought I would like Persona 5 Strikers just as much if not more. But those obstacles really get in the way to the point I was playing just so I can see how it ends and finish the game.

As much as I tried liking and defending this game, I think this is the first Persona game I ended up not really enjoying.  The original Persona 4 Arena story and Persona 4 Dancing stories were pretty boring too, but at least they absolutely killed it with gameplay. While its unique in P5S, it just doesn't save it from the problems it has.  I'd skip on this title unless you're a Persona enthusiast that wants to see everything in every game. I recommend Persona 5 Dancing in Starlight or the upcoming Persona 5 Tactica instead.

It can work for fans and even then it's not a must buy.

author: f83ac7bce69558d58358c49efc00e128
content:
I dont usually write reviews but as someone that recently got into persona this game did not do it for me. It's not bad, but I dont recommend playing it:

The first three arcs provided nothing new to what was already seen in persona 5 and felt like filler.
The pacing is unbalanced in that the story sections pass by really quickly and break one of the biggest rules in storytelling, "show, dont tell." In other words, a lot of information is told instead of being shown. In contrast, dungeon exploration is long and repetitive. That is partially due to the tedious request system that drags out this already long game much more than it should. (i want my 53 hours back)
(To those that like persona, be warned that this game has very few social interactions and barely builds upon the phantom thieves as characters)
the combat is alright i guess

The dialogue might be the worst part. The game is filled with scenes of characters standing in a circle doing the same three talking animations, discussing matters you should not be expected to care about as half of the plot events have no stakes involved.
Its not that big of a deal but it really bothered me seeing the characters perform the same two animations in all the discussion scenes.
That being said the game does slowly get better after the first few arcs and had its moments where it truly felt like persona.
and i must say the soundtrack did not disappoint of course


In summary, not worth your time unless you REALLY enjoyed persona 5. Otherwise, you'd have just as much fun or even more watching a playthrough rather than actually playing it. Either that or wait for a sale.

7/10

content:
Fun game, you get a good action game with the characters from P5 that we love
Please be aware the port is donkey doodoo. I had major stuttering issues but I fixed it with the following:

1) opening task manager
2) right click on persona 5 strikers
3) click "go to details"
4) look for "game.exe", it will have the P5S logo.
5) right click on that
6) set priority to "high" (on normal by default)
7) select "set affinity" and check the box for all processors.
8) you'll have to do this every time (at least I do). 

Hopefully a future patch fixes the above

author: da3b5d3f6f5d5f45849f854406ee13e2
content:
The good:
 
•We get to see the PT again, some members get some much deserved extra screentime

•The new playable characters are very likeable

•Story is decent, it's a bit repetitive at the start but has some good moments

•Music is great, there are new songs as well as remixes from P5

•Gameplay is interesting, similar mechanics to turn-based Persona games, except now it's in (pseudo) real time. Personally it was overwhelming at first but by the end it felt natural

The mediocre:

•Dungeon design was often pretty boring and sometimes confusing, idk could be a me problem

•Merciless mode (which is ng+ exclusive) is actually hard. No really, breaking the game is a prerequisite

•Fusion system is "simplified", which actually makes fusing personas you want a lot more complicated

•Random drops from enemies are stingy and make no sense, I've played for 126 hours and still don't have some very basic "whatever boost" skill cards. The drop pools are seemingly so large that farming is a fool's errand. On the bright side you shouldn't really need to farm

•No control for AI companions, can't give them even basic commands like "Stop spamming heals the moment anyone takes a bit of damage we have 6 million healing items in inventory you're gonna run out of SP and become useless". Also they suck at dodging certain attacks. Additionally, as far as I've seen, they don't use any special attacks or master arts or anything, which is understandable but still pretty lame

The bad:

•The difficulty suffers from "Persona Syndrome", where the beginning of the game is needlessly difficult and then it gets easier as time goes on as you unlock more skills, level up, get more items, etc. This is especially true in this game; at the beginning on Normal difficulty random mini-bosses will shrug off your attacks and one tap you, but by the end of the game you feel practically unstoppable. This makes the early to mid game a massive slog

The worst:

•The final boss is just boring on Normal, but on Merciless it's absolutely the worst part of the game hands down. Mashing buttons for 30 mins turns you braindead. You also have to beat the fight 3 times to unlock the secret boss as well, which is not fun at all

•The final boss on Merciless, again

•The final boss on Merciless, but now it's "painful past +" so it has even more health, hits harder, faster, etc. Essentially translates to "takes even more time to kill"

content:
Going to tap out at 8 hours. The story seems like it'll be cool but this combat is just awful. You either "ambush" then press another button to "beat em up" and that's the whole fight or you get into a fight where your lock on fails constantly, bosses have big damage attacks that aren't broadcasted and all the while the game's colors are just absurd. It's way to much going on.

After looking into this, I see that these people usually make turn based games. I hope they do not make any more hack and slash games because even at $20 this feels like a cheaper indie game that is someone's 4th round draft.

Voice acting and art are very well done. That's not enough to carry this game for me though.

author: b546bcbbee255a36b4329b1ca6054ef9
content: Koei Tecmo returns with another spin-off follow up to a pre-existing series in the Warriors format. But rather than simply just being another Warriors-type venture, Persona 5 Strikers feels more like a full-fledged Persona game that happens to have the combat of a Warriors game. There are personas to fuse, access to the Velvet Room, and the classic SMT/Persona spells and weaknesses accounted for. Narratively, P5S is a follow up to Persona 5 and Royal (note: as of writing, have only played base P5, so I cannot comment on how well P5S jives with any changes introduced there), and the plot definitely feels like a true sequel rather than just a mere throwaway story. P5S maintains the flair and style of the original, and the combat is fun and flashy. Overall, a worthy successor to P5.

author: 215441b9297756978a8913d74de6fe02
content:
So about half a year after I finished Persona 5 R I finally decided to play Persona 5 S. It took me a bit to finish despite how short the game is compared to the main game, mainly because of Genshin and Honkai Star Rail lol. 

P5S was able to replicate the aesthetic that the main game had which is nice, and of course, the music does not disappoint. Even though it reused multiple songs and had reprises of some of the songs from the original game, the few new songs they do add are bangers.

This game was both really different yet pretty similar to P5R. When it comes to the hack-and-slash part of the game It's pretty fun, especially for casual players, but in terms of difficulty, the game didn't really pose any challenge, especially in the later half of the game, which caused me to lose interest in the game from time to time. 

Now when it comes to the story and character interactions, it's really similar to P5R which was the main reason why I was able to finish it. Of course, in my opinion, the story wasn't as great as P5R, but despite that, it was still able to really immerse me in some parts of the game. I also really loved the introduction of both Sophia and Zenkichi, I love them both as characters and find them very charming characters, It was to the point where some scenes involving them really moved me. Also, another thing I liked about the game is that it gave me closure for P5R, just like the ending of P4G.

Would I recommend this game, yes and no, I chose yes on Steam because I personally like it, but there are many things about the game that I can see people dropping or choosing to not play the game over. Also, I do not think this game should be 60 dollars, especially since P5R is also 60 dollars. The game only takes around 30 to 35 hours to finish, there's not that much replayability, and the combat aspect of the game is mostly different from P5R so setting the game at 60 dollars really makes it hard for other P5 fans to justify a purchase like this. Hell, the only reason I got the game was because it was on discount and I was desperate for a Persona game.

Anyway those were my thoughts on the game, very fun, now time to wait for the release of P3R :)

author: 4bdc4ff66622547492a1a7cb9c1742a3
content:
[h1]PSA[/h1]
This is not a review, but a warning.

This game will probably stutter like crazy for you. The solution is to go to Windows Task Manager - Details, then right click and set the game's process to full CPU affinity.

I'm putting this here not only to help potential buyers, but also criticize such blatant disregard for PC port. I am prepared for Koei games to have abysmal PC versions but this takes the cake. The game even starts in a window, for fk's sake... The fact that it's so easy to fix means that devs didn't care at all.

[h1]Initial impressions[/h1]
I expected a musou game with Persona 5 characters, but this game actually plays a lot more like Persona 5 than I anticipated. Walking around town, talking to NPCs, VN-style cutscenes, equipment, even typical dungeon design - it's all here. It's just the combat that's different. From what I can see - you don't get large maps filled with enemies or forts to capture like in most other modern musou games - you explore a palace like in Persona 5 and when you encounter enemies - you fight an enlarged group of them like in a musou title.

Combat itself is what you'd expect out of a game in this genre. Works well, has it's own spin with persona switching, guns, etc. Makes good use of what we've seen in Persona 5 to create a unique musou experience.

Story is also far more involved than I expected. It's not really a sequel, but calling it a spin-off would be an understatement. It takes place after the events of Persona 5 (but without extra events of Royal edition or it's characters). It introduces completely new additions to Phantom Thieves roster as well as new threats with full-blown anime cutscenes, fully-voiced dialogue and everything you could expect out of a sequel to Persona 5. But if we ever get a sequel to Persona 5, I doubt this would be the story they continue, more likely they would continuoe from the events of Royal.

Then again, it would be very unlike ATLUS to create a proper sequel to a Persona game anyway. Point is - don't treat this like a sequel, but also expect a level of storytelling and quality that's higher than a typical musou spin-off like Fire Emblem Warriors.

[h1]Should you buy it?[/h1]
I think so. Despite me putting this review at 'not recommended', I have high hopes that it's going to be a great Persona musou game, combining both franchises into a surprisingly strong whole.

But the way PC ports are treated by Koei is not something I will excuse. If not for the fixable stutter I would recommend this easily. However I may change my mind in the future. If the game ends up being incredibly impressive I may put it on a 'recommended' verdict despite the stutter. We'll see once I'm done with it.

author: c22773dfb75058959c6076f1284687c3
content:
Persona 5 Strikers takes the beloved characters and world of Persona 5 into the realm of musou-style gameplay, and it successfully manages to blend the intense action with the series' signature elements. Developed by P-Studio and Omega Force, this spin-off game offers an engaging and refreshing take on the Persona formula.One of the strongest aspects of the game is its captivating storyline. Persona 5 Strikers takes place a few months after the events of Persona 5, where the Phantom Thieves reunite for a summer road trip across Japan. The narrative delves into the group's inner struggles and their attempt to solve a mysterious supernatural conspiracy that threatens to distort people's desires. The well-written dialogue, character development, and overarching themes of friendship and justice are reminiscent of the original game, making it a worthwhile continuation for fans.

The gameplay mechanics in Persona 5 Strikers add a new layer of excitement to the series. Combining hack-and-slash combat with role-playing elements, players can control any member of the Phantom Thieves with their unique skills and personas. The battles are fast-paced and exhilarating, with a wide range of enemies and stunning visual effects. Despite the hack-and-slash nature, strategic elements such as exploiting enemy weaknesses and switching characters on the fly still play a vital role, preserving the strategic depth Persona 5 fans love.

,MY RATINGS: ★★★★☆ (4/5)

author: d17f0538d61e5a14a90745ffc2e59b83
content:
It's more Persona 5 so if you liked Royal then you'll probably already be playing this anyway.

I like that because the tone of this game's story is less serious than Royal it gives more time to the characters interacting/joking around as a group and there's more social events which I feel was missing a little from PS5R.

Overall the experience is more streamlined with no daily calendar to worry about or social links but is instead all about the dungeons/story. Slightly disappointed some of the social link decisions didn't carry over from PS5R but then Royal didn't reflect completing social links in the main story's dialogue well either.

I liked the new fighting probably more than the turn based stuff in the main game.

The sidequests are pretty crap and would've liked to see some more social interactions when completing requests for party members instead of just a few lines of dialogue in the menu screen.

During dungeons at any checkpoint you can restore the party's HP/SP to full for free by leaving the dungeon and returning to the checkpoint with no expense other than sitting through the loading screens. Time doesn't progress or anything there's literally no reason not to do this so every checkpoint should just be made an auto-heal to full.

The new characters where good and wasn't too disappointed that characters from Royal where missing.

Although the story isn't as good as PS5R I didn't expect it to be and is still interesting enough.

content:

That being said, it does have technical issues. It lacks anti-aliasing, is capped at 60 fps, and crashes often. The crashes can be avoided by using the "hotfix2" beta branch and disabling hyperthreading. I am disappointed that it has these issues.

That being said, it does run just as well on Linux/Steam Deck as it does on Windows via Proton.

author: 045f5c45790754f2b36b8d2e8c2df10f
content:
Wish I could say the fact that Persona 5 Royal completely exceeded my expectations is a factor with how disappointing Persona 5 Strikers turned out to be, but that’s not really the case. I went into it expecting a good mindless hack and slash action RPG with a story that will at least be not bad, yet even that was too much to ask. And while I didn’t hate the title and even occasionally enjoyed it, I’m not sure who the audience for this game is supposed to be.

Persona 5 Strikers is a curious title. It’s far from the first Persona game to be a story continuation of some kind – Persona Q, Dancing All Night or Arena games are all considered canon. But it is a direct canonical sequel to Persona 5 (and Royal) to the point where it was marketed as P5 2 in some promotional materials. The title was developed by Omega Force, best known for their Dynasty Warriors games (usually called musou games, from the Japanese title for the series), so it’s a hack and slash with elements of an action RPG instead of a turn-based RPG. While I’ve played and enjoyed only a couple of the Dynasty Warriors titles in the past, I do know that usually their titles are about territory control over big maps with lots and lots of enemies on screen. This game doesn’t play like that.

Instead, Persona 5 Strikers tries to employ an approach closer to how P5 worked. You still have a stealth aspect and an ability to hide and ambush shadows. Shadows are still patrolling the levels in very small numbers only to reveal more of themselves once the battle starts and battles still work as a separate game mode, with a clear boarder you can escape from and a post battle results screen. Locations are also still operating on the Persona logic of certain activities available in the real world and combat taking place in another layer of reality, with several such dungeons available across the game. Magic spells, Persona usage, collection and creation is retained, as are minor aspects of the social life.

But then the rest of the mechanics are swapped for an action game. Fights are hack and slash and you can juggle dozens of shadows in the air at once. You can jump, have air combos and more movement options. Time management aspect is completely gone and time only advances via story, meaning that you can usually enter and exit dungeons at any point with no downsides. A lot of systems are simplified and the only mechanical aspect of social life is represented via a system of permanent upgrades for you and your team. Every character has their own fighting style and strategy… Although, you will simply mash buttons most of the time as that’s how these games tend to work.

It’s nice to have a somewhat mindless hack and slash now and then, but Persona 5 Strikers doesn’t feel that good. I like how you can quickly dash across the battle area and perform cool special attacks, but everything about the combat in the game feels sluggish. Like – there’s a dedicated dodge button, but it works half the time, often with a delay… until it decides to works perfectly fine. Or how some contextual actions tied to one single button are usually prioritized in a smart way, except when they misfire and instead of an All out attack you’re suddenly riding a skateboard. I didn’t expect Platinum Games combat, of course, but even Tokyo Xanadu eX+ had a better one and that game is far from being fun.

All of which then ties to just how dated the design of the game feels. Even Persona 3, for how frustrating some of its design decisions were, feels far friendlier than this title. There are so many pointless loading screens for every little thing. Some side quests require you to talk to a person, then need to go back to your car with a loading screen, accept the request, exit the car with a loading screen, go talk to another person in another location with a loading screen, who gives you another request, so you load back into the car to accept the request, to then go into a dungeon with a loading screen, to then start playing the dungeon with a loading screen or a long cutscene, to then do menial tasks for the request… And if you think just confirming that you’ve completed said requests requires less steps you’re mistaken. It’s stupid how much stuff is inconvenient in ways I’ve not seen since Playstation 2 days.

Then again, even the audio and visual aspects of the game are such a downgrade. Visually the game isn’t bad, but it doesn’t have that same bold striking vision that P5 has. While the music is… There are a couple of good new tracks, but the rest are either bland or horrible butt rock arrangements of tracks from P5, that sound as if they were composed and performed by a 50 year old rocker dude who thinks he’s very cool.

The story is pointless, as in most ways it’s a revisit of the exact same main plot idea from P5, but much worse. New characters aren’t particularly interesting, but that’s not the the issue. The sad thing is that the returning cast feels… How do I even describe it… You know how in the 80s and 90s there were TV shows based on movies and they would often have the characters from the movie and same premise, but everything was simplified and every episode had to maintain the status quo and there was no overall story progression? Characters feel like that – like they were simplified down to their most basic aspects. As if they regressed from who they were at the end of P5 (even if you’ve ignored going through their personal stories). Or here’s another status quo – the protagonist never tells anyone about the Velvet Room, even though everyone personally experienced it, seemingly just because “that’s how it was in P5 for the most part”. I know it might be weird to get hung up on the story and characters in a musou game, but it’s also a Persona game. You know, a game with a good story, where personal relationships aren’t just important for said story but are also its defining gameplay mechanic?

So I simply do not see the audience for this game. It’s not a good hack and slash – it’s decent enough to be sometimes enjoyable, but not fantastic. The story sucks and feels like an average fanfiction about the characters you grew to like, rather than a sequel. It’s not as stylish or cool sounding as main Persona games. It has no substitute for the fun turn-based aspect of the main game, but is also not mindless and silly enough to be entertaining in the way a Dynasty Warrior game can be. I did finish the game and there were moments where I found myself enjoying the silly spectacle on the screen, but I can’t say that it was worth it. Might be for you, if you find any of what I’ve described alluring. And I do hope to see an action oriented spin-off for Persona someday. Just, maybe do it with Nihon Falcom next time, Atlus. Anything but this.

content:
I'm not the biggest fan of the Dynasty Warrior style of gameplay, but they made if feel so much like Persona 5 that it was kind of nice. I found it hard to get into, but then I dropped the difficulty down, and it made the game a lot more fun because I was really just playing for the story segments and to spend more time with the Phantom Thieves.

The actual port is really bad. The game didn't run in full screen mode, so I had to play the whole game windowed, which breaks immersion when I can see my desktop.

In conclusion, kinda jank and the gameplay is not my cup of tea, but the Persona 5 style carries it.

author: e03636bef62557cf834352f663d2c158
content: I don't really compare it to Musou, Nioh series or Souls series but it has some good reference from all these modern action games. The story and the vibe are not far from the og and I really love the summer road trip with my best friends. However, the game is not that brilliant as an action game. The game flow is weird, the map design is confusing, the character movements are clumsy, and it has nothing can be really called "reward" after each battle...so I can't recommend it to the action game fans if you don't know P5. It is a good addition to the og story though and it makes me happy to live in that world again. Perhaps this alone is enough to put my thumb up for this game.

author: 9d42ddf640fa50578c9afecec1aef860
content:
This is my first Persona game, the characters are interesting enough to make me want to play P5R and P4G. The story isn't exceptionally good or anything, just a fun summer trip with friends but the gameplay is quite solid.

 Great soundtrack, didn't understand a world including the english parts. Performance were solid, not a single frame dropped, the UI is a little bit blurry but that's about it. The game isn't hard, enemies are just spongy on higher difficulty unless you can consistently inflict ailments for technical hits, no extra money or exp for playing on higher difficulty. Unless you want to grind, play on normal mode, it's hard to keep the entire team up to your level without grinding much.

 The game is surprisingly good for a spin-off especially when the franchise is all about turn-based combat. It's an Action JRPG with Musou combat, not a Musou game with JRPG story elements so don't expect to just spam combos to win like a Musou game. You have to use Persona skills and combos that end with a persona attack to exploit enemy weaknesses to break enemy shields so you can perform an All Out Attack which is your highest single attack damage.
 The time pause when you bring up Persona menu or using gun so use that to reposition yourself during combat because this game is quite a visual clutter, for the first 2 jails I couldn't understand what was happening on the screen. The first 2 Jails gonna be a bit tough because you don't have a lot of SP or recovery items, you can leave jail at any checkpoints to recover HP & SP for free as well as refresh shop's stocks.
 You can play as any characters in the party but everyone only has one persona except for MC, Joker. Different weapons and movesets for everyone, you'll be playing with a party of 5 but one character will always be in your party but unplayable so you'll have Joker and 3 other characters to switch during combat, you can switch party members at any time as long as you're not in combat. Would have been nice if there were custom strategy for AI companions like Tales of Arise.
 You get new persona by either getting a mask drop from killing personas or through fusion, some personas can only be acquired through fusion, when you fuse personas the new persona can inherit up to 5 skills from the parents. You can spend hours trying to figure out how to pass skills that you wanted to your favorite persona, which was quite fun for me or you can just follow a guide.
 New weapons, armors and accessories are locked behind progress, some come from chests or side quests. On certain days during the story you will get new side quests in form of requests, most of them are kill enemies by exploiting their weakness, run to a location without triggering the alarm, collecting junks, refight bosses, fuse a persona to have a specific skill, find an item in jails. Some requests take place in real world, provide interactions between characters and are missable.

 Overall the game is solid, I enjoyed it, the first jail is a bit rough but once you get passed it the game become a bit easier, nothing much to complain really except for one achievement that will stop you from 100% the game because it require a stupid amount of grinds for bond experiences, like 15-20 hours just to get the last 30 levels. If you don't care about achievements then the game is one smooth 50-70 hours experience.

author: c2014c843c9851be8cb8d42c916d4870
content:
Persona 5 (Royal Included) sits in my top ten games. This game is like Persona 5, but:

- The gameplay sucks - Braindead mashing and the camera controls are the hardest enemy in the game. Everytime there's a boss the devs' idea of making it a challenge is giving it a stupidly large amount of health.
- The writing sucks - annoyingly anime tropey at times, although the voice acting is still fantastic, as is every persona game.
- The new music sucks - unmemorable and the remixes of old songs range from alright to bad.

So yeah, it's Persona 5 but worse in every way. I'm being very harsh on the game and I'm overselling a lot of the points, but by the 4th jail I was so tired of the gameplay loops and I had to force myself to finish it.
it fits the definition of a "mid" game. Unmemorable, mindless but decent way to pass the time, only recommended if you are a weeb and/or a diehard Persona 5 fan, or you like musou games (which I've never tried before and never will again!)

author: 5d50f0e422d45af0b3f79a7be3f7b0b7
content:
P5 and P5R are one of my all time favorite games, so of course i got this and quite like it. Story's pretty good, not as thematic as P5 but nonetheless an engaging second outing for the Phantom Thieves. combats fun but a bit tedious. dungeons are cool thematically but overlong and devoid of puzzle-solving. figuring out how to trigger elemental attacks without SP is a gamechanger, and im super pleased with the variety each character has in playstyle; Joker is a bit of a Jack of all Trades, just as he should be, Ryuji and Haru are heavies (both have different combos), Yusuke and newcomer Zenkichi are basically DPS, and Morgana and Makoto are basically healers/buffs. Each character has their own combos inspired by their elements and weapons of choice (Ann imbues her whip with fire, Haru does a spin attack with her axe, etc) and each with also expand by using them--as each character gets used in combat, they unlock more powerful combos. Follow-Ups from P5 return in slightly a different way: when an enemy is staggered, you can switch to the prompted character to trigger a powerful follow-up attack. The baton pass mechanic has also been reworked into an instant switch to active character, so at anytime, you can switch to a character that may better suit the circumstances. A "Showtime" attack can be activated once a meter has been filled to either deal heavy damage or clear a room. Each character has their own unique animation for these. Bosses are proper hard, necessitating teamwork and frequent switching, clever use of Showtime, as well as engagement with the dodging and weakness mechanics--this is a very different game from the Persona series' usual turn based MO.

The story starts really strong and kinda peters out. At first, you may be given the impression that its retreading the personal themes of each thief to further flesh out their character (the first villain relates to Ann, second Yusuke, third Haru) but it drops this seemingly to get on with the actual plot of whose behind it all. Newcomer Sofie/Sofia is charming and helpful as an AI character (which also allows Futaba to shine a little) and is a decently worthy addition to the crew. some noteworthy early absences feel baffling (why are both Iwai AND Takemi not in their usual spots? Not to mention Sumire, but tbf this is a sequel to P5, not P5R) as well as a few missed opportunities to have fun cameos from others admittedly kinda drag it down.

My one major complaint comes down to the Covid pandemic; this game's voice acting was recorded remotely. While each actor is better and more comfortable as their characters and the acting is generally great, the mixing is not. even after fiddling with the audio, i haven't found a set of options that makes the music and dialogue feel like they have the right volumes. other than that, its a bit tedious, but if you like the characters, its basically a no brainer.

Alright, so for starters, the game is amazing, the new Fighting animations and Designs and Inclusing the story are good, they are like a MOB WAVE Game and each charcter have their own unique animation, i love the yo yo Sophia Moves, but anyways imma head into the main issue. the crashes now i gave up on the game after doing the second Jail. i had over 10 crashes, legit coulndt understand why the crash keep going, i lowered the entire game settings to the lowest, and even turned off discord and 1 other background app and guess what? the crashes countinued. i wont lie, but every time the game crashed, it either crashed when they went into the Metaverse, or a cutscene was changing, i keept crashing after the end scenes for the second Monarch, and i decided to just finish this ark and leave the game for good, i couldnt fixe it, i tried going thru forums, reddit, and even yt videos to fixe the damm crashes, but no prevail. i gave up on this game for now until i get either a better PC or get a way to fixe it to lower the crash rate, but lets see, from 36H game, you only play around 45 minutes before u crash, the game run fine while fighting, but exactly when u head into the metaverse u legit either crash, or just freeze.

author: dcee5c089759593b813cb8f03f7da08b
content:
[h1] A satisfying "sequel"[/h1] 
This game ended up being very different from what I expected from a Warriors style game. The change from all out warfare in a big map to repeated encounters of varying difficulty on segmented maps fits the Persona series well. It starts really strong with a visually lush and detailed rendition of fantasy Shibuya but all the further locations aren't as impressive to look at. I would've liked it if we could deploy all the characters in combat instead to being limited to a team of four. It's nice how the plot develops some characters more than the crumbs they got in Persona 5. Play it if you don't mind long games.

author: e770a9b5d8b358018f9834dd5154fdd4
content:
The craziest summer vacation of the Phantom Thieves!

The gameplay went from "sneaking into peoples palaces and stealing peoples hearts" to "high octane brawling and dashing all the way through the castle".


The gameplay is really good, unique and flashy. The only thing I'd complain about in this game will be the awful camera movement. Other than this, everything in this game is amazing. The new soundtrack is absolute bangers as well.

Zenkichi and Sophia are great additions to the game, loved how they played their part in the story. The story is also filled with memorable events that were wholesome, goofy, awkward and fun. And the best part, THEY GAVE HARU MORE SCREENTIME IN THE GAME!

Overall, it's an amazing sequel that I'll forever cherish in my memories, just as I loved Persona 5 Royal. I adore this franchise with all my heart so maybe I'm biased so yeah.

10/10!

content: Really great game, combat is really engaging and the soundtrack is amazing, but you should play Persona 5 Royal first because this takes place after and can spoil some of that game's story. Speaking of story, this game kinda has the same story beats, for example, (SPOILERS AHEAD FOR PERSONA 5 STRIKERS AND PERSONA 5/P5 ROYAL) [spoiler]the first palace (or cage as this game calls them) is themed around the deadly sin of lust, and takes place at Shujin Academy. The second palace is themed around vanity and the owner is a famous person that many people hold in high regard.[/spoiler] however, with all that said, I do think that this is overall a pretty good spin on the Persona 5 universe but you should probably only buy it when it's on sale, just to be safe.

author: 4bc5358d6147578bad3fcc5cdc617be8
content:
Alright funny hehe haha persona game sequel. TLDR? Good Luck.
My interest in the game itself? Pretty okay mostly because I love Persona 5 on its own. (including royal because more story stuff.) Im very interested in the combat on its own, especially since you can use abilities without well. Spending resources if you use your combos right. It can get wild. The art style and the looks like usual are just great. Still some things stick out that arent as unique when compared to Persona 5 but still good. 

My problems with the game right now? It is INCREDIBLY difficult to actually PLAY the game. At least for me, im seeing this same problem with other people on higher end rigs. Mines not really high end at all. However I was able to run Persona 5 Royal on max, never had a single frame drop to my memory. 
You are ABLE to run the game max setting without issues absolutely. The problem, is the game is Horribly optimized. The control scheme is written by monkeys on typewriters mans. (I genuinely rebinded all I could to play like dark souls and it was working better than the default.) 
More on the optimization issues. Running the game in Windowed, Borderless, or Fullscreen Ive continuously ran into the same problems. (Even with running Process Lasso in the background as suggested online.) The game will drastically drop all the way down to running at 5-10 frames. With Process Lasso running the frame rate doesnt really drop often? But the game Slows Down as if it WERE running at that framerate mentioned above. 
This can happen with any scene transitions, cutscenes, Pre-Rendered cutscenes, and practically anything you can do in the game. Including Showtimes! in combat. 
Ive only put 3.5 hours as of this review and have barely made any progress. Its a serious struggle to enjoy it in this state. Please fix this port. 
Ill be leaving it as a No until either I can find an option to fix these issues, or the game gets fixed by any amount. 
Oh yeah, the camera is also terrible.

author: 26229f9d12ec56ada40e7b09c100b4d4
content:
tl;dr: beat up monsters for the equivalent of 5 USD and spend it all on food and soda to heal your party hee-ho

Strikers is my first musou/hack n' slash game, I decided to pick this up after finishing P5R. I don't hate it. Sure, feels a bit tedious and the story is not nearly as good as in the mainline titles, but it's actually quite fun beating up crowds of bozos when you get into it. Boss fights aren't a breeze on Normal, but they aren't too difficult or unfair from my experience. The game kind of drags out the tutorials through the first Jail, but I don't mind it as a newcomer to the genre. 

If you are expecting all the Persona-related systems to be fleshed out, I'm sorry. Fusion is terribly neutered and I don't bother messing with it very much. Most of the items you buy are going to be healing items for your team as they get bodied by boss fights. The main draw is the combat, and if you're a player who enjoys time management and day to day life within the world, you'll be sorely disappointed.

It's definitely extremely linear and doesn't seem to have much meaningful replayability. But so far, I've logged about 12 hours on my save and I'm pretty sure I'm only half way through the game, so there's still plenty of value-for-money to be had here. If you're a Persona 5 fan then you'll at least like the character interactions outside of the gameplay. 

If you're looking for something to hold you over until Persona 3 Reload or Persona 6 arrives, this ain't a bad time investment.

author: 4aae31bad50a5a1f96cb6bf5191dc75f
content:
Bad tutorial, but once you actually figure out the mechanics this is a very good game. 

Early game tips:

- You can change your party even when not at a checkpoint (go int Stats in the menu)
- You are expected to go out of the jail multiple times to refresh your SP.
- Items refresh when you go out of the jails (if you've stayed in the jail a certain duration). Buy up healing and SP items every time you go out of jail
- Get the shop bond skill early, 60% off bandages will help a lot
- You can trigger elemental attacks without using SP by using a specific combo (light - light - light - heavy for most characters, some characters just need 2 lights before the heavy)

author: e5fce5b86bdd5476966de3823af73180
content:
If you are playing on a PC with an AMD processor that uses simultaneous multi-threading (SMT) make sure you download Ryzen Master and disable SMT when you play this game. It seems to prevent the menu freezes that people have experienced. 

I spent over 2 weeks going back and forth with a customer service rep from Sega support about the issue, which didn't result in any helpful information whatsoever. I was able to finish the game using this fix at least and I wouldn't expect a new patch.

As for the game itself, I would highly recommend it for fans of Persona 5. Definitely play P5R first though.

Just know going in that this is mostly a pretty standard action RPG. I was expecting Persona 5 Dynasty Warriors and it doesn't really feel like either of those games in terms of the core gameplay.

The day-to-day life sim elements of P5R are mostly gone, but there is still plenty of the classic fun interaction between the characters (except Yoshizawa & Akechi I guess, booo). Many of the other features that you'd expect from Persona are there, like persona fusion, just in a similarly stripped-down fashion.

Despite not being a full-on Persona entry, Strikers is still a lot of fun. If you want more Phantom Thieves, definitely give this one a try.

author: 5ad6faaa90a15859b9e9b9fd9ff186ce
content:
Summary: If you love the Persona series but wish it was less turn based and more live action, this game is for you.

GASH review (Gameplay, Achievements, Story, Hate)

[b]Gameplay[/b]
I absolutely love the gameplay. Some may say it's basically another musou game, but I disagree strongly. There is so much respect to the Persona series gameplay that it essentially feels like the devs just took that and added a musou twist, rather than a musou game with Persona sprinkled in. 
To really succeed, you need to have strong personas and can't simply treat it as a beat-em-up. You have elemental weaknesses/strengths, almighty damage, critical stun states for stronger enemies, and basically everything in mainline Persona games including persona fusion/execution to make your personas stronger. 
The usage of personas is extremely fluid, allowing the player to choose a persona using a semi-paused popup menu and executing attacks based on what combo you use. Overall, great gameplay and feels like the expected quality of a mainline game.

[b]Achievements[/b]
There's nothing particularly noteworthy of the achievements, and if there were any that were painful, I don't really remember them, indicating that even difficult/tedious ones weren't that bad.

[b]Story[/b]
The story is somewhat lacking but still holds water. It feels like they took a sequel plot to Persona 5 and watered it down. However, the new character is absolutely charming and adds so much to the story by virtue of being such a great character, but I wish the game could've had a story as deep as the mainline game. What it does instead is take a very light approach, which is acceptable considering it's enough to keep your attention, putting the gameplay first and foremost.

[b]Hate[/b]
There's not much to actually hate about this game, and I really implore anyone to buy it even if it's not on sale. I wish there was more story, more to be explored, and just more overall, but the experience was absolutely worth every penny.

author: bfbada8ce1eb59f2822c84aa5ba1c9c3
content:
Full playtime: 66 hours.

Full recommendation to those that love Persona 5.

Feeling very sentimental now.

I waited years to finally play Persona 5 Royal, then as I considered it not only good, but full of content well beyond its asking price on Steam, I bought Persona 5 Strikers as well. And played it after finishing the original game.

In short, Strikers takes after the events of Persona 5 and brings the team back together in a new case, against a new foe, in a new mystery, which takes them all across Japan.

I just finished it and now it really is over. As the credit roll, I am brought back to all of the moments in the original and in this one that I have enjoyed over 250 hours.

名残惜しい


Is it worth it? The games is more of a Dynasty Warriors type game with many elements of the Persona games. It is not turn based and is more live action.

Other than that, if you loved Persona 5 and its characters, then this game is definitely worth it and is quite fleshed out, especially for a Persona 5 spin-off game. The game provides massive amounts of fan service as well as general knowledge about Japan and its different regions.

Some tips: Don't let the first part of the game turn you off, it does get better and easier from then. I finished the game on hard mode.

author: 336d852d7b4153da847168383db7bdae
content:
I held out on this for a long time, due to thinking it was just a spin-off capitalizing on the popularity of Persona 5. I was simply not interested in a Musou game (think, Dynasty Warriors) since that style of gameplay seemed too grindy and repetitive, and if it wasn't going to be a JRPG then why bother.

I'm so glad I finally played it.
Let me make one thing straight: it did _not_ make a believer out of me when it comes to Musou games. In fact, I played this on Easy difficulty to reduce the grind.
But, it was absolutely worth it. The story is a direct continuation from Persona 5, and it brings all the style and themes from the orginal, including the grandiose Palaces (called "Jails" here), a fantastic soundtrack of both remixes and new songs, and all the crew from the original game. Some new characters are also introduced and they mesh very well with the old cast, which have grown so comfortable with their company to the point where lots of hilarious shenanigans take place on a regular basis. Together with the new well-written story, it was an absolute blast.
Yes, the game feels a bit like it lacks polish or there have been corners cut here and there compared to the full package that was Persona 5, but honestly you won't mind it if you're mainly here for the story.

If you completed and loved Persona 5, you should definitely get this. If you're not a fan of Musou games, play it on easy and just enjoy the story and spectacle. It's worth it, and the game goes on decent sales from time to time too so you can snag it for cheap if you want.

author: 64271531dba85922b50cf44b4b58c871
content:
As a musou game, it's a disaster. As a Persona game, it's also a disaster. God, I didn't have high expectations for this game, but somehow they managed to make me hate it outright. You know, you don't have to fill a game with mini-bosses and bosses with absurd amounts of HP. Even if you play as the game tells you, you're stuck in a boss fight with the same boring, unresponsive combat that has ever graced this genre. It's just awful. The dodge mechanic might as well not exist; what's the point if you're not going to add something to make us actually use it? The punishment is way too high if you miss it, with no real rewards for dodging perfectly. And what's with the ridiculously high amount of damage the mobs do compared to the damage you do? Even when applying debuffs to the enemy, you can barely notice that you're doing damage. It's so weird that the only thing that actually does some damage are your personas, but here's the catch: they have so little SP that by the time you manage to lower 10% of the boss's health, you'll just get absolutely drained of SP.

And what's with the world in this game? I just can't understand how we went from a great introductory palace like Kamoshida's to a really dry, generic, and soulless half-baked "city". Almost every part of that first jail looks so bland and uninspired.

I won't even talk about the voice acting; it's mostly due to the awful job from the mixing team not doing their jobs properly. Morgana's voice is way too loud in comparison to Yusuke's, and it's just baffling. Again, good job to the voice actors, it's a shame they got let down by the audio mixing team.

The game difficulty might be too hard even for newcomers, even on easy mode, I presume. Anyway, I just can't recommend this game. Just stick to P5R. Even though it's a JRPG, you'll probably have more fun than whatever they tried to cook up with this one.

author: 9639aa16b4095b57b860aaa6bc39c2d1
content:
if you have a Intel 12th gen cpu or later DO NOT BUY THIS GAME. The game will barely run at about 3 to 17 fps no matter your settings with severe stutters that lead to crashes. This is likely due to Denuvo DRM embedded in the game but customer support has been of no help and says that "Unfortunately since the game has not been tested on newer gens we cannot guarantee that you will not encounter these type of issues". 
The game has not gotten an update in 2 years even though there is a discussion board (made by Atlus themselves) with more than 1.864 comments about issues with the game (https://steamcommunity.com/app/1382330/discussions/0/3118150513192496504/?ctp=125)

The game also stutters a lot even when played on a 8th gen cpu which I can only assume is due to shader compilation.

On Steam Deck using proton 7 or 8 the game will not boot.
It should be noted that on Steam Deck with proton-ge50 (modified Valve's proton) this game is playable but the video cutscenes have no dialogue audio which is very important in a Persona game like this one....

To sum up this game is not worth the technical hassle/bad performance and not even close to being worth the 60 euro price tag.

Edit:
Here is a tip for users, with "stuttering and lag" issues, who are using intel 12th and 13th gen cpu or any future cpus that has big and little cores.
Use Process lasso to set affinity of the game to all available cores (P and E cores).
You can do this even in process manager of windows.
If you need more tips go to the game steam forums and type process lasso for more details and discussion on this topic.

author: 37d1a5bd005a5a3bb771d8c8d238887e
content:
The Good: I think this is the only Persona spinoff I've played where everyone actually feels in character without having their quirks philanderized, and the music is fantastic as always. My desire to keep playing is being fuelled by these things and the plot, which is intriguing enough so far.

The Bad: Gameplay could have used another pass or two in my opinion. The core action is fine, but the compulsion to cram every mechanic from the main series in here makes for about 10 subsystems too many. The tutorials (while exhaustive) throw pretty much everything at once at you. There's no way (for me) to keep it all straight so I typically end up cruising on the basics instead of getting fancy like the game clearly wants me to do (also I'm 10hrs in and haven't really felt the need to fuse personas at all???).

EDIT: Depending on the day, it also runs like an epileptic tortoise. I've been running it in windowed mode since the start of the 2nd dungeon which helps a bit, but given that loads of people are having similar problems, I'd definitely take this into consideration before buying.

author: dc522828d79254ae85866ff32db40d3a
content:
First off! If you are having issues running this game, fix can be found at the bottom:

UPDATED REVIEW 

I have to swap this to Negative, unfortunately. It's a Warriors game through and through as far as the combat is concerned. And I really don't vibe with Warriors games. 

If you don't mind that, go for it. Story seems nice. But if you also don't like Warriors games, reconsider carefully.

Also, the fact that there is no punishment to just leave mementos to get a full heal is a big issue. It should just heal you by interracting with the checkpoint/teleporter. At this stage, you spend several minutes every time you reach a checkpoint just to teleport out and back in. With several unskippable transitions and loading screens. It's a pain.

It's also a pain to run, but you'll find a fix for that down below.



!FIX TO PLAY THIS GAME ON MODERN HARDWARE!


Big ups to NoobMasterB in the comments here. The port is god awful for any decent CPU released the last 5 years. Essentially unplayable. However, using a program called "Process Lasso" lets you run the game without issue :)

Another tip: The game for some reason only has 8 directional movement, even with a controller. Super awkward. For this you can use a mod called "Smooth Analog Movement". You get it from Gamebanana. Fixes this issue as well. 

All of this shouldn't be neccessary, but it is. This is a hackjob of a port. But with the above, you will be able to run it nicely.

author: 5559d727c2d95ac192b4963bc030a6e6
content:
(very, very mild spoilers. People might miss them completely)

4.5/10 game review, done about 1/4-1/2 the way through the game

Game Play: 3 (controls messy out of the box, camera can be janky), game balance is whacked
Game Mechanics: 4 ( a good nod to the original but it clashes with the main theme of the combat and it lacks 'soul')
Graphics: 7 (good, true to original)
Sound/Dub: 7 (good, true to original)
Plot: 5 (neither good nor bad, little reference to original but doesn't mess with it either)

For some reason, some of the cut scenes lag. I suspect a porting problem.

Combat is odd. Do you like kicking puppies? Be prepared to kick puppies dozens at a time, because that's the feeling I get taking on a million trash mobs that are no threat with so much happening on the screen that hardly matters, so my brain shuts down and I don't much care. I get this is a type a brand of game on it's own, but it doesn't seem interesting or well done.

The story does make references back to P5 in a fashion. Slight ones. After all, we know the police aren't fond of joker because of the whole "No we are the Power and you will BOW to our Awe-Thor-itay because if you don't Society will CRUMBLE" mindset the japanese have as an excuse for their brand of fascist government and law enforcement (99% conviction rates in court, that's some bull). Heaven forbid there be a hero anyone else look up to that's not them, or anyone else with any real power.

They added the cute little ballerina, a twisted character I didn't approve of but came to enjoy in PS5R. Then replaced her with an AI in this game. Disappointed.

It has been done in a way that doesn't mess with the original, lets you go back and enjoy some nostalgia and a different type of game play. I still greatly prefer the original. Dubbing/voices, and artwork are a great match for the original at least, and characters so far have been true to the source material.

I like being able to main as the other character in game play, but game play differs so much from the original and there's so much 'emptiness' to things like not being able to 'live' in the game and develop relationships naturally like in the other game. Also they did just write some other support characters out, and I miss having them around.

I'd almost have rather had an add on for PS5R, that expanded the phantom theives little den to include interactions and little slice of life stories so that it was like adding one of those story book games or "choose your own adventure' type books. The 'gameplay' is just janky and I havent figured out how to re key the controls into something sane that doesnt annoy me yet. TBH this is a game for either die hard fans or people clueless about PS5 that just like mind numbing mass slasher games. I feel something like Soul Worker or Diablo clones and hybrids would make people happier than this.

author: 8b643edd90a456e690c3528a59ca4cbd
content:
The Phantom Thieves are back! This is basically Persona 5 Part 2. Takes place a few months after the events of the Persona 5.

This game is not a turned based RPG like most of the other Persona games, instead it is a an action hack and slash JRPG. It takes a little getting use to, especially if you just played Persona 5, but I think it works well overall.

The cast and characters are like your old buddies you got to know in the previous game and still has that certain charm about it.

It's much shorter than Persona 5 at roughly half the play time, but I do feel that they cut out a lot of the useless time wasting stuff from Persona 5 and really streamlined the game. So overall I think this is fine.

It's not too difficult on normal difficulty and I think most players should easily be able to beat the game on that setting.

Only real complaint is on a 12 Gen Intel chip the game does not run correctly. I needed to change the game to run as high priority on my processor in order to stop the game from stuttering like crazy. Some people might run into this issue, in this case I recommend using a program like Process Lasso to set the game to always run with high priority.

author: bc5b166c60395a869795ac42fa84d94e
content:
(NO SPOILER REVIEW)

After completing the story playing New Game Plus on Merciless Difficulty and attaining all the achievements on the game i could clearly say that this has to be one of the greatest sequel games I have played so far. 

Coming out of playing Persona 5 Royal -> Persona 4 Golden -> Persona 3 Portable & FES this game felt like a breath of fresh air.
Going back to Shibuya as Joker seeing how the other phantom thieves are doing in life really felt like meeting your old friends again back in the day. And thats where this game shines it takes all of whats in persona 5s story and world building and adds upon it. Using the same rules not breaking it but also adds upon it to the point that it feels natural is one of the greatest ways to make a sequel. Another thing that I enjoyed is the dialogue of each characters every single dialogue didn't feel out of place, every line of each character has meaning, each banter among all of the characters is nothing but entertaining to watch (props to the voice actors as they did a phenomenal job never in my entire life have i heard such great voice acting their performance in P5R was great but this was a major step up). 

Overall 10/10 for writing and direction 

Gameplay wise it is similar to a warriors game but may it not stop you from actually trying the game out the combat is smooth and the combos are satisfying to pull off and are greatly animated. Each character are uniquely made to suite every play style and not one character was ever useless or unplayable. Gameplay loop of smashing buttons is fun as heck.

Overall 10/10 for Gameplay 

Now on the the graphics and animation, it may be in a different game engine and was made by a different team but the graphics and animation never fell off furthermore it feels more of an upgrade at times. So in short if you love the original Persona 5 aesthetic you will love it all the same with this game

10/10

Now music. 
Its a no brainer 10/10 
Lynn went ham with the signing remaking most of the songs from the original persona 5 and making them into rock was a move no one expected but everyone enjoyed. From past music to new music everything on this games track was banger after banger never disappoints.

Addition to what i said about the writing of the game all the new characters mesh well with the phantom thieves group and are all well made.

The only con I have with this game is that after finishing and experiencing it means less persona games i have left until persona 6 or another persona 5 spin off is released.

author: 80b69f5e621457dcba36bf4f3086515e
content: “Strikers” has the “Persona 5” (P5) DNA all over it. The Persona universe and P5 characters are nicely used and new memorable faces join the action. It all makes the game feel like a true sequel! The “musou” action genre works great too, implementing Persona-like elements for even better. Nonetheless, it can get repetitive, so I’d advise playing in short sessions. The only thing I didn’t like -at all- is the “jails” (dungeons) music. It feels off! And left me wishing there was an option to change it, as there is with battle music. Also, no gallery to watch images or cutscenes nor new game+, bummer! In the technical aspect, I had a problem where pre-rendered videos would stutter for the first seconds, delating the game was loading in the background. Also, a crash that costed me hours of progress (no auto-save! Which doesn’t make sense, as the game doesn’t have branching paths or anything alike). That said, I would sincerely recommend “Strikers” to any P5 fan. It will help with the post-game depression the original leaves you with and present new amazing (canon) situations for you to enjoy! Just don’t expect the “depth” a traditional Persona game can have.

author: 4ba95fd977ff54ffbc3b6ded12a80e53
content:
I was really looking forward to having more of the P5 cast, but Strikers is way too unfocused to be enjoyable. 

I initially thought Strikers was going to be a more action oriented take on the Persona formula and im aware that it was drawing inspiration from Dynasty Warriors type of games. The movement and combat itself feels very clunky. Mid-PS2 era clunky, those years where devs were still grappling with having a lot more freedom of movement in 3d space and better tech to support it. They also didnt blend mechanics or gameplay styles, theyve simply jammed them into the same area. Imagine a Dynasty Warriors game, but now  take every single mechanic from P5 and layer it on top. It's too much to handle and it doesnt feel good.

The smaller mob encounters are also over way too fast for you to get comfortable with the combat, which means by the time you get to a boss you have no idea what youre doing. All in all its a very sloppy execution of a cool concept.

author: e6b47d0587f751fc94deb4673c4beba6
content:
As someone who loved Persona 5, I'd love to recommend this game and I can tell that a lot of effort was put into its development on its original console systems. However, the PC port is a stuttering, lag-filled mess, even several years after the steam release. It's playable, but frustrating for an action game. Its combat is also somewhat questionable. It tries to marry the "ambush and start a fight" mechanic of a JRPG into a dynasty-warriors-style combat system. The result is squishing a chaotic number of opponents into a tiny combat arena while simultaneously removing the strategic map-management elements normally present in this genre.

Although I appreciate the effort at innovation, this just didn't quite work for me. I'd still probably appreciate the overall game if it played better despite disagreeing with some of its design decisions, but no amount of polish in flavor/style can make up for the poor performance of the game itself.

author: 23fb3e98af645164b5ed4f5c335d1a44
content:
This game is a solid sequel to persona 5, and anybody that enjoyed that game should definitely play this one. It can be a little brain dead at points, but the combats pretty fun (for the most part). Every character (except Morgana) has a fun, if just a little too similar move-set I enjoyed playing and learning. I think Makoto, Haru, and Ryuji were my favourites. The road-trip story is solid, and has some great character moments for all of the phantom thieves, except like Morgana or Futaba (rip) from what I remember (Finally, justice for Haru). Most of the new characters are also great. I love Zenkichi SO MUCH. Even outside of all that, Ryuji gets to say fuck, so the game is automatically a 10/10.

HOWEVER
The game has some MASSIVE problems.

First and foremost, the PC port is absolutely TERRIBLE. The game constantly stutters to the point of being unplayable. Seriously, I couldn't even get past the first goddamn cutscene when I first tried to play. I had to download an external program called process lasso to get the game to even work properly. The game is also capped at 60 FPS, which isn't the biggest deal, but I found it can quite easily drop below that when things get hectic. Even on hardware which far exceeds the recommended specs. While I'm sure it was a pain the the ass recreating Persona 5's trademark look on a completely different engine, the anti-aliasing makes the game look pretty terrible. But luckily, this can be pretty easily fixed with the few settings tweeks. I also got caught in an infinite loading screen at one point, which was is always my FAVOURITE feature in any game.

Unfortunately the problems don't stop with just the poor porting job. While I liked a good amount of the story bosses (final boss excluded), a good amount of them have WAY too much health. I played on hard so I'm not sure how it is on lower difficulties, but I feel like most bosses ended up outstaying their welcome. I remember one of the optional bosses took me about 20 minutes straight to beat, all while having no extra challenge outside of the time commitment. Also, once I figured out spamming the square + square + triangle combo was BY FAR the most efficient way of playing the game, the combat became far less fun for me. Those are my main issues, but there's a few other issues I have with the combat, like all out attacks feel incredibly under powered, and the camera being pretty janky. The side quest also kinda suck, which is pretty disappointing for a franchise like Persona, where the side content has been one of it's major draws since Persona 3.

The persona fusion system in this game is also a hot pile of ASS. For some god forsaken reason you need to have high level early game persona for some of the later fusion. This would either take millions of yen of buying and deleting high level personas over and over again, or literal HOURS of grinding. I have no clue who approved this change, but they should be very careful on August 17th 2038 at 7:43 AM.

Overall, I still think strikers is a worthwhile sequel to Persona 5, and I would still recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the original. BUT, there are some big problems that hold this game back from being truly great.

content: This game is so much better than I though it would be. I thought it was going to be like Dragon Quest Heroes where wave after wave of enemies attack you. I can tell the developers were trying to keep the battle system closest to Persona 5 as possible while changing the turn based element. I feel they did a good job. author: 9df1d8d1f4285d2b89fd114b48c428b4
content: I've played this game on Nintendo Switch at launch and it was the first close to mainline persona game I was able to play (at the time I think I had only played parts of Persona Q and Persona Q 2). It's actually a really good introduction to how persona games work, you have deadlines and side tasks, but it's simplified compared to the main games so you don't have to balance 20 social links, upgrading your stats, dungeon crawling, and playing the main story. Yes, it is super barebones in comparison but it's actually a good way to get used to the system without getting overwhelmed. Before I played this I had watched playthroughs of Persona 3, Persona 5, and either Persona 4 Golden or Persona 4, so I was used to the mechanics. This was a great intro to the system for me before I got Persona 4 Golden, though to be fair I think Persona 4 Golden is simplier than Persona 5 Royal which overwhelmed me a little my first playthrough. There is one main issue with the steam version I have noticed. It buffers a lot. I'll be playing and my screen freezes or is delayed a ton. Sometimes it works out after I mess with setting, but other times not which is why I haven't put more time into this version when my Switch copy has like thirty or so hours of gameplay. It can't be my computer because Persona 5 Royal and Persona 4 Golden have no issues running on it. Overall a really good game that serves as a fantastic intro to the game series, excluding the whole minor spoilers to Persona 5 part.

author: 300963db3c2a545995ed394c652d82d2
content:
Although Persona 5 Strikers had been available on PC for a long time, because [b]just minutes inside this title would be enough to spoil most of Persona 5[/b], I saved it until after I could experience Royal.

Credit is due to the developers for their ability to recreate Persona 5 in a different engine and genre. If I didn't know otherwise, I would have assumed it was the original team behind this spin-off. [b]Every step of the way I could feel the love put into this game.[/b] Starting from the story to gameplay and the new music tracks which will enter my playlists!

[b]The story[/b] of Strikers is a lot simpler, while captivating. Whereas in the original you obtain new companions and help them through their hardships, this is a bit less connected to the cast of the game. Compared to the original very black-and-white story with clear villains and heroes, Strikers is a morally greyer story with a unique outlook on its villains. 
It's worth noting that although Strikers is technically a sequel to Persona 5, [b]the events of Royal are never mentioned[/b], but they are not incompatible on a story level.
Although justified, sadly the player doesn't get to keep the powers from the original title.

[b]Gone is the turn-based combat, replaced with a new action-based combat system[/b], and, while it's wildly different genres, the combat feels very familiar.
[b]The game is a musou[/b], which literally translates to "unmatched" and the main focus of this genre is cutting through hundreds of enemies that are nowhere near your level.  Because of my interest in the characters I went into it knowing it was not necessarily my cup of tea. Regardless, I can see it's one of the best musous out there, with all the faults that might come with the genre.
[b]This makes fighting fun, but repetitive[/b], especially with the smaller enemies. Because this game is still a Persona, [b]in-between fights there's a lot of story dialogue demanding your attention after waves and waves of enemies that don't[/b]. This is followed by the very peculiar choice of having the first 3 dungeons of the game be almost copy-pasted, only to add all the variety towards the end of the game. 

When it comes to [b]exploration[/b], compared to the other Personas, [b]this is an extremely linear title [/b]that leaves little to no freedom to the player. The gameplay loop consists of going through cutscenes or brain-dead-ly cutting through waves of enemies when exploring a dungeon that often follows a very specific progression pattern. Rarely it's possible to explore the city and move freely, which would really be just a jog around stores to see if something interesting is for sale. 
While the game is more linear, one very positive note compared to the original is that [b]almost all dialogues are dubbed[/b]. Because there were physically fewer dialogues, more could be voice-acted.

The title suffers a bit from all this repetition in my opinion, but it definitely ramped up in the second half keeping me hooked!

Just like in the original, [b]Requests are back, but[/b] because of the absence of Mementos, [b]it's only fetch quests that instead of adding to the experience, gatekeep abilities and whatnot behind their completion.[/b]

[b]The difficulty[/b] was also a weak point for me, because as it often happens in these titles, [b]it's just numbers, making the fights longer instead of more challenging.[/b]

To me, [b]Strikers was like when your favorite anime releases a filler movie that doesn't really add anything, but it's still more of the thing you like.[/b] It's a delightful, post-main story of the original, adventure with all the characters I grew to love.  
After reading all this, if you're still convinced to get it, go ahead. The small repetition in gameplay won't wipe out the charm and a story worth the Persona name!

[b]6.5/10[/b]

author: d7509fcfa2a956d092f3814b45d7af9e
content: The combat, music, characters, story, and overall gameplay is extremely enjoyable. The combat is so fun, I want it in future Persona titles. The combat's breathtaking and it's real fun combined with the banger music. However, the game is extremely unoptimized for PCs. The UI elements and texts are extremely blurry (even with anti-aliasing disabled), and it really took me out at the beginning. I got used to it to the point where I could play the game without being too annoyed, but it certainly doesn't feel like enough attention has been put into those aspects of the game, compared to P5R absolutely nailing them, where the game looks gorgeous at every turn. And the performance is pretty inconsistent as well, despite the game being locked to 60fps unlike P5R running flawlessly at 120fps. There are occasional frame drops and stutters, which I don't think should be happening with an i7-12700K and a 3080. And the camera feels weird to control with a mouse (but it's fine with a controller), where it was perfect on P5R with both mouse and a controller, which makes me think they just upscaled the Switch version of the game, leading to unoptimized camera and blurry UI elements. The game is still extremely fun nonetheless, it feels like a lot of care has gone into the music and overall gameplay (along with other things I praised), which is ultimately more important than minor optimization issues, but I'd like the issues to be fixed at the same time, so I can truly feel happy and satisfied playing this game :D
