author: fe9dafd1f9565d88955c03869f734e36
content:
Absolutely loved it. It didn't outstay its welcome at all, despite twist-after-twist, even though that is sort of expected with Persona games now. The combat feels more fluid and engaging to me and doesn't burn me out in the same way the turn based combat would, the faster pace is very much welcome for me. Overall, I enjoy the combat more in P5S than the original. It feels very much like P5, though, carrying over every mechanic from that game -- on the combat side of things, anyway.

Story and progression has been streamlined. There's no time management aspect to it anymore, and no social links. 

Whaaaat?! But those make Persona games great! Maybe. But I never felt like it was lacking, going through just the story of it. In fact, I appreciated it, because it severely reduced the feeling of *bloat* that was so evident in P5. The pacing is better. But the game is still very dialogue heavy, with some serious moments, emotional moments, and laid back moments, with the crew just hanging out. It was great.

In other Persona games, I've never really had the urge to go in for a New Game Plus, or post game content, but here - I still have the drive to play, after finishing the story. Much of this is due to the more streamlined nature of the story and progression, but more than that, it's because I find the combat much more enjoyable.

author: 5e9cd24c1e9f562da9cd4f1884a3ec22
content:
This is a fantastic sequel to P5, and it made me understand the fun that warriors-style games provide.
The gameplay is so fun. They managed to implement many features from the previous game in a way that just works in a super satisfying way with the Warriors-style gameplay it has. I enjoyed it so much that I ended up doing every single possible battle challenge the game gave me and I loved all of them.
In regards to the story, I generally LOVED seeing the interactions with each other that the Phantom Thieves had during this long trip through the whole country, it gives a lot more depth to their bonds as friends, but... There are some scenes I would do without in it, though. If you have played this game, you'll probably know which ones I'm talking about. 
The new characters are also really well written and fun, Zenkichi is definitely my favourite in the whole game, honestly.
I had so much fun with this game that I ended up replaying it all over again on the highest difficulty, and still had a blast with it. It's that good.

author: 17c8aebd1e1b5e6a8d10149ea50c0e39
content:
This game is a very bizzare mix of P5's original mechanics and a hack n/ slash ARPG style game. 

The core problem that feeds into all the other issues I'm about to mention is that Strikers carries over ALL of the mechanics from P5, including baton passes, skills, elemental affinities, all out attacks, etc. This is way too many mechanics to juggle all at once while fighting enemies in real time. All of that stuff worked in P5 because it was a turn based game. But here, you're fumbling with the controls to desperately do the thing you need to do before you get killed. This process isn't helped by how awkward the control layout is, which to be fair, isn't a design issue, its a result of having so many more key assignments than you'd normally have in an ARPG. Sure, you can reassign them, but that doesn't help with there being way too many RPG-like mechanics in the first place. I suspect no layout could possibly make this mess feel intuitive. 

At the same, the game seems to be critically lacking basic features common to ARPGs: blocking, for instance. I also found out only after dying over and over again that while there is a dodge button, it is too awkward to use reliably (its H, try pressing that repeatedly while keeping your fingers on the standard WASD!) It also doesn't seem to stop the enemies from hitting you with skills, the only way to interrupt them being to down them with their weakness. 

Which isn't a reliable strategy because...you only get enough SP to use skills a few times during each infiltration. Since the red powerful shadow mechanic returns, this basically means you have to avoid those guys entirely. They're minibosses with massive HP sponges that take forever to kill if you can't beat their weakness. And even if you can, it drains all your SP. But don't try saving your SP either, because just sitting there mashing attack will get you killed by their repeated bombardment of undogeable skills before you have a chance to even dent their HP pool. Using non-weakness breaking skills also doesn't help, since they barely do enough damage to dent their HP pool either. 

So what you get at the end of all of this is a system that combines the worst of both worlds. You have the really shallow elemental weakness system that makes fights a cakewalk if you have the right skill, and impossible if you don't. You have to manage it at high speed while fighting in real time, but no simplified moveset that compliments this speed. 

You could try to coast by using the gun and basic attack, but those are really the only ARPG elements and they aren't very effective or deep because the bulk of the game is balanced around the RPG stuff carried over from P5. For instance, all you're really doing if you're not using skills is literally just mashing left mouse button over and over again. There is no timing mechanic, or having to vary your attacks, parry, etc...in other words, the basic fundamentals of an ARPG. Its all automated. 

Also, the screen is way too visually cluttered to even see what is going on or react to enemies properly. It made me really annoyed with the anime art style because sometimes I couldn't even see when an enemy is "down" and open for an all out attack because there were too many ridiculously flashy effects happening on the screen at once.

The story seems like it could be decent, but without breaking it into segments where you can control what you do each day, the game feels very streamlined and gives the player even less agency. The time management is the main thing that makes Persona games feel sorta like real RPGs in the first place, so without that, I just found myself lacking any kind of investment in the story. 

Skip this one. Its a JRPG half-assed into a clunky ARPG that doesn't get the high points of either genre correct, and simply re-hashes the main themes and characters of a much longer game.

author: bd45363019a250338cd8ebfbeeef2c4c
content:
I had this game on Switch and absolutely loved it. So when Black Friday rolled about and this game is also on sale, I just have to get it for my Steam Deck. Officially, it's not Steam Deck verified as of yet, but there are some tweaks I did that enabled it playable on Deck, but not without a few technical issues. The audio for one is missing from cutscenes when I play on my Deck. 

Otherwise, game runs perfectly fine.

Onto the game, story-wise:

This is technically a sequel to Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal, so if you hadn't played that game, you would be completely lost on the plot. It revolves around the Phantom Thieves, with it taking place nearly a year after the events of P5/P5R, with Joker returning to the town once more to meet up with his friends, and with Morgana in tow. However, they then stumbled across another alternate verse in a highly popular new app that had been making it's rounds, with certain individuals making use of this alternate verse.

Unlike P5R however, the 'villains' in this sequel aren't outright 'evil people'. They are still misguided individuals, and need a good dose of reality. But honestly, I prefer them a lot more than the villains in P5R. This game is also a very 'coming-of-age game'. If the prequel focuses only on one town and one area, this game actually has the group travelling across Japan.

Essentially a hack and slash game instead of the turn based combat in the previous game, the game still kept the basics of sneaking around and ambushing enemies. Dungeons however are easier than the original.

Hoping Valve soon verify the game for Steam Deck though. I really want to play it on my Steam Deck.

author: adeb3656b12c5098adf1833c1cd38f1c
content:
[Much of my time was idle. A full playthrough is probably around 35-50 hours active time.]

I absolutely love Persona 5 + Royal and was glad to experience more of the narrative, which wasn't as good as the original with less personal growth among the player characters and less interesting early game villains, but still quite decent. In some sense it was also nice that it was a faster experience. But the combat gameplay just felt so terrible: Slow, cumbersome and frustrating.

It seems like there might be a lot of depth there if I had engaged more with it, but it just struck me as time consuming and not very worthwhile. I've had an excellent time both in original Persona combat and in fighting games such as Monster Hunter where I've soloed most hardmodes, but here the fighting just seemed very much not worth the effort, and fundamentally incompatible with the deep menu systems and skill usages from the Persona backbone. There were so many abilities and nuances that I'd have cared about in turn-based that just felt unimpactful or a waste of time in this system. For the first time I turned a game to easy and breezed through most of it. That made it a pretty decent visual novel but meant that anything to do with stats, fusions, gear, skills and attributes was pretty much meaningless and left the experience lackluster with major pacing issues. But before I did that, my experience with the game was a great deal worse.

content:
A decent spin off game. 
Fun combat, but other then that it felt like a roblox version of persona 5.
The story was a drag up until the end. Characters didn't feel like the ones you got to know from p5, but cheap copies instead. It was very off putting at first. Everything they say feels wrong. Yusuke was the worst when it came to writing. It's obvious that the writers who worked on persona 5 strikers don't understand what made yusuke funny and special. He has 0 moments in this game. He says something autistic then his part is done. 
Had the game been mostly combat and gameplay this wouldn't really matter. But since there is so much talking, it becomes very hard to overlook. 
If you haven't played persona 5 this is probably a pretty interesting game.
But I feel like this game would have been better off not being a persona 5 spin off. The core of the gameplay is fun. The writing could actually work if it the characters weren't already established. 

Mostly recommend the game for it's combat/systems and end of story moments

author: 63be9312d5405badb434118f868f5155
content:
My honest review after clearing the game at 87 hours, not including post game. (1st playthrough)

1. Gameplay
A wonderful spin-off from the persona series set in the world of persona 5 with a unique twist on the dynasty warriors style. Hack n slash style of gameplay combined with mid fight persona switches and party member tagging. There are also interactable overworld objects that provide cover or grant their own attack options, allowing for different gameplay styles. In addition to persona abilities, all out attack returns and the mechanic of showtime changes up attack combinations and makes for a satisfying playthrough. 

2. Story
Even coming out of Persona 5 Royal with high expectations, Persona 5 Strikers has managed to prove itself to be a worthy sequel in its own right. The journey around Japan on a roadtrip feel so nostalgic and heartwarming. The plot is also a fair continuation to the original Persona 5 with its own twists in its story. As a game focused on battle gameplay and less on story, it manages to do its job well. 

3. Characters
The return of the Phantom Thieves starts off back at LeBlanc, a heartwarming reunion which brings back memories. The new Phantom Thieves also integrate themselves well into the team, enhancing the story further. The character development arcs of the new characters are great and being able to control each Phantom Thief individually plays perfectly into the immersion. 

4. Graphics
The overworld is amazing, using the same style as Persona 5 Royal. Each city is different from the next and really takes you on a tour around Japan. The new dungeons are fabulous, each having their own distinct features from those that mimic the real world to fantasy worlds. Attack and movement animations are fluid too. Persona 5 Strikers is without a doubt, visually stunning.

5. Audio
The OST in this game is once again, truly phenomenal, I had my doubts that it would come close to Persona 5 Royal, but considering how high the bar is, Strikers has done it. The electric remixes of returning Persona 5 OSTs are fantastic, fitting for the faster game pace of Strikers. Not forgetting the new tracks too, the first Jail's soundtrack was such a hook and made way for all the bangers in the OST, down to the final boss fight. 

6. Technical
Game is bug free and is buttery smooth, not a single crash throughout my playthrough. Load times are short as well.

7. Value
100% buy, bang for every buck, DLCs included! Even though this style of game isnt my preferred and it took a while to get used to, I loved every bit of it and have 0 regrets. 

Persona 5 Strikers offers more replayability compared to Persona 5 Royal and I can't wait to get back in to NG+ after clearing the post game. Fingers crossed that more Phantom Thieves content is on the horizon, as I have come to love the series so much, cmon Atlus make the dream come true.

author: 8052bfe2d7ea5c24a69e0a6d41a2b84b
content:
Cool spin-off for Persona 5. A nice roadtrip throughout Japan with all your friends to make some more memories and defeat evil gods (again), sadly romance options dont carry over, most characters except the main characters from 5 are missing and no Royal characters/content either.
Not the biggest fan of the combat either, its action-heavy and fast paced, but I prefer the normal turn-based combat. In this game it sometimes can get very chaotic with the dozens of enemies around you and abilites filling the whole screen, and a lot of the time you just button mash your way through hordes of enemies to victory, other than that its fine.
The game and therefore the story itself are shorter than the main game, which is to be expected, but because of that some story beats and especially the (main)antagonists are very surface-level and bland at times.
The  music, voice acting and visuals are all up to par with Persona 5 and the game also features some new tracks.

author: cf7234b3edc255cb98fb9d33d7d7cc13
content:
As spin-offs go Persona Strikers is superb! If anything it comes off more as an expansion pack of old. In other words,it picks off right where P5 left off whilst dealing with similar paranormal,psychological,and societal issues.

As a musou fan I love the action based combat but in trying to adopt mechanics from P5's systems it excels in certain areas and falters in others. This time you have to be much more aware of enemy weaknesses with certain more formidable foes requiring you break their defenses before you can prod at their soft tender underbellies with your attacks.

 Additionally there's a clumsy attempt at "stealth" and "surprise ambushing" that frankly does not carry over well for this kind of genre. Imagine Devil Mat Cry 5 having aspects of Metal-Gear randomly thrown in just for the heck of it. It would make for a rather disjointed stop and go affair wouldn't it? The same applies with Persona Strikers. "Fortunately" future unlockable abilities begin to circumvent this problem and everything else from the exploration to the boss-fights is still platinum mint!

The story-telling,character interactions,and sound-track also deserve praise with even the new characters fitting in as opposed to sticking out like sore thumbs.

Well,"mostly". We finally get an adult persona user thrown into the mix but because he's a cop and initially has ulterior motives the main characters constantly dog on him by calling him gramps. Instead of handling the roasting stoically with a wry smile he whines about it incessantly. You know that meme "How do you do,fellow kids?". That's  Zenkichi in a nut-shell! Fortunately he eventually moves beyond this annoying first impression by revealing himself to be a more likable person later on. (Thank goodness)

As for Sophia? I have no problems with her what so ever. Persona 3 already presented the idea of having artificially intelligent robot companions with Aigis so Sophia being an "ap" that can manifest a more physical form in the meta-verse makes perfect sense within this continuity. She manages to be innocent and curious yet learns quickly whilst always being helpful.
 
I also appreciate how Strikers seems more about helping flawed people towards their personal redemption arcs and forgiving them as opposed to simply pursuing them as the bad guys then destroying their livelihoods. Don't misunderstand me,the antagonists in Strikers are still formidable adversaries. It's just this time we get to see the more positive application of "stealing hearts" expanded upon similar to how it was used to save Futaba and Sae Niijima.

Yet there is an underlying problem with "Modern Persona" that permeates Strikers as well. That being that the mundane socializing aspect which is wonderful for character building also undermines the high stakes of the over all meta-plot.

To me Persona is still apart of the Mega-Ten/Shin-Megami-Tensei brand. That means gods,goddesses,and other mythological beings are "real". There are dark uncaring cosmic forces from neighboring dimensions that creep their tendrils into our world to usher forth Armageddon. The only reason we are still here is because the heroes and heroines in these ongoing titles reset reality every so often to ensure humanity as a whole will continue to survive.

But hey,gotta go to the bad-bad bathhouse with the boys,amirite? Gotta throw some darts,exchange "gamur speak" with Futaba, or sing some karaoke to ensure the fans can  immerse themselves in the "totes believable" post-modern-pop-culture setting!  Again,I don't want to come off as a grouch. When I first played through Persona 3 and Persona 4 I really did appreciate the social-bonding system as I grew to truly care about even a few of the more insignificant side-npcs. "But" when you go about mundane routines within an environment that is not remotely surreal or remotely frightening the whole "We're under-dogs fighting scary apocalyptic deities in a cosmic horror setting" part of the SMT formula is watered down significantly.
     
Strikers does not have as much of this normie-simulation-filler as its' predecessor "but" there is still a lot of dialogue and down time compared to the typical musou outing. No doubt certain people will appreciate this but others will forget they are fighting with dark-forces from beyond the pale as the road-trip-monotony sets in. Strikers would have benefited from a greater sense of urgency. (Same with P5 as well.)  

Now back to the good news! Persona fusions,leveling up,unlockable bond bonuses,and acquiring increasingly better equipment sets are still present. Better yet,you can take control of EVERY Phantom Thief directly. (Save for Futaba and that's a pity. Oh well. She served as the oracle in P5 so it makes sense she's relegated to the roles of hacking and support! I still see it as a missed opportunity though.)

Of all the spin off Persona games I rate "Strikers" as the best one thus far even if the transition from turn-based rpg to action combat did not go off entirely smoothly without a hitch. 

Pros

+The combat,press-turn-system,fusions,and Persona spell-casting carried over surprsingly well into the hack n slash/beat em up format!

+A decent continuation that expands upon the concepts presented in its' predecessor.

+ New characters fit in with the rest of the cast.

+Good soundtrack coupled with the VAs doing a servicible job in their respective roles.

+The exploration and platforming break up the monotony of the battles.

+Objects in the environment can be exploited to give you a more direct advantage during fights.

+Good message about forgiveness and having empathy for others.

Cons

-Cannot decide if it is a lighthearted road-trip OVA or a tense paranormal/supernatural/mystery thriller.

-Dialogue and down-time between missions can be very dense,especially if you compare Strikers to other musou games. 

- The stealth and "surprise attack " mechanics that complimented the dungeon/palace infiltration in Persona 5 come off as a hindrance in Strikers. 

-RPG inspired roots ensure there is an intense level of grinding. No,it's not as bad as a gacha game but be ready to commit regardless!

-Where's Katsumi?

-Would have been rad if Goro Akechi made a guest appearance. Oh well,perhaps next time!

author: 7eb6bc3760f15b8aa5c0cc9a3a86ec52
content:
Just to get it out of the way, if you're expecting an experience that even holds a candle to royal in any way, shape or form, you're going to be severely let down. P5S is basically just a story expansion pack in terms of its narrative, and retreading old ground is the name of the game. To the point where [spoiler] All the antagonists are just copies of the palace rulers with very slight tweaks, and the main antagonist is literally a somehow worse version of Yaldabaoth, right down to her design. The entire endgame is nearly identical to vanilla p5's: Go through not-mementos to kill not-holy grail to stop a false god devoid of humanity who is attempting to mind control all of mankind because they don't want free will anymore. It's such a step down from Maruki in every way that it enters freefall. [/spoiler]

The music is still mostly bangers and remixes of bangers, but the normal battle themes, while far from bad, do not even come close to 'take over' or 'last surprise'.

The gameplay is button mashy, but that's to be expected of a warriors style game. When the combat is fun, it's quite satisfying to pull some crazy move and kill 50 enemies at once. But when it's not fun, you'll be mindlessly hacking at the shins of a massive damage sponge while it one-shots you with every attack.

But the gameplay isn't what you come to this game for, you come to P5S to spend more time with the characters you love, and the game does a serviceable job giving the phantom thieves plenty more funny and heartfelt moments with each other. Unfortunately though, the game doesn't include any confidants other than the main group, and assumes that you spent valentine's day with Ryuji, meaning that there is very little actual continuation from the original game. Not only that, Yoshizawa doesn't even exist in this game's timeline, as for some baffling reason it was made as a sequel to vanilla P5 and lacks all of the story beats and characters introduced in Royal. The story barely even mentions the events of the original game, and when it does they're often throwaway bits of banter or a single dialogue option that elicits the same response as the other choices.

The side content SUCKS. Every single request you can get is either a mindless fetch quest in the overworld (without the ability to sprint) or agonisingly boring backtracking to levels you've already cleared. Go to this level and kill this specific enemy that only appears in this one location that's annoying to get to, then kill this specific enemy BUT with a specific character, AND THEN [spoiler] go back and kill the boss of a previous level again with no changes whatsoever. [/spoiler] It's padding at its most egregious, and it straight up locks gameplay perks behind it, making some of them pretty much mandatory.

The voice acting is way lower quality than in P5 or Royal, which is bizarre since the Va's sound identical to their 2016 selves in the latter. They either were given bad direction or the dev team went with bad takes, and it can be a bit distracting coming fresh off Royal. (Seriously Futaba sounds like she's drunk half the time and Ryuji's voice cracks every other word.)

Massive nit pick as the cherry on top: the menus have these cute little animations to them that are cool at first, but become agonising when you're just trying to get through the menus quickly and have to wait for the animations to play out before you can do whatever you're trying to do. Also, a r e y o u d o u b l e c h e c k i n g t h e r e q u e s t??

If there's a sale going on and you're a die-hard lover of these characters and this world like me, this game can be worth it for just a few more hours with the phantom thieves. But if you're expecting it to be an improvement or proper continuation to literally anything from its forebear, you'll be sorely let down.

author: 4ea7640a317b515b93b76b31eda003cc
content:
Positive experience overall, but I wouldn't pay much more than 30 bucks for this.

First of, there's basically absolutely no way I can recommend this if you haven't played p5 or p5r. A significant amount of the enjoyment I got from the game comes from watching the Phantom Thieves reunite and mess around in their tour around Japan and Jails(This game's version of Palaces). Playing around on a beach, visiting landmarks, tasting local cuisine; the characters having fun is pretty fun to watch.  Some of the characters even get some additional characterization which can range from meh to decent. 

Other than that? Zenkichi and Sophia are likeable additions to the team. Their respective character arcs couldn't be more predictable, but they at least get decent pay offs. It also helps that they have colourful enough personalities and designs which blend in surprisingly well with the rest of the phantom thieves.

The combat is also pretty decent, though it can get draggy if you don't make use of your skills to hasten through certain fights. 

There are more negatives. The story rehashes a lot of elements from the original game's story, except most of the climatic moments didn't have the build up and pacing leading up to them to make said moments especially emotional. Conceptually, it had a lot of potential. It was just executed rather poorly. Has a few cool moments though. 

Most of the sidequests are so boring I wonder why they're there in the first place. 
"Kill X Number of Y Mob with Z Character" 
"Collect X Number of Y Item Drop"
"Revisit a boss and kill it a second time"

That's about it really. The only thing that I can add on is that it maintains the visual flare from the original p5. All in all, it was fun and I'm glad I played it, but the game is riddled with some serious issues that makes it difficult to recommend at it's original price tag. Not to mention it's only like 20-30 hours.

author: a526dc33af435d15b5a73c957389d143
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a spin-off set after the events of Persona 5 featuring most of the Phantom Thieves, developed in tandem with Omega Force and with significantly different gameplay to mainline Persona games.

I think that the gameplay differences are ultimately a good thing because turn-based combat, as good as it is in P5, gets boring eventually so the mix-up is appreciated here. The combat is fast-paced and can be engaging, however personally it's not ideal. Whilst I like character action and hack and slash games, P5S is essentially dynasty warriors with a persona skin, and I have some issues with that.

The hordes of enemies the game throws at you regularly make it very difficult to see what is actually happening on screen, and it doesn't feel like player skill is all that important in the grand scheme of things, rather most battles are just stat checks or a test of how long your patience will last against a bullet sponge. Fortunately, the effects look pretty decent and the music is fantastic as usual - so things don't get too boring.

In terms of story, P5S does some things well; the story is fairly interesting towards the middle-end, it's nice to see more of some of the Phantom Thieves and Zenkichi is a great character addition (he reminds me how much I would love a future persona game to feature a largely adult cast). But there are also a few failings; I think the story is too similar to themes that have already been explored in Persona 5 and Royal, and for the first half-or-so of the game it is far too formulaic in it's story-telling. Ultimately, it's quite predictable, which would be fine if things weren't presented as 'twists'.

I also have to say I was a bit disappointed by the absence of most of the characters that were in Persona 5 and Royal, and I feel that although it's set after Persona 5 it doesn't feel like it's a true sequel to the story.

And one final note because this was definitely the most annoying thing throughout my playthrough... The menus look great and all but they play so many animations when switching between menus that it significantly slows down navigating them, I also found the animation that plays when entering and exiting jails is too long when you're encouraged to go in and out often. Maybe it's a bit of a nitpick but for a fast-paced action game like this, the fact that the menus are way more cumbersome to navigate than the ones in P5 gets very frustrating very quickly, especially when you forget you're not controlling Joker so you can't swap out the character you're controlling in the menu.

All-in-all, it's a nice addition to the Phantom Thieves story which has a reasonable completion time, so I recommend it if you liked Persona 5 and want to see more of the main characters.

author: 150d107a21605cc3bb5381448c01e853
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a bit of an oddball. It's a canon spin-off that assumes you played the base game, but it omits details from Royal. It’s also a Musō game with surprising complexity and the smallest scale battles in the genre. 

It’s not uncommon for Persona games to have weak beginnings and Strikers is no exception. Players are inundated with lousy tutorials and gameplay-interrupting cutscenes. It’s no wonder there are numerous negative reviews complaining about the supposed difficulty of the game. To put it as inelegantly as possible: unless those reviewers were playing on Merciless, this is a colossal example of a skill issue. While the tutorial is mediocre, the onus is on the player to use every tool in the game to succeed. Once you acquire the Master Arts for each Phantom Thief, the gameplay is like flowing water. Chaining special attacks and Persona skills into All-Out attacks feels great, and there are further opportunities for skill expression. Late-game bosses can be cut down like a knife through butter by remotely competent players.

There isn't much to discuss about Strikers' story, it's more Persona 5. While the story arcs are similar and many of the villains are laughably one-dimensional, Strikers shines with its upbeat charm and flashy aesthetic. Just don’t go in with hopes of a villain on par with Maruki, you’ll be disappointed. 

Strikers has a few remaining flaws. There are frame drops during cutscenes. The tension and pacing of dungeons are nonexistent since you can leave and return with full HP and SP. Ambushing Shadows is less precise than Persona 5. There's no “register all” button for the Velvet Room, and the way you purchase equipment in Sophie’s shop is unnecessarily inefficient, which is baffling considering Persona 5 solved this issue back in 2016. If you can overlook this, the game is a fine but flawed sequel.

author: acf81452e5f7597ab6549043e5165198
content:
controls are a little wonky but the innovation is there. Gameplay so far encourages you to use all your party members and Joker's wild card in musou format seems to make good sense (i.e you can use free skills in your combo depending on the persona you have equiped).
Only issue is that theres alot to pay attention to so having a controller to slow down the game is a must. You could probably compare this game to ff11 / ff15 action strategy hybrid.

That said, i'm glad another action orientated game has been added to SMT. I've been wanting one since they stopped making Devil Summoner games.

In terms of story, they've flipped the script and the gang is exploring new territory this time around with social media being one of mediums for influencing 'cognition'.

------------------------------------------

Finished the game. Honestly glad i picked this up, a lot of the nit picks i had with P5R were tightened up in the gameplay this time around - i.e ambushing is slightly tricky and dangerous if you mess up - this makes it harder to keep alarms down to continue exploring. I would also stress again, the game makes it viable for you to play as everyone so you're not going to find yourself in a Tales situation where you can just play the game as your starting MC forever and call it a day. Overall a moderately challenging game that nudges you into trying new playing styles to keep it fresh. 

As for story it was serviceable. Nothing too over the top but the main draw is just touring around Japan with the crew. Haru is also given a lot more screen time this time around.

author: 7368e5ce98045206a0da036843ee889b
content:
First off, if you didn't play Persona 5, this game is not for you. There is a legitimate story in this game that extends beyond the standard musou spinoff plot of "all your favourite characters have been sucked into a non-canonical alternate universe". It assumes that you have played through P5 all the way to the end. As such, the rest of this review will contain spoilers for P5.

Persona 5 Strikers is honestly a very weird game to review. It is a musou or warriors-style game that tries to cram as many P5 mechanics into a musou game as possible, and the end result is a musou game that is utterly unique, though in a way that is likely to annoy many players who are approaching this game purely from the musou perspective. However, P5 fans will see these quirks as knowing references to the original game and appreciate them nonetheless, even if the game is somewhat jankier as a result.

Plot-wise, P5S picks up not long after the end of P5 (the base game, not the Royal ending). The phantom thieves meet up for summer vacation only to find that people are messing with the Metaverse once again even after they destroyed Mementos. This meddling has resulted in change-of-heart incidents all over Japan, which the police have decided to pin on the Phantom Thieves. Thus, the gang now has to go on a road trip all across Japan, solving Metaverse crimes and clearing their own name.

Overall, I'd say that the writing in P5S feels like a lighter but still authentic-feeling version of what we got in P5. One interesting angle that P5S takes is that while most of the Palace rulers in P5 are straight up irredeemable villains, all of the Jail monarchs (this game's version of the Metaverse) in P5S are sympathetic people who have been wronged in one way or another and got tempted to use the powers of the Metaverse to take revenge on society. Many of them have backstories that directly challenge the beliefs of the Phantom Thieves, causing them to question how right and just their actions are. Unfortunately, while these are interesting ideas, they do not have time to develop properly due to the much shorter length of P5S, both in terms of gameplay time and in-universe calendar days. While a typical Palace in P5 might consist of two weeks of investigating the backstory of the Palace ruler, two weeks given to infiltrate the palace and steal the treasure and another two weeks to see the fallout of the change of heart and how it affects everyone, in P5S you will typically discover a Jail, learn about the ruler's backstory, perform a change of heart and move on to the next city all in less than a week.

However, if there's one area where the writing of P5S really shines, it's in the cheerful and bubbly character interactions amongst the Phantom Thieves. If you enjoyed the many interactions between team members in P5 during the less serious moments, such as the beach day, the Hawaii trip and the cultural festival, P5S is a treasure trove of moments like that. After all, the premise of the game is a cross-country summer vacation road trip, and every new city they visit is an excuse for them to enjoy the local tourist attractions. If you're a Futaba or Haru fan especially, they have much more screentime in P5S than P5 because they're part of the starting roster right from the beginning.

In terms of battle mechanics, most of it is standard musou game fare. You have a light attack and a heavy attack, and combining them in various ways leads to various combos that have various effects like air launchers and crowd control. Every playable character also has a unique mechanic associated with them. For example, Ann can infuse her whip with fire so that her normal attacks also deal fire damage, and Ryuji can activate a stance that increases his defense and knockback resistance. The unique mechanic that P5S brings compared to other musou games is the return of elemental weaknesses and resistances from P5. You can deal elemental damage by either spending SP to cast Persona abilities as AOE damage effects, or by using certain attack combo paths that naturally end with your character summoning their Persona without using SP. Hitting a regular enemy with an elemental weakness will trigger a small all-out attack which damages all enemies in the area, while minibosses and bosses have shield icons that must be broken with elemental attacks. Breaking a single shield will lead to a one-more attack which is a bit of free damage against them, while breaking all the shields will trigger a much larger all-out attack which deals a lot of damage and leaves the boss downed for a period of time.

On one hand, I don't really mind the elemental system from an offensive standpoint. Some people complained that bosses only take chip damage from everything besides elemental attacks, but every musou game has enemies split between fodder grunts that only exist to charge your ultimate ability and actually threatening enemies that need you to focus and think for a bit. On the other hand, I really don't like the elemental system from a defensive standpoint. Like I said, in musou games you're meant to treat the hundreds of small enemies as invisible and focus on the few large enemies, but in this game the small enemies also have elemental attacks, and some of them are super-effective against your character's Persona. Getting hit by a super-effective elemental attack, even from a grunt enemy, can stun you and lead to you getting comboed to death by the miniboss, and it's impossible to keep track of every small enemy when there can be literally dozens of enemies on screen at any one time.

The pacing of the combat sections is lifted straight out of P5, which will probably annoy many musou fans. Most musou games have you running through a decently large battlefield, taking down roaming groups of enemies while prioritising specific targets according to the story. In P5S, you take down one group of enemies, then you get a cutscene explaining a new story development, then another fight, then another cutscene etc. This is basically exactly how the Palaces in P5 functioned, but this is highly atypical for a musou game and people who are not accustomed to the pacing of P5 will probably get annoyed. Also, there is a very weird and annoying quirk with the game where you are allowed to exit the Jail at various checkpoints to fully recover health and SP and go back into the Jail at the same point, it doesn't advance the calendar and there is no penalty for doing so. In fact, the game explicitly tells you that this is a legitimate tactic. In that case, why not let the checkpoint heal you directly, instead of making you wait through 2 loading screens to exit and re-enter the Jail?

Also, most of the P5 gameplay outside of dungeon-crawling has essentially been removed in P5S. The calendar system is in the game essentially in name only. There is no deadline for clearing Jails, and leaving and re-entering Jails does not advance the calendar. The calendar only advances with main story completion and the time-management aspect of P5 is no longer present. There are also no social stats for you to level up, so your time spent outside of Jails will consist mainly of buying supplies and talking to your teammates to get side quests. However, to compensate for that, all the Jails you visit will still remain accessible even after you clear them and you will revisit them to complete side quests, which is a departure from P5 Palaces.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anybody who played P5, enjoyed the interactions of the Phantom Thieves and wished that there was more of that to snack on. If you're the kind of person who loved all the vacation side stories in P5 and wished that there was a game which is 50% of just that, then this game is definitely for you. Honestly I would hesitate to recommend P5S at full price, but this game goes on pretty steep discount quite frequently and it's definitely worth picking up during a sale.

author: 7b57506bc27456b69b214ebfe990d4c2
content:
Do I recommend this.. I honestly don't know. I wish there was a maybe button. 
I find that every time I try to play this I realize i'd just rather be playing Persona 5. The story isn't as strong right off the bat, but on top of that the gameplay also isn't as strong. I say this as someone that doesn't really like turn based RPGs. The gameplay of this reminds me closest of Dynasty Warriors and like Dynasty Warriors the combat neither satisfies nor challenges and I felt like I was coasting through the game.

At this point the phantom thieves know each other, and while each 'monarch' tries to relate to the phantom thieves for me it fell flat on the first two monarchs. Where as Persona 5 immediately gut punches you with a corrupt teacher abusing students, Strikers seems to just.. start. The first enemy is a pop star abusing her fans which never grabbed me. There's little in the way of character development as all of the phantom thieves already had their character development and got to know each other.

In the end this game is for folks that just want to see another adventure for the Phantom Thieves, but be warned it doesn't touch the quality of the original.

author: 805c44d65dad5a5591b3638790324c55
content:
Do you love musou?  Let me share with you my favorite part of this musou hack-and-slash brawler game with a Persona skin:

You will enter an area, get a bunch of story, take 2 steps, get some dialog about a monster, fight the monster, take two steps, get a bunch of story, take 2 steps, get some dialog about a monster, fight the monster, and these steps will repeat until you finish the area.  In the middle, you're going to get interrupted nonstop with tutorials until they're done, and then you're going to get some more you didn't think existed.

All the while, 2 steps, stop, fight, 2 steps, stop, fight, 2 steps, stop, fight.

30 hours of that.

10/10 A++ would musou this way again!

author: 8da8d953cc2455a48b77666e8ae2d094
content:
Only buy this game if two things are true, 1. it's on sale and 2. that you really want more persona while you wait for persona 6. 
*SPOILERS PAST THIS POINT*




The game was very repetitive and palaces where difficult to call unique from one another just because they were all castle with a different coat of paint, additionally most of the bosses/enemies felt very bullet sponge like, making it have a artificial playtime, even playing on easy mode it took up to 15 minutes to complete a boss fight, which would consist of light attack 2x + one special so as to proc X affinity to hit the weakness which felt much less satisfying compared to P5. The story is practically non existent following the same twists the P5 had. however if you are like me and want to play just to hear the Phantom theives chat and hang out this game is worth it, when it's on sale. But full price the game just doesn't compate to P5 or even P4 for that matter.

author: 7d20301f484a59a3bef6ed2f21bcc8f8
content: It's not the worst musou game I've played but no where near the best either.  The boss enemies are extreme HP sponges which just gets boring.  Honestly, by the lock boss before the end of the 2nd jail I am completely done with it.  The HP pools of the bosses have ground my enjoyment of the game down to 0.  Learning patterns and rinsing and repeating over and over for far too long is the reason I don't play NASCAR games and is now the reason I will never play this again.  I've got better things to do than go to one boss battle after an another spending anywhere from 20-30 minutes doing the same things over and over.  Otherwise, the elemental system from Persona was interesting to work with in a musou but doesn't fit as well as it does in a turn based RPG.  The story so far has been a mix of all right and mediocre and since I just finished putting 176 hours in P5R, it was nice to have a continuation with the characters but sadly, this was a waste of my money and I will never play it again.

-PLAY the OG Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal before playing this, the game assumes that you know the squad, its a direct

-Fast paced action AND it still holds that RPG character/persona building from P5.

author: d24c878d11575a7fa362478bbe8f10ce
content:
This game was supposed to cure the gaping hole in my heart left after finishing Persona 5 Royal, but like a drug, it only held me over temporarily before striking that hole even deeper than it was previously.

In all seriousness, for being only half the length of its predecessor, Persona 5 Strikers packs on hell of a punch. The gameplay is a pretty big shift for those who have grown acclimated to Persona's turn based style. Yes, the camera controls are absolutely vile, and you may need to reach near-divinity to process all the information on screen, but you get used to it pretty quick. Once you find your favorite character(s) to play and get some levels under your belt, things get a lot smoother. The story maintains the bar of quality set by Persona 5, definitely continuing its style, and the new characters that come along for the ride are a blast, and bring some unique angles to the Phantom Thieves. Once the story gets going, it's hard to put down.

All in all, 10/10, and as a side note, you should definitely let Haru drive, trust me.

author: 8fe1d726d5cb5d3e99d310243c8d209c
content: A big criticism I see from people about P5 is that it doesn't have those friendship moments with the Phantom Thieves as P4 did with the Investigation Team. This whole game felt like those friendship moments that P5 lacked. I felt way closer to the characters after this second adventure. I thought about playing Strikers before P5 since it released on Steam first, but I am so glad I waited so I could meet the characters properly. As far as Musou game sequel/spinoffs go, this is a great one that pulled off the same effects as Fire Emblem Warriors Three Hopes. I got to meet some old friends, make some new ones, and enjoy an already-built world in a new format.

author: 297c160c1f365aff9b5d0233017eb2b1
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is a disappointing sequel to an exceptionally well established title. Poor visuals, cut content, lack of an enjoyable combat system and uninteresting music leaves much to be desired. What remains is a decent story which is a replica of the original Persona 5, a couple of new likeable characters and the fantastic cast - The Phantom Thieves.

Performance is a mess, need to set affinity to utilize all processors which minimizes stuttering.

Although a chore to complete because of the off-putting combat system, Strikers is a must for anyone who wants more of the Phantom Thieves. It's not any better than Royal, very far from it but it will help fill the void that Royal will have left.

author: 496d2b31bf90523f8d56f65d05d83b04
content:
Coming into Persona 5 Strikers, I thought the game would be a fun spin off where I get to see all my favorite characters in a hack and slash game. However after completing this game I'm more than happy to say that this game is more than just a spin off, but a worthy sequel to the Persona 5 story and an excellent addition to the franchise. 

The combat in the game at first was a challenge at first, but after getting used to the controls it felt smooth and it incorporated the core elements of Persona 5's battle system like baton bass and persona creation excellently. Each character felt like they had a unique combat style that matched their character and were all fun to use, with my favorite's being Yusuke and Zenkichi.

The story was also a strong point of the game, and the two new members of the phantom thieves, Sophia and Zenkichi, were wonderful addition to the main cast and added a lot of life to this game. The story also allowed characters that didn't get as much development in the original game to get fleshed out more, with Haru getting the most development out of any the original cast. The villains of this game had some really great boss designs and were characterized in a sympathetic light, which allowed them to act as foils and further the growth of certain members of the Phantom Thieves.  My favorite part of this game was while there was an overarching plot about freeing people from their trauma, the game also spent a lot of time on slice of life elements. It really did feel like I was on a road trip with good friends, and made me appreciate the Phantom Thieves characters that much more. 

The visuals of this game are top notch and maintain the flair and art style from the original game that we all know and love. The soundtrack is phenomenal and just as good as the soundtrack from Persona 5 Royal. Lyn absolutely brings her A game to the table with all the new songs featuring her, and the remixes of songs such as Last Surprise and Blooming Villain do the originals justice.

I would wholeheartedly recommend Persona 5 Strikers to anyone who is a fan of Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal that just wants to spend some more time with the characters that many of us have come to love. It's a fantastic addition to the franchise and I hope Atlus will continue explore the world of Persona 5 in the future.  

An easy 10/10!

author: c6c92c6ad8625bde87cafc9173de99ec
content:
Overall great follow up to P5.
Story-wise it's a direct sequel to P5 Vanilla ending. Story itself is very similar to main storyline of P5, but it flows better thanks to pre-established PT characters and is very interesting because of its focus on trauma and tie-ins with PTs. It does start kinda dry tho, but picks up later.
New characters are great, espeically new additions to the PTs.
Gameplay is dynasty warrior style action rpg, its good, but sometimes bosses can feel a bit spongey.
Soundtrack is more fire from Lyn.

Only bad part is PC port. 
60 fps and compressed assets suck. I wish they would do a refresh with 120 fps and 4K assets like they did with P5R. 
Default controls are pretty terrible.
I was also constantly getting this annoying bug where your hotkeys just stop working in menus until you alt-tab.
Also loading times are pretty terrible, even on NVMe SSD.

author: 66e7228412715f6eb52aac67fcdcb76b
content: appallingly bad game that tries to somewhat amount to what persona 5 was. combat is clunky as all hell, ui tries to be stylish like p5 but is a pain in the ass to navigate. somehow, scenes in between run worse than combat scenes, and the issue of too little SP recovery is still apparent, but much worse this time, as you can only really use 3 moves before running out of stamina. bonus content is pretty cool, but it does not in any way enhance the gameplay. a shame, because this games story and characters are actually pretty cool and i would definitely enjoy it. alas, the game is not at all up to code for persona 5's standards, or even just regular video game standards. if you like hack and slash games, try it. if you like persona 5 enough, try it. buy it on sale.

author: d99e64a35cf75015a8fd98e7879d922b
content:
Okay game, horrible port. Buy only if you really want more Persona 5 content, and even then just try get it on a console or something.

Constant crashes mixed with no autosave (???) and awkward placement of manual save points (luckily cutscenes even with chooseable dialogue options are completely skipable) , barebones support for PC graphic options, esp over 1080p/FHD.

Gameplay is hit or miss leaning on miss. Mixing hack n slash with normal Persona turnbased elements, like how Dynasty Warriors does it, but worse. The real time actions of the enemies makes it frustrating to use strategic skills and the hack n slash part does not feel good to play standalone (saving grace is Yusuke with his carbon copy Vergil moveset). 
To do well in hard mode feels more like needing to grind levels and cheese skills and items you to obtain from mindless mob grinding (kill trash mobs in an area, leave the area, kill the new batch that respawned and repeat) to beat the insanely bloated HP of bosses and mini bosses; otherwise you'll be stuck in a 30 min clunky boss fight that ends prematurely because you ran out of SP and your computer friends died somewhere between the fight starting and you zoning out after watching the boss's health bar tick down at like 1% every 5 minutes. The AI teammates in your party act like basic computers reacting to enemy attacks (ironically not smart enough to be AI), yet somehow manage to still be useless to the point you have to babysit them esp on hard.

Story is regular Persona business (pretty decent overall but not as good as the mainline games such as P5R, P4G, P3 etc.) but it is also completely linear and can be skipped through without missing too much (useful, because it's what I had to do after losing hours of saves multiple times). IMO it almost has ruins the impact of the story/ending Persona 5/Royal had given you, especially if you play this one right after.

Banging music though, makes up for all the shortcomings. But again don't play this on PC unless you have to.

(This was written after losing a few hours of grinding for the 3rd time)

author: e6f47b48a2cc5e08a21c981e8a8088f2

Setting the difficulty to easy seems like a cheap way out, but it sadly is the only way to avoid spamming XXXY + dodge for 30 minutes each bossfight

author: 4bf0ea19413950438d1b7025434f478a
content:
I enjoyed this game WAY more than I thought I would, definitely worth getting it.

I loved how much it focuses on developing the character's friendship as a group, I think it's one of the strongest points it has, which is something the original P5 could have improved upon. The story is a bit predictable and has many repeated points with the original game, but some bits are really good. I'd almost say the main plotline is secondary until well past the halfway point of the game, up until that point it's basically Slice of life with dungeon crawling, and I don't mean it as a downside. The Phatom Thieves go on a vacation through Japan and it's full of hilarious moments.

The gameplay itself is the main complaint about this game since it's not turn-based, but people seem to forget this is a spin-off title developed by Tecmo Koei, and honestly as an action RPG it's very entertaining and considered to be one of the best they've developed. I found it incredibly overwhelming at the beginning with all the tutorials and characters with different playstyles, but I got used to it and appreciate that they made all characters playable, relevant and they actively encourage you to learn them.
Also the soundtrack is a complete banger, easily a top contender for best Persona soundtrack, put me Daredevil and Axe to Grind in a 10 hour loop and I'm a happy person.

As a side note: If you see the text blurry, disabling antialiasing fixes it. Graphically the game is not the prettiest while comparing it to P5 or P5R, and those games weren't pushing any boundaries either, but it's something completely secondary in this franchise

author: 86dceda5056858cd8bf5034bac0b15c6
content:
For a cashgrab sequel of a cult JRPG, this is surprisingly in depth, fun as hell and has a very interesting premise.

author: 4f8175251779591f868950b0b3d34ca1
content:
Cons:
Combat is very different than personal 5 royal. It takes away the turn base and adds fast pace combat. The down side is that they didn't think it out very well. The controls are awful.

Persona 5 strikers allows your companions to be in fast combat with you. However this is a down side as your companions seem to have brain damage and can't fight properly. 

They have taken out nearly everything that makes Persona what it is. If you're looking for a persona type game play you wont  find it with this game.

Pros:
It continues the story where persona 5 royal left off.

If you have never played or heard of a persona game and this is your first, you may enjoy it.

My thoughts:
If you enjoy persona games, I suggest you skip this one and just watch the story on youtube as this game is awful compared to the last one. I have no clue what they were thinking when they changed everything. I guess they don't understand the concept of if it's not broken don't fix it.

author: 1a560981043455fd9c213560b851abe1
content:
In short, Persona 5 Strikers is a wonderful game with a nice history, amazing voice actors and soundtrack, fun gameplay and beautiful graphics. I absolute recommend this game.

Full review bellow, may cointain spoilers, I dont know.

I really loved Persona 5 Strikers, not only it brought back our dear Phantom Thieves together filling that void that you get when your favorite game or show ends but it also delivered an amazing history and game.

History

I really enjoyed the history, usually Persona games are really straight foward, the bad guys are evil, the good guys bring them down, nothing wrong with that, however, in Persona 5 Strikers most of the villains arent actually evil people and its really good to see such shift from an abusive professor that beats middle schoolers and abuse them to an artist and singer consumed by sadness and sorrow doing some wrong things after obtaining an unknown power through Emma that could help them in running away from scars from the past.

Not only it gave the gang a weird feeling after beating the shadow form of the villains, but they also felt so connected to the problems they were facing. Instead of having the usual hero vs villain fight to save the people, our dear Phantom Thieves wanted to help the villains aswell, since they were good people too! It was so nice to see that people could forgive people like Natsume cherishing his comeback or Mariko listening to the mother that lost his daughter saying that Mariko was really important to the city and wanted her as mayor again.

We're living times were people define you for mistakes you commited, you see on Social Media people absolutely terrorizing famous people lifes for errors they did 2? 6? years ago, ignoring that despite being famous they're humans aswell, imperfect and capable of changing. People do it to everyone nowadays, one mistake and your life is ruined.
So Persona 5 Strikers history brings a really important message, that not everyone that do mistakes are evil people, that people despite doing wrong things wether you forgive them or not CAN change. I really liked it, it is really important to have themes like this delivered to us.

I really liked Sophia and Zenkichi, both were such well developed characters. Despite having the means to have an extensive knowledge, Zenkichi being a grown adult working for PubSec and Sophia an AI with full acess to information, both had such low knowledge of emotions and spent the whole journey learning. It was so warming to see Zenkichi coming to therms with Akane and finally facing Owada, thus, becoming a good father and a good friend to himself, no longer running away from his ideals and goals. Sophia, even though she is an AI, displayed so many emotions, everytime she interfered and spoke to villains, showing her views and ideas about what was going on, I could imagine her crying if she could, for an AI she has so much passion, its like even though she doesnt have a physical heart, it is there. She became a caring and loving friend, a true humanity companion :)

It was also nice to see how much Makoto and Haru matured, while Ryuji and Ann are still teenagers slacking their duties on school hahaha

Gameplay

I enjoyed so much the way Atlus introduced Persona to hack n slash, it was really well done. Battling felt so satisfying with such beautiful graphics and soundtrack, the voice acting is top notch. Every character had an unique way of attacking and the way baton pass works in P5S was really well done.
Despite having so much fun, there are things I believe it could be done diferently.

Since the battles are so action packed and fast, having an image show every time you attack the enemy weakness not only becomes a visual polution but it also decrease the value that it had on previous Persona Games. It is so satisfying to see an image pop up with a close face of your character when you crit in Persona 4, it didnt feel that satisfying having the close up every time you attack the enemy weakness, sometimes it felt like it was delaying the battle and I know I just felt this way because the image showed every time. The close-up face image should only show sometimes, I suppose in future hack'n'slash games, Persona magic abilities could crit too and therefore the image would only show if the ability landed a crit? I dont know.

I am grateful that the commands arent a mess for keyboard users, I had no problem playing this game on keyboard and could enjoy it's full experience despite not having a controller. I dont think its a flaw, its just an opinion, but, I wish they changed the default key for guns, it felt weird to use ctrl key + shift for charged shots and sometimes I accidentaly pressed the windows key, also, it was difficult to leave the Gun mode when using Sophia due to the keys being so far away. Maybe its a problem in my end, who knows.

Soundtrack + Voice Acting

Amazing as always, Persona games always deliver good music and this game is no exception! The new versions of musics used in Persona 5/Persona 5 Royal are REALLY good, I couldnt image that such good tracks could be improved since they were already good, but they improved them a lot to fit this game! Keeper of Lust in Persona 5 Strikers is such a banger, congratulations!
Also, thanks Atlus for possibility of choosing old Persona games battle musics, it was such cool addition, I really loved it.

The voice actings was perfect! There were so many emotional moments that would NEVER be as good as they are if the dub wasnt so well done! Yusuke telling Natsume to dont lump Sayuri with the soulless history that he wrote, Sophia and Ichinose/Konoe, Ryuji telling Emma to shut up when she was telling bad things to Sophia. So many good moments.

Ahh I feel like playing again just by remembering those moments haha, Persona 5 had such a good dub and Persona 5 Strikers keeps the tradition.

-----

Thanks to everyone involved in the production of this game, it is really an amazing game and I felt so happy while playing it.
There are so many good things to write about Persona 5 Strikers that would make my review so big, but in short, thank you very much for creating such cool game for my favorite series!

author: af6c21d3d89152b3911b5c6d08140527
content:
summary get this if you finished persona 5 or royal.

this game is a p5/p5r base setting with changed battle system and also social system since the story set after p5 ending which you suppose to max confidant with all your friend. story wise still the same p5 vibe so if you like p5 you like this as well.

as for gameplay most ppl think this is a warrior like gameplay with p5 skin, while truth is its persona/smt series base system but changed to warrior like battle style with it p5 battle adaption such as weakness/all out attack/baton pass/show time etc... it start out kinda difficult when you dont understand the game or you are not action game player, but as you play and understand the system more you feel the p5 adaption is on point. 

overall while the game is far from perfect but it put in effort to try new stuff instead of just skin change. maybe it will be better next adaption if there any.

author: e067e48cd8535858806d61ca49cea472
content:
Persona 5 Strikers (P5S) is an action RPG title that is co-developed with Omega Force - who popularized Musou-style action genre with Dynasty Warriors series where the action revolves around mowing down ridiculous hordes of enemies. I initially posted my review at the 37h mark (around 3/4 of the story) but felt compelled after I've finished the game to make the review more complete, in order to do it justice - because the game went from being pretty good at first to being great when I was technically done with it. 

It should be noted that P5S appears to be the canonical sequel to Persona 5 (P5), so if you're the type that needs to follow stories in chronological order, you might want to pass on this game for now. Personally, I've yet to play P5 myself although I do have some background having watched the awful Persona 5: The Animation before. If you have no background of P5, some names and terminology that come up in the game might leave you confused but I don't think they are a huge issue. And if you're invested in the story thereafter, then all the more reason to pick up Persona 5 Royal (P5R) - the definitive version of P5 also available on Steam - when you're done with P5S.

In terms of gameplay, other titles in the Musou genre (which I'll refer to as "Musous") are laid out in mission stages where the combat field (the stage itself) involves mowing down hordes of enemies while completing set objectives - visceral large-scale combat on an open field while being outnumbered and yet overpowered. However, P5S's game structure is that of a JRPG and is an authentic Persona experience. Instead of stages, P5S uses JRPG dungeons (known here as "jails") which become available as the story progresses. When encountering an enemy (or via scripted events) in dungeons, it will usually spawn a horde of enemies - this is where the Musou-influence comes into play. If you're familiar with Persona series, just think of the turn-based combat being replaced by action combat. There are some minor platforming/puzzle-solving in various dungeons which I didn't appreciate but they do add variety. Outside dungeons, you hang around in a designated open city like those in the Yakuza series except there's no fighting to be had. There are side quests in the game (known as requests) which are mostly kill/fetch quests - nothing super interesting but aren't annoying either. In terms of content, there's the main story comprising of a few dungeons. Finishing the story will allow you to make a clear save to access post-game content which comes in the form of requests to obtain the best weapons for your team. Finishing the post-game content will then allow you to start NG+ which also unlocks the highest difficult, "Merciless". In NG+, everything you previously earned is carried over. There are a total of 9 playable characters and 8 of them are accessible from the start of your first "non-tutorial" dungeon while the 9th will join later in the story. In NG+, you can access all 9 in the first actual dungeon.

Combat is one area the game shines in and caters to various styles of play. The controls in the game are responsive and all the Persona mechanics are very well integrated into the combat. Your attacks are made up by strings of basic attacks ending with a special attack. In addition, you have a dodge that has invincibility frames and can invest points in perks later on to capitalize on perfect dodges. If you're not a fan of fast-paced action, there's also a dedicated button to access your personas and also freezes time. There's also access to Persona fusion like any other Persona games. Different personas have different (but fixed) effects at the end of their combo strings, so finding a good mix of skills that work well alongside the combo strings is what the substance of build-making is - figuring out what skills are good and the fusion path to inherit the skills you want, to the target persona to fuse. In P5S, skills learnt by personas (i.e. not inherited from fusion) are always remembered and can be reconfigured when out of combat. The party size is up to 4 and members can be changed when out of combat, with the main restriction that Joker (the main protagonist) must always be in the team. So if you want to go at it alone, you can do so but only with Joker. All characters have a different play style and you can swap to any party (not team) member during combat. Progression takes the form of levels/equipment, persona roster, character-specific arts and a bond board which is used to unlock team-wide perks. Combat may initially feel plain and restrictive due to low SP gauge for abilities but gets better with game progression as characters learn new skills and from unlocking perks at the bond board. Although Musous tend to have a bad rep for being no-brainer button-mashers, P5S isn't quite the case and you can play it as a skill-based game by not abusing consumables, which will be in short supply anyway unless you grind for them. Boss fights are especially fun.

The story is pretty decent and the storytelling really shines here - compared to Persona 5 - which is helped by the good writing, overall presentation and a focus on bonding events. The dialogues are mostly full voiced and the English dub is pretty good. The script is well-written and there's a lot of humour which the voice actors did a really good job delivering. The story cutscenes and non-action-related gameplay takes up like 50% of the game, so if you're invested in the story, then it's great; if not, the game will feel like a beefed up visual novel with sparse but lengthy action gameplay in-between. While I did enjoy the story conversations, one gripe I have with it is that there's a lot of repeated info which feels like intentional padding rather than real value to the overall plot. For Persona fans specifically, there aren't any social links here and literally zero consequences to player choice. However, there are many bonding events that do a terrific job of fleshing out the friendship of the protagonists - like in Persona 4 Golden (P4G). P5 was disappointing to me story-wise, but P5S pretty much redeemed it for me - in fact, I prefer its story-telling over the former.

Presentation is top notch in pretty much every Persona game I know of (since Persona 3) and this one is no slouch either. The UI is sleek and stylish while remaining usable. Combat looks amazingly flashy and feels good to pull off combos/abilities. My only gripe with the visuals is that the UI clutter can make fights with a lot of enemies difficult to read. The music was initially only serviceable for me, but did grew on me over time. I really like the themes in the dungeons of the later half and the remixes of the original Persona 5 tracks, like "Blooming Villain" and "Keeper of Lust". The track during the last phase of the final boss fight, "Demiurge II: Negai" was truly exceptional; it so well orchestrated with the last fight that it elevates it beyond epic - I think it's right up there with "Ameno Sagiri" (P4G), if not better. Most of these are arranged/composed by the Koei Tecmo Sound team, I believe.

Performance-wise, I'm happy to report that I didn't encounter any technical issues in the entirety of my 90+ hours playtime. Game runs great and loads fast on my AMD 2700X/GTX1060 6GB setup even when installed on a spinning HDD.

In conclusion, I've thoroughly enjoyed P5S and would strongly recommend it even at its asking price. It has a decent story that is well delivered and has a good amount of content going for it. The action combat is fun and caters well to players looking for simplicity or depth. As for replayability, it depends on how much you get tired of replaying the storyline over and over. But that's what I'm doing right now in NG+ merciless. Overall, fantastic game!

author: 9ab038fffdb7587982a3ce77882d7e08
content:
This game s l a p s.

Loved the remixed tracks from Persona 5 and the new tracks for the jails are PERFECT for the atmosphere. 
The story has nods to the original persona 5 but doesn't require the player to have played it, and the new characters are smoothly introduced. 
But most of all, this gameplay is so satisfying. The system for leveling up Joker's personas is well made and allows for some extremely complex planning, and hitting enemy weaknesses feels gratifying. 

Literally my only quarrel is that sometimes the audio balance for the voice acting feels way off. I assume it was recorded when everyone was working from home.

author: b4558456e8235fa884908675fd1da7c5
content:
Los Chorizos Fantasmas estan de vuelta para una ultima aventura.

Unos meses despues del final de Persona 5, Joker y Morgana vuelven a Tokyo para pasar el verano con la banda y resulta que hay alguien jodiendo con el metaverso otra vez y cambiando los corazones de la poblacion, asi que los muchachos se ven obligados a hacer algo al respecto. La diferencia es que para esta altura los personajes ya son re porongas, asi que la amenaza principal no se siente tan apremiante. Sabes que los Phantom Thieves le van a romper la cara a quien esta detras de todo y eso deja lugar a un juego que no se toma tan en serio asi mismo y que tiene muchisimo fan-service e INCLUSO MAS humor que la entrega anterior
El juego tiene el framing de un Road Trip, lo cual es una idea genial. Vas viajando por todo Japon en un motorhome por cuestiones de la historia, pero esto mismo es una excelente excusa para ver a los personajes viviendo alocadas aventuras (y morfando hasta el hartazgo) en distintas ciudades.

Algo importantisimo a aclarar es que para esta entrega el sistema de combate deja de ser por turnos y pasa a ser tipo hack and slash, pero super rapido y estilizado. Piensen Devil May Cry pero contra docenas de enemigos al mismo tiempo. Asimismo, la musica de combate son, en su mayoria, versiones mixadas de temas clasicos de Persona 5, pero en versiones tirando a metal. Keeper of Lust y Last Surprise se llevan las palmas. Una maravilla como siempre la musica, no es de extrañar.

En fin, es una mas que digna despedida para estos personajes tan queridos. Ojala los volvamos a ver algun dia.

A quick summary after the first 4 hours

For the life of me, I don't understand why you wouldn't just play the newer YS games instead

Equip weapon with moar damage equip armor with moar defense equip persona with moar stats

aAt least at the beginning, you can't take 5 steps without triggering a cutscene that goes hey there is an enemy hey you can jump up there hey there is a treasure chest

The presentation, VA, just general style, are all truly top notch, I'll give them that ... and that's about all the positivity I can muster. Ehhh
