content:
Haru gets more screen time, so yeah, it's good. 

Strikers is a direct sequel to 5 and since Atlus are dumb lazy cunts that hate money, you will need to emulate 5 vanilla on rpcs3 before you play this. 

Strikers is not a turn-based rpg like the previous game, it's purely an action game, similar to Dynasty Warriors. I usually hate musou shit, but this one is pretty fun. The combat is neat and i really enjoyed the way you use your personas powers in real time with combos to counter enemy weaknesses, just like the turn-based game.

Anyway, Strikers is a worthy sequel. If you enjoyed Persona 5 characters and story you will definitely enjoy this one too.

Play it. It's alright, I guess.

author: 54060fd53a5951f8ac9a7cc89ae268fc
content:
Absolutely love this as a continuation of Persona 5! The combat feels like a fun departure from Persona's turn-based combat while still remaining true to staple mechanics like exploiting weaknesses, One More, and All Out Attacks.

The story is also very fun, and it's great getting to see all the characters interact with each other. The individual plots for each "dungeon" do feel a little samey so far, but that isn't enough to detract from the charm and amazing rapport the Phantom Thieves have with each other.

author: 1cf5f42c94195cb381c6276a456d4d0d
content:
Anyone familiar with the Warriors games will have a rough understanding of what to expect. But this time around the Persona mechanics are integrated quite well, making it a very different experience than any Warriors game before it - if anything, the much larger number of enemies than normal for a Persona game necessitates a stronger focus on the weakness system in order to maintain an advantage. And yes, Persona collection and fusion are still core mechanics as well. Overall, it lends itself to using very different tactics than a normal Persona game, and combinations I wouldn't have really bothered with outside of this game. The story and cutscenes are completely faithful to what one would expect of Persona, and I felt were very fulfilling.

That being said, I will say the boss design is a bit weak - the major bosses do have unique mechanics and do feel unique, but the fights drag a bit and begin to feel stale with the amount of hp they have. The minor bosses don't have the benefit of unique mechanics to offset the hp-spongeness.

content: I'm about halfway through, and this game rules. The Persona fusions and skills are still just as useful here as in 5 and Royal, and the twists and bends the narrative takes are highly similar to 5, but lean more towards Royal. Basically, if you liked 5, give this a try.

author: 08fa2ea0dbc5509ba04ffd466701b643
content:
If you want to know if Persona 5 Strikers is right for you, simply answer yes / no to the following questions:

1 - Did you play Persona 5?
2 - Did you like Persona 5?
3 - Do you like action / Hack n slash games?

If you answered "yes" to the questions above, you will love Persona 5 Strikers.  I loved it.  

The game is lengthy.  The mechanics are fluid.  The integrated RPG elements are well done.  The story is great and its wonderful to have the Phantom thieves back together again for a second romp.  The writing is good.  

Excessive chit chat can get a little tiring towards the end of the game.

Overall excellent.

author: 53d5328fddce5c4c8500866d8d41ddfd
content:
P5S is a sequel/ spinoff of Persona 5, and its pretty good. The question I see about this game all the time is "do I need to play Base Persona 5 to play this one?" and yeah, I think you should. It takes place directly after, and while they don't touch on the story of P5 often, you still miss a lot of information on the characters and world, and if you go back to P5 later, a lot of stuff will be spoiled for you. Its not MANDITORY by any means, but enhances the game considerably. 

With that out of the way, the game itself is a hack and slash game similar to the Warriors Series. And this is the first game with that combat I've consistently enjoyed. I've played Fire Emblem Warriors and Hyrule Warriors, and both of them get really REALLY boring after so many hours, but P5S keeps it fresh the whole way through, and is the only of this kind of game I've gone and 100%ed. The Demon Fusion elements from SMT are still present, but have been watered down considerably. This was a downside for me, but if you found the system tedious, this could be a good thing for you. Unless you're going for full completion, there is minimal grinding in this game, and the different ways to improve are all satisfying and fun to keep up with. The social aspect is all gone and the story is very streamlined, which makes it feel a lot less "persona-y" and the story is generally far more simple than anything else you'll see in this series, but the game never pretends to be more than it is. If you're coming for a simple button masher with some familiar faces and a cool world. you're in the right spot. But if you want a game that will make you feel the same way previous Persona games did, you're in the wrong spot. Overall if you liked P5 and want more. I'd recommend checking this one out. 6/10

I love the persona series. Played them all. But you should know a few things about Strikers.

1. It's dynasty warriors reskin. And when it comes to the Musou the mechanics are pretty bare bones. Which, of course, ain't that bad - But that's a big hit or miss with a ton of people.
2. There is no story choices. Romance, social links, mini-games? None here, bub.
3. It's really a story that doesn't need to be told.
4. The music is bumping.

Persona 5 is great. But this extra filler? Even the most die hard fans I think will be semi-let down over it. For example, Sophia and Old Man Zenkichi are not very charming. Finally, it has some of the lame changes of heart ever... Including someone semi-copying other peoples manga tropes and adding them to his own stupid manga. I would advise you watch a YouTube for about an thirty minutes of gameplay just to see if it's for you.

author: b0c08170808b5228a06b93b9cfac8adf
content:
This is persona 5 light fused with a musô. 

First, I would strongly recommend coming here after playing the original persona 5 or better persona 5 royal (even though in this case some elements would not be cannon with this story). First, it is a sequel / OVA so starting by the second entry is a bit silly, second a good half of the persona experience is your link with its cast of characters so, even if most of the mechanics of the story are re-explained, you would miss a lot a things, and persona 5 is one of the best games of last generation sooo...

Anyway, presentation wise, exactly like its predecessor, this game is pristine, beautiful, inspired and varied environments, the music (again) is awesome, great animation works... It just radiates quality.
Same thing in the writing department, the characters are as endearing as ever, and the additions to the thieves are very welcome, but the plot is a tad predictable sometimes.
The problem arises in the gameplay department, the moment-to-moment gameplay is clearly an experiment here, sometimes fighting can be tedious because of the stuck camera, lack of clarity, and the amount of enemies / time to dispatch them… when it’s good it is really good you dodge and weave through the enemies with grace… until nothing shows you that another enemy is about to one shot from behind… Also, some jails (think palaces in p5) are a bit too big and revisiting them can be a bit tedious. The fusion system is a bit more tedious with level requirement for fusions components. And for the out of jail part, it is good, the confident system has been replaced by a much simpler system that allows you to unlock bonuses by collecting points doing requests (simple quests), after story event and during fighting, simpler but fitting for this much simpler game.
Anyway, it is a quality game with some gameplay inconsistencies, though even though it is less good than its mainline entry, I enjoyed it a great deal and if you liked p5 you should too! Though I would really love to see another iteration on these mechanics, a p6s maybe? 
Anyway, it’s time for you to tear your mask out, right?

author: e82ea4fe4ccb524e9d5f7653cd61c3bf
content:
note: I am a major fan of persona5. 

pros: 
+ story is direct sequel to p5
+ new characters are beautifully designed and well voiced.  this is what made the game worth it initially. 
+ great to spend time with p5 cast, most (all?) with returning english voice actors. 
+ lightweight game loads quick. polygonal and vector graphics scale up to 4k nicely  


cons:  
- the story mode for is Strikers is a formula sequel - think home alone 2. 
- yusuke's characterization is sketchy. he's obsessed with vacation BBQ food now? c'mon.
- re-used character artwork. for a full price sequel it's kinda lame to stare at exactly the same portraits again. 
- character art is rasterized at what looks like 1080p resolution - blurry at 4k. 
- dungeon design is below average.
- full priced sequel with missing social sim mechanics and nothing new to fill the void. 

worst of all - 
- combat system isn't fun. little incentive for dynamic play. spam attacks, save SP, target weaknesses.... repeat repeat repeat

conclusion:
as a fan of persona5, i found the Strikers story mode marginally acceptable - BUT - as a gamer i found the experience tedious.

author: dee66ec6b8a455658757ca949d8d021f
content:
If you liked Persona 5 this game is quite a good sequel.  (Playing this without playing Persona 5 will leave you utterly lost though so go play Persona 5 now) 

Comparatively, you get another 3/4 of a game of Persona 5 story and character interaction.  You get another new 3/4 of a excellent Persona 5 soundtrack and some arranged returning tracks.  All the new battle music is amazing as usual.  Voice acting is top notch.  No social links and the persona and fusion lineup is pared down, but it's no big deal.  

Gameplay is decent.  It's a Musou game by the Dynasty Warriors people but does not feel swarmy or button mashy most of the time.  Even on normal difficulty not paying attention to the enemy movements and resistances will get you killed as enemies can hit like trucks.  There's more focus on killing large minibosses over swarms of enemies.  And the big bosses are pretty fun.

author: 5d09e33dcb32598b8925fa483effb25b
content:
Just about everything I loved about both Personas 5 and Royal is transplanted into Strikers. The charming characters, the story, the vibrant menus, and the music combine with a new combat system that disposes of turn-based, RPG-style fighting in favor of a more frenetic, real-time, one vs. 1,000 format that still makes you feel like you’re playing a Persona game.

Put the Phantom Thieves in damn near anything, and I’ll show up. They’re so well-written, realistic-sounding and mature. And they’ve grown from when we last met them, showing empathy to their adversaries. You’ll cheer when they get their big damn hero moment. How could I not take the opportunity to spend another 100 hours with these kids? And on a cross-Japan road trip too? Say less.

It’s almost unfair to call Strikers a musou game, despite being one, as it doesn’t feel like a Dynasty Warriors game at all. For as much as I love Koei Tecmo’s tentpole action series, Strikers’ combat is too slick and too varied, and too stylistically Persona to be called a typical musou. And I think it’s that combat that saves an otherwise sparsely appointed game.

author: 8eb581d720b65458bcb06dd74c778638
content:
[h1] They should have gone all in. [/h1]

This is a game that exudes adequacy. Everything is where it needs to be in order to sell a game people play and, at the end of their session, say "wow, that was a unique and interesting game" without actually paying it any mind. The reality of the situation, however, is a bit more grim.

We should start by giving this game kudos for TRYING to implement mouse and Keyboard support. For a W-Force product to do this, you know someone else was involved forcing it to happen. No, on to the short and sweet as to why I would not recommend this game:

[b] Replayability is almost nonexistent [/b]

There's not much more to say. You are trapped in a linear storyline with horribly restrictive and boring free-roam [b] elements. [/b] Outside of that, it is just you doing missions with a main character who, while wildly loved by the series' respective fans, is not the reason people play Warrior games. To have a single-digit number of characters that can be played, and only after some time, in a title like this is embarrassing and really highlights the shortcomings of the rest of the game.

[b] Artistic style is not an excuse for fun. [/b]

At the end of the day, a fresh coat of paint isn't an excuse for a lack of content. It looks very pretty, yes. True to the series for artistic choice? Yes. Does it add anything else? No. It seems the majority of production on this game went into pressing out another story in the Persona Universe without actually making the game around the new action-based mechanics.

Don't get it unless you merely want to continue the Persona fandom.

author: bff0eaffcba95d7b859c714c4b8a62b4
content:
An okay Persona spinoff game and a barely passable port. I would prefer to give this a mixed review over a negative review, but people only read the negative reviews.

If you're buying this, then you have probably already played P5/P5R (and if you haven't, there's really nothing here for you). It's pretty much just a lot of fan service tied together with an okay story, which is fine if that's what you're looking for. The gameplay loop is novel at first if you're coming from the slow, turnbased combat of the mainline games, but gets very boring and repetitive towards the later half of the game. I used Cheat Engine to get more XP and lowered the difficulty because the game expects you to grind to level up all your characters even on the lowest difficulty, which is frankly silly. 

The fanservice is enjoyable, but they cheaped out on a lot of the smaller interactions. For example, in mainline Persona 5, if you ate ramen with Ryuji in your free time, there'd be at least some action-figure-like animations accompanying you eating ramen. In this game, it just gives you a black screen with Ryuji telling you how delicious the ramen is. It's not great, but this is only for the minor interactions and nothing else really reaches that level of laziness.

That said, if you understand this is just a spinoff with none of the major Persona mechanics and just want to have more time with the Phantom Thieves, this might be worth it- on sale.

author: 6cf86c65d312563e9312a757919a3f1b
content: It's a sequel with great story and an actual continuation to the original Persona 5's (also great) story, but of course doesn't play like the original game. It is by no means easier either, as the game can be insanely difficult even on Normal mode, making Hard mode almost impossible to complete. Without doing extra side stuff like requests, or secret bosses the game might only take about 20 hours to complete, which my play-through with doing those things (plus some save scumming for specific side objectives) i finished the game at around 35 hours, which is not reflected in my Steam playtime as I was alt-tabbed out of the game a lot. I've not played many Musou games (only two being both Hyrule Warriors spin-offs as well) but for a crowd fighting game it's really weird the most you'll fight at a time is 3-15 enemies, with bigger crowds only available in scripted events, filled with generic no weakness enemies.

author: 87b26eeeb7fb5ba086df55fdef20b242
content:
TLDR: I don't like the gameplay loop, its too boring and redundant, but I like scenes where the gang hanging out and once the new story start rolling. There's something lacking on the gameplay loop, I find it hard to gather motivation to comeback to this game.

I'm a huge Persona fans so I'm a bit sad I can't like this game, I tried to push the end because I want to see what's the story had to offer. This is not a bad game, its a decent game but I need to push my self to finish it unlike other Persona games.

[h2]Good story and Character[/h2]
One of the good aspect in this game is the story, it's not as good as P5 Royal's third semester but it's an enjoyable story. It started with formulaic story but after the monotonous story done, it's an enjoyable story. The new cast on this game is the highlight of this game, his story is good and enjoyable, it had soul and might touch your heart. I really enjoy his story.

[h2]Great Music[/h2]
I like the soundtrack of this game, my favorite one is "Daredevil" and "Counter Strike". This game had really good music like you would expect from any persona games. The music gives so much vibe in this game, for example the "Daredevil" is feel like "I'm stylishly unstoppable" when striking toward towers and "Counter Strike" feel like "a smooth badass". It's pretty good

[h2]This is a decent game for returning fans, but its not a good game for new comers[/h2]
This game contains every team member already finished their character development on P5 so there's no many growth worth mentioning, many stuff in this game will appeal to the fans but might confuse new comer.

[h2] There's a good mechanic, but gameplay wise, I can't say many good thing about it[/h2]
There's a good mechanic like allowing you to swap to previously learned skill on your persona and cooking. I'm a huge Persona fans and find this entry quite underwhelming. It's still feel like Persona 5, character and story wise its good but gameplay wise is meh.

[h2]SP & HP management is bad in this game[/h2]
One of the most fun challange in Persona game is HP and SP management and this spin off made it a nuisance. On the original game, you need to manage your resource efficiently, if you fail to do so you'll lost 1 day worth of free time it's a pretty clever mechanic. On this spin off there's no penalty, to recover your resource just simply go out and go to dungeon again while doing it you need to watch 3 loading screen, it's such a pain to do. This game should've had 1 button to recover HP & SP instead of doing that stupid clunky way.

[h2]Decent UI, bad UX[/h2]
I hate the UX in this game. The UI is decent but the UX is bad. The most obvious thing is unskippable transition, it such a spit in the face to the original P5 UX. To do something you need to watch TRANSITION, it's unskipable and slow it makes doing everything in the main menu feel sluggish, I hate it. It's so bad compared to P5 which is very concise, stylish, responsive, fast and clearly designed with player in mind. Pretty sure the designer in this game should learn from Masayoshi Sutoh and Hisayoshi Kijima (the UI designer of Persona 5 and Nier: Automata).

[h2]Stripped Velvet Room[/h2]
The velvet room is a stripped down version of the original, I don't like it. It feels limited and it lacks the charm of the velvet room.

[h2]The Persona skill is not well designed and battle is a bit mindless[/h2]
A simple case: "maragi" previously it used to attack fire to all enemy in front of you, this lead to many interesting decision like:
[list]
[*] "should I save sp or damage everyone with fire?"
[*] "there's a deamon that drain fire, is it worth to attack everything but some of them gain health?"
[*] "there's a deamon that reflect fire, is it worth to attack everything but I take damage?"
[*] "should I finish this battle in 1 turn or wait for the next few turn?"
[*] etc
[/list]
But in this game, maragi just simply attack wider range. It doesn't effect anything, there's no interesting decision its just a mindless skill. This not only happen to maragi skill but happen to buff/debuff and the gambling hama skill. The battle on this game is a bit mindless, I'm not saying P5 is hard but it had many interesting decision during its battle and I feel there's no such decision being made while I play this game.

[h2]Conslusion[/h2]
If you like persona games, I would bet you'll like the story of this game. If you really want to know what's happen, go a head and play it. I don't like the gameplay and if you can't stand mindless gameplay and nuisance that I mentioned above, IMO its not worth it to push through it and better with watching youtube gameplay.

[h2]Final Score: 2/5[/h2]

author: 096bb794682d518f928dfe47ca041bda
content:
Hello  there  ,  hope you are doing well  . I have finished the game but for some reason I forgot to write a review for this amazing game . So , let me begin by saying that if you haven't played Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal ,stay way  from this game at all costs  if you don't want your experience to be ruined (If you have specific questions about that ask  me in the comments and i will  try to explain  as much  spoiler free as possible) . Since  I am afraid that I might spoil  something and the fact that  English is not my mother tongue language , I will be short  :
Pros  : 
- Soundtrack :  Even though  this is a sequel/spin off and clearly I thought that the budget is gonna be less , I expected that  the quality  would not be as good as Persona 5/Royal , the game absolutely  destroyed my negative expectations . I can safely say that the quality of the different songs of  this game were on par with the soundtrackk of Persona 5 if not better . And  Lyn Inaizumi with her superb tone and really good control on the high notes, a great overall performance as always . Give her some love please on Twitter .
- Engine : I really don't know what Engine did they use on Persona 5 strikers but  the textures for characters ,objects,game terrain are light  years more clean than the  Persona 5 Royal (which have a slight upgrade on it's graphics in comparison with  the vanilla Persona 5) . And  even though this is anime or as some smart people like to say it ''a weeb'' game , the game looks soooooooo good in 4K  60 fps and everything  on the highest  settings to the  point that I could not believe it . 
-Gameplay: At first ,  when it first was announced for the Japanese market I thought that the gameplay will be  broken , poorly made or whatever you want to call . And I was sure (for some reason) that this type  of gameplay will absolutely not  fit well on a Persona game so decided to ignore it since I believed that it won't have a Western release . After some time when the game was announced for the West , I decided  to take the risk (due to my bias towards the Persona franchise and Atlus)  and preorder the digital deluxe . So the early access released  and  I started playing . Not only it is not boring  but it also has so many many creative mechanics that build on the Dynasty Warriors gameplay  formula and make it wayyyyy more fun  than I expected and it  felt so good using the different new  mechanics  .
-Story (SPOILER FREE) : Even though I have the bias i already mentioned above  ,  I never expected the story of this spin off (which also servers a sequel to Persona 5) to be so well crafted . Of course , not as big (that’s what she said) and good as the Persona but so much better than your everyday spinn off 
-Duration/NG+ : First of all , the playtime I currently have is not  accurate because I have spent  1-2 hours looking  at the preorder bonuses . Also this is the duration of my first playthough and I haven't started yet NG+ .  NG+  is neccessary if you want to earn al the achievements . I am the type of player that likes to look every nook and cranny of the game , unlock  all the abilities for the characters , do all the side quests first  and then start doing the main story to unlock new side quests (and repeat ) until I finish the game  . 
 Cons: 
The only  thing I didn't like was the epilogue(it was rushed in my opinion but it probably they didn't have the apropriate budget to make it  smoother , I can't be  sure )  and fact that [spoiler] you can predict after a certain point  in the main story who the main antagonist is so I wish they would have hidden this person  better but it didn't bother me that much . Don't make that stop you from buying it , it is just my personal whining [/spoiler]

Ooof , I wrote more than I expected . Before  I  leave please leave  a comment if you  have anything to ask before buying in the comments . Have a great day and stay safe !!!!!!

content:
The first Persona game I have played was 5.  it was fun at first but as you go you realize every enemy fights the exact same and every single battle is the exact same tactic.  Tactic, strategy what ever you want to call your plan in battle is the exact same every fight, hold R1 to find a weakness on an enemy to get an "all out attack" to build your special, or "showtime" meter.  I cant finish the game because it became so mundane and endless talking and cutscene's.  Every time you encounter an enemy they have to talk to you first then change their form into what you'll fight, which is also confusing why they all have one form to speak and one to fight in.  

I think these games are over hyped and end up long over staying their welcome.  If it had an intelligent combat system and intuitive and changing enemy types it would be far more engaging.  Not for me personally.  I'll stick to the God of Wars when i need some melee story telling exerperience and you should save your money and not get this dull game.  Having forced myself to attempt to finish this game I'm calling it quits at 44 hours in.  Use me as a lesson and not your wallet.

author: bc1af733a67e589483d3aba852912473
content:
I absolutely love [i]Persona 5[/i], it’s actually one of my all-time favorites, and I remember how I wished for a direct sequel after I finished it. Never would have imagined that my wish would come true!

Well, sort of, at least. Story-wise, [i]Persona 5 Strikers[/i] is indeed a sequel (although most of the side characters from [i]P5[/i] are absent, and don’t expect to develop/continue any romantic relationships, either), however, the battle system is quite different this time around. I, for one, wasn’t a huge fan of this new, active, real-time combat. Sure, you can get used to it pretty fast, it’s not very difficult, controls are pretty fluid, and it can definitely be fun obliterating huge hordes of enemies – it’s just that I, personally, have always preferred turn-based battles in JRPGs. 

As for the other aspects of the game, there’s nothing I could complain about. The visuals are absolutely gorgeous, including all the beautiful anime cutscenes, the story is meaningful (although maybe a bit weaker than in [i]P5[/i]) filled with relatable characters, and the music… God, I loved the music, just like in all [i]Persona[/i] games I’ve played so far! Admittedly, most of the songs are from [i]P5[/i], but I didn’t mind that at all. I’m telling you, the soundtracks of these games are incredible.

All in all, even if you’re like me and are a bit intimidated by the battle system, I think you should give this one a try. There are less social interactions than in [i]P5[/i], no minigames, less characters, but in exchange, you get more cities to explore, [spoiler]and even some new Phantom Thieves![/spoiler]

author: a60923fd1ecd51fe932ba20155d5b578
content:
EDIT October of 2022: Persona 5 has just been released on PC. I highly recommend playing through it first before Strikers.

Persona 5 Strikers is a sequel/spinoff to Persona 5. Unlike it's predecessor which was a turn based jrpg with dungeon crawler/social sim elements, Strikers is an action hack and slash game in the vein of Dynasty Warriors.

One of my favorite aspects of this game is how familiar to Persona 5 it feels. It has so many little touches like the player being able to pause the game and view the dialogue log mid conversation. All of the player's companions return from the original which is a very welcome inclusion. As a huge fan of Persona 5's story and characters the primary selling point for this game was being able to continue the adventures of Joker and the gang. Which this game delivers. On the flipside this is also potentially the game's greatest shortcoming. It's a direct sequel to Persona 5 and fully expects you to have beaten that game before playing this one. Considering Persona 5 isn't on Steam (as of the writing of this review anyway) this is a massive problem. Because of that if you haven't previously played P5 or P5R you will be rather lost in terms of the story and general gameplay mechanics.

The action rpg combat is serviceable albeit very simple. It feels kind of mindless at times and selectively makes you pay attention when it throws a challenging enemy at you. It does feel like the developers did their best to try and make an action rpg out of Persona 5's combat. However I never felt like it ever surpassed that game in terms of strategy or personality. I can see this game appealing to people who were turned off of Persona 5's turn based combat. However because it's story expects you to have beaten P5 it also doesn't really appeal to newcomers. 

All in all in terms of being a spinoff/sequel to Persona 5 it delivers. It gives you more of that game just with a different spin on things. Outside of that though if you weren't crazy about the original like I was it's hard to recommend. Especially since Persona 5 isn't on Steam as of yet. Hopefully if/when that game releases, Strikers can have a second wind on Steam. But til then it remains as a novelty for the minority of PS4 owners who own a gaming PC and were also huge fans of Persona 5.

author: 5dd8bc4eba7358d2b75def6e0cfa035a
content:
Persona 5 Strikers overall does a fantastic job of bringing P5's characters and gameplay to a whole new style of combat.  Fights are smooth, the combos are satisfying, and it still feels like Persona combat.  Elemental affinities are still present, and Joker can freely swap between available Personas.  Every playable character feels unique and has a moveset I feel accurately represents them.  For example, Morgana can transform into his car form seen in Mementos, and several of Makoto's combos involve riding Johanna or rapid punches.  The story overall was pretty good and helped make this still feel like a Persona game.  The Phantom Thieves are rather static characters compared to the original game, but instead they help others find their own way, especially the two new members of the Thieves.  However the first few Jails can feel rather...samey and formulaic.  It doesn't help that every boss fight takes place in a castle.  It loses some of the uniqueness seen in P5's Palaces.  I also don't think the Jail Monarchs have the same impact as Palace rulers, but there were good ones.  

One major returning part of the game to really tie it back to the Persona series is the Velvet Room.  Lavenza alone manages it this time as Igor is nowhere to be seen.  And this was honestly what I felt to be the weakest part of the game.  Especially coming nearly fresh off of Persona 5 Royal, the Velvet Room felt very bare bones.  Persona Fusion works in pretty much the same way, but there's not much else.  You gain the ability to level your Personas directly up to Joker's current level with a new currency, but it gets very expensive very quickly.  Not helped are the new restrictions that the Personas themselves now must be at a certain level to be fused.  This wasn't a big deal in the early game, but trying to get powerful Personas in the late game was a chore as they often required Personas acquired in early Jails to be at a level far past when they stop learning new skills.  For example, King Frost requires Jack Frost and Jack-o-Lantern to be at level 40 while Joker to be at level 66.  But Jack-o-Lantern might be around level 8.  So the only way to get him the extra levels is to spend the new persona points.  But I at least could not find a reliable way of getting them besides re-summoning and dismissing high level Personas.  Gaining new Personas in the field is random; there is a chance a defeated Shadow will drop a mask for Joker, and that chance can be increased by leveling a skill.  Repeated Personas will give persona points instead of exp like in P5.

Overall this is still a very fun game with fantastic music and a decent story, but I think Persona 5 Royal is the more polished experience.  But for a spin-off sequel in a totally different genre?  It did a great job.

One last note: the digital deluxe edition is slightly misleading.  The art gallery and OST are locked in a separate application with no built-in way to download the contents.

author: b9cf43af4f8a5936bece72d859adf803
content:
Calling this game a spinoff of Persona 5 would be a disservice. Despite a huge difference in gameplay Persona 5 Strikers feels more like a proper sequel. Not only that but I can wholeheartedly say that I had more fun with P5S than with the vanilla Persona 5.

Persona 5 Strikers, at its core, is a Musou type game with Persona mechanics. Meaning, a hack'n'slash with hundreds of enemies and some RPG elements. And surprisingly such combination works very well. The production values are quite impressive, with a brand new story reuniting the Phantom Thieves together, as well as introducing some well-developed new characters. The way the characters interact feels like a proper Persona game, and while the core story isn't anything groundbreaking, it is still very well presented, with some nice twists here and there. Honestly, I think I enjoyed the story more than the vanilla Persona 5, mainly because the characters we interact with are not just simple one-dimensional villains like in the original.

Despite lacking the social-life aspect of previous Persona titles, many other elements unique to that series are present in Strikers. And the action-oriented gameplay works very well with them. Kind of brings back memories of the Devil Summoner series from the PS2, only better and even more dynamic. With several different playable and customizable characters, as well as dozens of Personas to fuse for the main character, the hack'n'slash gameplay doesn't get tedious too fast. Mashing buttons won't get you far, as there's still a need to be tactical and aware of enemies' affinities. That said, even though I'm no action game expert, I've found the controls to be very intuitive and comfortable. Rarely had any issues controling the characters or running around the environment.

The game looks and sounds great. The style is very similar to Persona 5, and the new music is very catchy, whether in battle, dungeons, or during free-time. Environments are numerous and varied. This goes for both the dungeons and the Japanese cities the party visits during their trip.
The game runs at 60fps and the PC port is honestly surprisingly good. Never had a single technical issue and the game ran very smoothly with no frame drops whatsoever.

Whereas the original Persona 5, for me, got tedious very fast, I've found Persona 5 Strikers way more enjoyable. To the point I've started the New Game + on the highest difficulty only to appreciate it even more. Sure, there are some flaws, obviously, but my point is that the game is really good and every fan of Persona 5 should give it a try. Other people maybe not so much, mainly because Strikers is a direct sequel to Persona 5, which I'd suggest either play or watch beforehand.

Overall, a great game that doesn't deserve to be called a spinoff, because it's much more than that. I've had tons of FUN with Strikers and I'm pretty sure I'll replay it again someday.

author: 3a0750bc65095132a6222562fe4dbddb
content:
Persona 5 Strikers is an interesting mix of Persona 5 story, characters and lore with the typical Dynasty Warriors gameplay (haven't played any dynasty warriors yet). Whether you like this game or not will depend on what you liked in Persona 5 more, which is either the life-sim/story or the gameplay or both. 

Also btw, this is a full-on sequel to Persona 5 (not Royal) so I would highly recommend playing that one first. Not just because it gives you more insight into the characters but it is also a better put together game, albeit with its weaknesses which P5S has seemed to borrowed over as well.

It is definitely a game made for people who have played and fell in love with Persona 5 before. Great music, great characters (new ones too) with an interesting amalgamation of both the combat styles, but highly leaning towards the use of Personas in the active battlefield. I was no longer waiting 120 seconds per turn to think about my next 3 moves, like what I would do in Persona 5. Now you have to make split second decisions, but you can always open up the persona menu mid-battle to pause time and think about your strategy a bit. Some levels are poorly balanced so feel free to adjust the difficulty if you retry more than twice on a mission, unless you are in it for the challenge.

1. My biggest problem with this game is the same problem that I had with P5.

The story and the pace of it is just too slow at some points especially in the middle, where you feel like the story is not progressing anywhere and we are basically waiting for something to happen/give us a clue. Some dungeons are just too big, and they throw the same enemy types at you and you steamroll through them till you reach a boss which spices up some things but largely uses the same skills, tactics etc. Lots of potential here to make you feel burned out and bored if you figure out some strategies which work in the short term.

2. My second biggest problem, I don't think the game puts enough emphasis on using persona skills that automatically trigger when you execute a particular combo. This is especially helpful with Joker since he is the most versatile one and using the skills in combos drains 0 SP, so you still get some chance to retaliate at low SP. It's basically a weakened version of a skill but takes no SP. SP is still a rarely found resource in the game and especially when there is no checkpoints to save your progress and refresh your SP in sight.

3. Third, I feel the story and dungeons were too repetitive and simplistic this time. The story repeated itself for 3-4 dungeons (these were the long ones too imo). Go to the dungeon, chase the red marker, kill everything that stands in your way. I saw this in P5 as well so I think it carried on from there but the most complex things that the dungeon crawling in P5 and P5S require from you are simple yet gloried fetch quests. I would have liked to see the dungeon crawling requires at least 10% of my brain power to clear through them.

4. This point is deriving info heavily from the P5 story so most of this is in spoiler territory. [spoiler]The plot lacks originality. The story is pretty similar to P5 (the characters say that they have seen this happen themselves). The bosses have more backstory this time so that's nice but still it seems pretty formulaic by the time the story tries to create suspense because the pacing issues I mentioned up there. Zenkichi and Sophia are welcome additions to the crew however. I think Zenkichi's addition should have happened sooner that it did because the plot picks up after that point quickly. The pacing issues is something I really hope ATLUS improves on because plenty of people just leave games when they get boring or some people just stop paying attention to the stuff going on (like me during the mid-game).[/spoiler]

Even after all my criticisms, I feel this game deserves a genuine try by Persona fans because there's still plenty of things to love here, especially Persona 5 fans like me. I think I just bought this game for the UI as soon as it came it out :P

author: e8b7368f731b562d92b6311aa1a36237
content:
I was on the fence about this game at first. Yes, it is a continuation of P5 (one of my favorite JRPGs), but the choice of combat style a la Dynasty Warriors seemed a weird choice for me. Indeed, it took quite some getting used to at first. Many of the battles will present you with so much information on screen that it can be difficult to keep track of what is happening. Hordes of enemies swarm and remembering certain attack combos in unison with summoning your Persona felt like a feat in multitasking compared to the original combat of P5; though this may be more my lack of experience with hack and slash games if anything. Showtime attacks, which felt like more of an after-thought in Royal, return center stage akin to ultimate moves in combat, with each part member having their own unique set. Persona summoning is also incorporated into combat, with the ability to switch between your deck and cast spells as needed.

However, after a while, the combat became fun once I grew accustom to the controls. Playing this on PC, I would highly recommend plugging in a controller over M&K. There was something satisfying in the flashy and stylish way each Phantom Thief performs in a fight. Beyond the main combat, it keeps to the series' traditional Persona fusing system (complete with Velvet Room), along with the same familiar abilities, strengths and weaknesses. Any veteran of the Persona will pick up on these with ease. 

The gameplay takes place in various "Jails," similar to Palaces where they are tied to and modeled after a particular boss. Even after completion, you can revisit each one to tie up loose ends such as obtaining a rare Persona or completing side jobs that will occasionally come in. Another change is lack of Confidants or daily social activities in favor of focusing largely on the main group. Because of this change, late additions to the party in P5, such as Futaba or Haru, receive a lot more screen time. 

In terms of story, this game is a direct sequel to Persona 5 (vanilla, not Royal). The Phantom Thieves reunite to tackle another threat as they travel Japan in a grand road trip. The Metaverse returns and, unsurprisingly, someone is messing with it again. It follows much of the same structure as P5 in finding the current big bad, taking them down, and moving on to the next target. Strikers deviates from the main game in that you no longer have major hub areas to explore outside of the Metaverse. Most new location only come with minor exploration, with most of the meat being within the Jails themselves. In-game time is fast-tracked in comparison, with typically only a few 'days' between missions. No new formula here, but if you're looking for more Phantom Thieves goodness, this game will offer it. The game is not nearly as long as its predecessor; I finished at about 54 hours, which included a bit of time building my Persona team and tackling various side jobs/bosses. 

Most of the same beats are here: stylistic combat, great music, an engrossing story, and the same lovable cast of characters. There is not much more to say beyond that, as anyone coming out of P5 will feel at home here (at least once mastering the combat system). While not as grand as those of the main line games, it is a worthy sequel to try something new and help pass the time waiting for P6.

author: a44a3be37b1e517b9df57e60e90606ac
content:
[h1]Things I liked:[/h1]
     > They took the already incredible P5 soundtrack and added some great remixes and a couple of good new tunes IMO. Had a blast listening to the BG music while playing.
     > The devs took the opportunity to flesh out some of the underdeveloped characters in P5/P5R and generally succeeded. The cast now feels more well-rounded.
     > Road-tripping through Japan as the setting was great as I was familiar with several of the places the Phantom Thieves visited and it reminded me of how much I enjoyed my own trips.
     [spoiler]> The devs did a helluva job in introducing and establishing the new Phantom Thieves Wolf and Sophie as relatable characters. Sophie in particular reminded me a lot of Vivi from FFIX in that her journey of learning and growth was also central to the story.[/spoiler]

[h1]Things I'm meh about or disliked:[/h1]
     > The combat mechanics were just ok for me. I settled into them more or less by halfway through the game but boss fights more or less devolved to P5-style of fighting - buff, spam elemental weakness, toss items around like crazy. Gimme the old turn-based combat any day.
     > The slice of life stuff that really drew me into P5R felt lacking here. As mentioned previously, I wish the game leaned more into that especially since the original premise of P5 was supposedly a big jaunt around the world which Strikers is delivering on a smaller scale.
     [spoiler]> The post-Kyoto storyline devolving into a retread of P5 was kinda disappointing. Konoe as Shido-adjace (even down to the boss fight mechanics), Demiurge being character-wise a repeat of Yaldabaoth, and the final 2 jails being Mementos-adjace left me a little let down by the final 3 or so hours of the game.[/spoiler]

[h1]Overall: A good, almost-great sequel to P5.[/h1]

author: bcab3ee5f1805d208eaaff2a73e6444b
content:
Legitimately improves on a bunch of plot and character development issues that Persona 5 had, unless you really liked all those scenes where the bad guys talk about how evil they are.

New music is pretty good, old stuff is reused. Which is fine, because the old stuff is good.

Gameplay was enjoyable for me on Normal as somebody completely unfamiliar with Warriors / Musou games. Every character is pretty useful throughout, and identifying the best strategies for them is rewarding. Bosses can be pretty damage-spongy though, and you definitely will feel underleveled if you try those very-powerful-demon requests as soon as you get them.

Ran very well on my system, without any noticeable issues aside from one random crash. Game lets you save freely outside of dungeons and at any checkpoint within them, so impact of those can be minimal.

author: 70946dfa187054259ed79aa17469a1aa
content:
I can not recommend the game in its current state.
Its very buggy, plagued by breaking bugs like freezes, infinite loading - very frustrating since they often waste lot of your time. These are no secret and you can easily find lots of reports and people asking for solutions on game own forums. Developer keeps releasing "beta" hotfixes, none of which fixed issues for me.

I am not sure if these issues have something to do with poor support for AMD CPUs, generally poor multithreading stability (some fixes suggest issues with hyperthreading) or some issues with Denuvo DRM uses.

Also keep in mind these bugs tend to happen most on late game levels, at time where you are well past return window. I wonder if developer deliberately spent most time polishing start of the game to avoid refunds.

Edit: After 13 additional hours, Steam suggested "do you want to revise your review".
Well, I still don't recommend it. I managed to get through buggy stages, but it was super-frustrating, I had to redo couple very difficult boss fights when game decided to freeze on me.

I somehow managed to get through by a lot of manual hacks by playing with CPU affinity, and later actually using Visual Studio debugger to un-stick the frozen game (having programmer background helped). Still I feel this was way above what average user can or should be able to deal with, so "Not recommended" verdict still stays.

The combat, while different, is very fun with the different ways of fighting and a good way to adapt a tradition JRPG to a more action-based combat system. author: 34cc709a875651338be732f3e3281023
content:
While I do think the game is very good, the combat isn't as great as you might think. Most battles on higher difficulties turn into you spamming SP because there's no way in hell you're beating some of these bosses otherwise. Stronger moves cost a large amount of SP, unless you have certain Persona abilities. Be ready to chug sodas or other SP restoration items. I definitely advise playing on easy so the combat doesn't start to drag and bosses don't take a long time. The combo versions of spells just don't cut it.  At all. You'll either get knocked out of it or get it off and deal basically no damage. Combat basically comes down to this cycle: heat riser -> apply status -> spam technicals and/or weakness -> recover SP. I've tried several times to play the game any other way and the payoff is never worth it. The moment I got Spell Master, the other party members might as just not exist. 

Okay, now that the bummer part is out of the way. The story is great! The new characters fit in perfectly and I want more of them. The old cast bounce off of each other and the new characters very well! The music is incredible and a lot of boss designs and set pieces are really good. 

The quality of life for Persona abilities is great and definitely should be added to the main games going forward. Merciless drops items that increase a stat by 1 so other party members can achieve 99 in all stats, which is pretty satisfying. Fusion is a little lack luster, requiring some persona to be very high leveled and there's just not that many to fuse. Persona take forever to level, and using the persona points system is really tedious. You essentially buy and release the same persona over and over to get more persona points. The ultimate persona is just Lucifer, which is a bummer given the potential of P5's ultimate Persona in this game.

You probably won't encounter these issues unless you play on hard or normal, and you'll definitely avoid most of the fusion issues if you aren't achievement hunting like I was. If you like Persona 5, you'll like this game. Simple as that.

content:
I went into this game completely blind.

I actually thought it was the original P5 story but in an action RPG format. Despite that, I was more than willing to try it out cuz P5 is THAT good (already played that game on PS4).

Much to my pleasant surprise, the story is obviously a continuation of the events of P5 and I love that! I'm always down to get more of the amazing characters. And this game introduces some new and awesome characters too!

The combat also surprisingly works REALLY well! The hack and slach feels satisfying and the mob density in some fights is really good!

A quick note - Don't forget to save MANUALLY. Its been a while since I played P5 and I totally forgot I have to save manually lol. Don't think this game has auto saves at all. So, keep saving! I lost like 3-4 hours of progress cuz I was gaming late at night and forgot to save before I hit the sack.

Overall a easy 8/10 for neutrals.. and a 9/10 if you are a Persona fan (like me)!

author: 89886906489750a497f0fc6ce9387320
content:
Going into P5S I was expecting to suffer through what I've found to be typically uninteresting and monotonous Warriors-type gameplay for the sake of seeing the next part of the Persona crew's story, I came away pleasantly surprised, with not just my expectations challenged, but my skills as well.

For a Musou this is a surprising in-depth game, and it's really remarkable how much painstaking effort went into making it as P5 as possible. In fact, if I had to complain it's almost too similar to P5. This is true for gameplay, atmosphere, and even story--it hits many of the same beats, including a couple of the more tiresome ones. It does a great job expanding upon a few of the characters, most notably Haru and Makoto, while also introducing an excellent newcomer in the form of Zenkichi.

Some characters don't get much spotlight, unfortunately, like Ryuji and Mona, and I lament that the development of this game coincided with that of P5 Royal, so none of the excellent additions therein with Kasumi, Akechi, and Maruki are present. And though I really liked the presentation of the Persona roadtrip, less is ultimately developed by this story than I would have liked. It goes places, but in a self-contained way, sort of like some anime movies. Still, it's a solid experience, and if you enjoyed base P5, you'd probably be missing out if you skipped this

author: 9b33b0cbd23e506c98d74c7208e0e58c
content: An enjoyable sequel to Persona 5. You REALLY should play through the original/royal before diving into this one as its a follow on from the main storyline of that game. That said it does NOT follow on from Royal's extra 3rd semester content so if you have gotten to the 3rd semester that does not apply here as this game was made at the same time as Royal. Albeit as of the time of making this review neither the original or Royal have been ported to PC yet so you will have to wait if you are PC only and pray that Atlus does port it after the success from Persona 4 golden's port. Personally i played through both on PS4 (Combined total hours of over 230 for Persona 5 and Royal, Yes i love that game so much i played through it twice despite its monstrous length).  Took me a little bit of time (about half way through the first jail)  to fully get used to the Musou style of gameplay as this is my first game of that type of playstyle but once i got into it its great stuff, The mixture of persona and that style of gameplay blends well in my opinion. Storyline is good for the most part (some parts may feel a little bit lacking but its still a good game) and there's a mixture of sizes for the jails. 4 are Longer more fleshed out ones while the other 4 are shorter and in some cases much shorter mostly for some storyline purposes. Kyoto's jail makes up for its length with a great ending boss fight though its a shame you can't refight it like the others. While some of the shorter jails are a little disappointing length wise this did not hinder my overall enjoyment of the game and its nice to have a persona game that isn't so insanely long. Albeit this game still has good length and it did take me some time to finish all the requests and main story etc and post game content as i like to take my time with games. Music as usual when it comes to persona games is fantastic and the game looks decent in a higher resolution.  In summary if you enjoyed the original Persona 5/Royal and can adjust to the Musou style over the usual turn based combat this is more goodness for you with the gang you have come to love.

author: 9c91df692942546db62f5ef08f0d0ccb
content:
[b]SPOILERS FOR P5R BTW[/b]
Oh no...

I'll include small sentences underneath each paragraph for those in a hurry.

[b]The controls[/b]
Starting with a subject that honestly breaks the game for me, the controls.
The control mapping is abhorrent in my opinion, they changed the button mapping for nearly everything, starting with setting the automatic text forwarding to pressing in the left joystick to not being able to change the controls to what i would want properly. I.E. you can set controls for when you are in battle, but if you want to use that same button in the "normal world" you CANT. The game will unmap the button from when you are fighting.

This practically forces you to use the default keybindings, which suck so much that the game is borderline unplayable.



[b]The music[/b]
What for me was a BIG reason why i finished P5R was the incredible music. Sure there were a few bad songs, think about mementos and okumura's palace, but mostly, the OST was great! Now in P5S the difference between good songs and bad songs is amplified. There are a few absolute bangers like daredevil, the intro, and the remix of last surprise. But sadly, at least three of the songs that i had really wished that would've been gone remain. (Tension, Blood of Villain, High Pressure (seriously, fuck this song))

Overall for the music, 8/10. Some songs are bangers, some i wish they would've replaced.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
As WarOwl would say, [i]it doesn't wooooork[/i]. From the boss fights with dialogue that you CANNOT focus on because the battles are now in real time instead of turn based which WILL make you miss story, to you being able to fully heal with no penalty whatsoever just by returning to the overworld and going back and the general clunky controls of some of your abilities... yeah, it doesn't work.

Clunky controls and poor game design choices. Yikes.

[b]Story[/b]
Yes i realize that i've barely played the game and that i'm nowhere near finishing it, but from what i'm seeing right now, this is not good. Unengaging, boring and plot-hole filled storytelling that does not address any of what happened during P5/P5R. Not for me.

It's short enough that you should just read it.
Please do tell me if the story gets better after the first palace, cause if it doesn't i don't think i'll finish the game.


I'll definitely keep listening to some songs in the OST, and i love the opening, but i just can't see myself finishing this game any time soon.

content:
as someone with 140 hours on P4G, 200+ on P5 classic, i really enjoyed this game a lot. the story is a worthy sequel to the original but be aware the events of Royal are not canon in the Strikers universe and the ending kinda falls flat. ARPG esk Dynasty warriors combat system with the persona system was one hell of a unexpected combination that works on a meta level. hope to see a P4 spin off using the their new hybrid engine for combat. considering P3, 4, 5 take place in the same universe, seeing a spin off like strikers would be gold imo. 

my only issue is what they did to NG+ and Extreme(merciless) mode. 

Don't read this next part(spoilers)

[spoiler] after beating another false god, NG+ is not unlocked like most other persona games, instead you are thrown into "post game" and given a boss rush set of requests with harder nightmare versions before you can face The Reaper, why is this bad you might ask? because in all persona games that feature him, he is a end game optional boss encounter that tends to be the hardest out of all before him, the Reaper does not screw around and forcing players to try and fight him to unlock NG+ is kinda harsh. if you struggle with dire shadows, you wont survive a minute with Reaper, ive been able to beat almost all the Dire shadows as well as prepping a fist full of high tier persona's to take on the Reaper. ive beaten him in every persona game so far, not gonna let him stop me from NG+ but for some people? they will most likely quit. defeating Reaper is also required for merciless mode(extreme) [/spoiler]

author: 266581047d1e55ec83735a4b137c0968
content:
This game is great, the characters are stunning, the writing enthralling, the action intoxicating but there are times it feels incomplete, a symptom of being stuck between two genres and having two rather different teams working on this game; the lack of truly unique social links, the absence of first game tie ins (there's no Mishima and I hold a grudge) and if you aren’t fond of the hack n slash genre the repetition in combat and the music that comes with it can be overbearing. 

I do recommend the game, you could try and wait for a sale but unfortunately JRPGs, Atlus games, koei games and triple A games generally do not go on sale often enough for waiting to pay off. 

I believe if you like hack n slash games, like the Persona franchise, like franchise mixing, or like long games this game is more than worth the price and it is at least the sequel to a masterpiece, if not one itself. 

And for a much more in depth look into the many aspect of this game be sure to check out my video review of the game at https://youtu.be/LcN9Tlo83uU

author: a3388371398c57ae9be5ee3afb43cc89

With the best parts from both series, some of which was changed to flow better with the other, the gameplay is excellent. Things to be wary of. Although it seems as if the story is just Persona 5 again, it isn't. Although it does tread over similar ground, the wholly unique aspects and new characters like Zenkichi make up for it. Also, on PC there's a slight chance of infinite load times. That being said however, I personally only encountered it once, so as long as you save frequently (mainly before major events) it isn't a hassle.

author: 201f54934cd95c51838e4c1b6944f47b
content:
So as a fan of persona 5 I just had to buy strikers and I wanted to do a review for other people who game to this game because of persona 5. I do a pros and cons type of review so I can make it as simple as possible. Now onto the pros

[Pros]

- [Combat]
I love this games feel for the hack and slash type of game style they did not miss on the feel of combat and the enjoyment of constantly throwing out attacks and dodging.

- [Bond] In the previous persona 5 it was done through spending time with characters and unlocking better skills, In this game it is gained through requests and story progression and is very neat upgrading the exact skills you want to.

- [Personas]
They kept a lot of the old personas making it pretty fun seeing the old ones and knowing how to counter them off of memory from the previous game. I also like how in combat you can use the ability's as a combo that doesn't consume SP making the personas more involved since they branched more into melee combat it kept the feel of needing personas relevant.

- [Requests]
I seen a request and it allowed me to re fight a boss of a jail for a reward which was pretty dope not having to start a new game plus just to fight a certain boss again, which in turn gives the game more replay value without having to new game plus it.

- [Fast Paced Combat] 
I enjoy running around and just slashing at every enemy in sight it makes for a more involved experience so you don't fall asleep while grinding levels as fast.

- [Sequel]
Unlike jumping from character to character when making a new game they instead made it like a sequel which was promising since I never played the other personas I wanted to relive the feel of the OG phantom thieves in persona 5. Making me want it all the more and I mention this because I have a con later down in the list making this make more sense to the rating.

- [Art Style]
It's very unique in the environment inside the metaverse which I can appreciate a very lot since it makes it stand out from other games it makes you wanna keep playing the franchise.

This is my temporary review since I haven't fully played through and only have 10 hours into the game now onto the cons.

[Cons]

- [Sequel]
So far into my gameplay I haven't experienced much freedom which may be because I'm not far enough into the game, I really enjoyed the dating whoever you wanted or deciding what to do with your time. It strayed from the feel of persona 5 which makes this sequel a bit of a disappointment though this is a temporary review so this might change as I get further into the game and comments are enabled so if anyone wants to comment on this explaining how the freedom works I would appreciate that. I very rarely get time to play so it may be awhile till I get to see how it is.

- [EXP] 
I fight almost every single enemy I find and I am still not a high level to where I can go through the area like its on very easy difficulty and that is not very promising for a time limited game time.

- [Time Management]
The previous persona made entering and exiting the palaces and mementos much more problematic in this game they don't really worry you since you can go in and out as you please and your days won't end. It completely heals you and your sp is returned making it a lot less fun trying to survive on no hp or sp or even being tactical on how you use your sp/items.

I do think this game will open up a lot of pros as I progress and this one specifically might just start slow but I will be back to update this review as I learn more things about the game.
And this is the end of the review to all the people that stayed and read my review thank you and I hope you have a great day/night :3

author: 9ed2de3db47d5efbadbe3f5fe3d19852
content:
Ware wa nanji… nanji wa ware…

First thing you must know is that the game continues the story of Persona 5 not Royal. No characters,events or ending are mentioned or seen in Strikers from Royal. Bare that in mind. It is a must to know the lore of Persona 5. Either play it or watch a no commentary walkthrough. Anime is not recommended as many things are lost.

Strikers had a drastic change in gameplay from Turn base combat to Hack and Slash which made the game more fast paced and gives you a big window of how you will fight with shadows. As we might remember, Yakuza Like a Dragon also changed it's combat but to Turn Based which was not the best decision.

Now we roam all around Japan to find Jails (Yes, now castles are called jails and they are not a little location but a whole city) and defeat Monarchs that rule them. There is no Memento for obvious reasons. 

The game became very easy in comparison to the previous game. You are not limited with time anymore and can infiltrate jails as many times as you want. You don't need to raise your confidants anymore because there is a new system of Bond. You receive Bond Skill exp for battles,requests,bosses and so. You get points with each level that you can spend on skills that will help you in different ways. The shop is now a;ways in the hideout. One click and you can buy anything you want. You don't need to annoy poor Iwai for equipment or go to Takemi for meds. Ah, you will be hearing "How many?" and "Are you sure?" a looooooooooot of times, so be prepared. I warned you.

The story is as always good but there is one moment in the game which makes me question why the devs repeated themselves...

Bosses. If you played or watched Persona 5, you do remember that each boss was unique and you had to follow some strategy not to die. Sadly, bosses here are like regular enemies. Nothing special about them. No difficult stategy needed. You just need to mash the buttons and evade. Only the final boss was unique and had something different in the boss fight. 
I'll just give an example of Persona 5 boss. Madarame. Several phases. Painting and then fight with clones where you had to use correct skills to win. Here...just mash the down buttons. Maybe it was made so the game doesn't loose the pace and stays fast like all of the gameplay but these are bosses. When you beat them, you need to get the feeling that you won by doing something and getting the feeling that all the hours you spent to grind for a new persona wasn't just a woosh. 

In general I like the game and it's new combat system. New locations were a nice change of pace and I hope the next game will have something more. Bosses need more attention because this is just a meh. I hope that the new game will have another cool story that I and other Persona fans will enjoy.

author: 6f91ff8420fb5b4293b5a8a24fac4177
content:
I should start this review saying that if you're new to the Persona universe, DO NOT PLAY THIS FIRST. This game is a sequel to the original Persona 5. This game fully assumes that you've played at least the original Persona 5, and doesn't give any background to new players, so play either the original Persona 5 or Persona 5 Royal first. I don't care if you have to watch an LP.

As a huge Persona 5 fan, I preordered this game and completed the story 4 days after it came out, playing nothing but this game. While it is significantly shorter than the original Persona 5, I can say that the combat is some of the most fun I've *ever* had in a game. You can totally feel the passion from this game, and the developers put their heart and soul into making something that will stay true to the Persona 5 vibe and the charm that made people fans of the game to begin with. 

Not even mentioning the SOUNDTRACK. This absolute banger of a soundtrack paired with super-intense-stimulus-overloading fights makes for some of the most fun you'll ever have in a hack n' slash game. Of course there are pretty easy to point out flaws with it like the story not being as long or good as the original, but in my opinion the good outweighs the bad for this game. If you loved P5, you will absolutely love this game.

author: 6575b5557674593180f83de2251df43e
content:
It's just as flashy and horny for style as the original Persona 5 is, if not more so. 
While not a turn based combat system like the other games in the series, I still found the hack and slash mowing down of enemies to be quite enjoyable. It also adds to the character of quite a few main characters, which is nice because some of them were sorely lacking in the first Persona 5. 
With that being said, it's incredibly similar to the first story and I found the final boss to be incredibly underwhelming, both in concept and as an actual fight.  Along with this, the story takes place over the course of a month, but don't let that fool you, there's still a lot of playtime to be had from the game. 
It lacks a lot of the key elements of the series, like the turn based combat, social links, and time management, so don't go into the game expecting that. It does offer a few unique things to better fit with the style of game, but if you're expecting another Persona 5 Royal, you will be disappointed. 
Not the best game in the franchise, but it's still incredibly enjoyable nonetheless.

author: ae78ec0cc7e957058fe73117d82ed936
content:
[u]Persona 5 Strikers is the best game I have played in 2021. [/u]

However, its existence on PC is a harder sell as the game's story is a continuation from the PS3/PS4  game Persona 5. Yes, you can just pick up and play Strikers, but unless you watched the anime, or played the prior game you won't know the characters, their backstory and all of their character nuances and personality traits.

[b]So what is the game?[/b]

It's a story driven action game with RPG elements. As you play the game you're tasked with infiltrating 'Prisons'. You fight your way through until you defeat the boss at the end. As you progress you collect Personas. Think of these like Pokemon. Each Persona has different skills and abilities. Some heal, some buff or debuff and some do fire, wind or death magic. You level up your characters and persona to increase their power and learn new abilities.

[b]The Good.[/b]

[u]The voice acting. [/u]

The game isn't 'fully' voice acted. Some sections simply have to be read, however similar to the game this is based on, large sections of the game are fully voice acted and the quality of the voice acting really elevates the game. All of the voice actors from Persona 5 have reprised their roles, with the addition of Nolan North joining the cast as the detective Zenkichi.

[u]The combat. [/u]

This isn't your typical musou game. Rarely is the screen filled to the brim with enemies. Instead, as you traverse the area, you will see enemies roaming around. You can choose to avoid them or 'ambush' them for a tactical advantage. Combat then starts with a small group of enemies to defeat. The combat is fast and satisfying, blending in a range of melee combos, ranged weapon attacks and abilities (think spells). Enemies often have weaknesses that can be exploited, leading to the opportunity to deal massive damage.

[u]Music.[/u]

This is obviously a personal preference. I like the Persona 5 music a lot. The Striker's soundtrack builds upon the existing soundtrack making slight changes, such as heavier guitar riffs.  The only glaring example here is the first 'prison' stage. The music is a stark contrast to the rest of the game. It's akin to something you might hear on a pachinko or slot machine. It's loud, noisy and is particularly grating on the ears. 

My personal preference is to use the DLC which allows you to use combat music from all of the previous Persona games. As a fan of the Persona series, I'll always choose to engage in combat with Mass Destruction playing.

[b]The Ok.[/b]

[u]Story.[/u]

The story of the game is in a weird place. Persona 5 Strikers is the story sequel to Persona 5, but not Persona 5 Royal. That means that none of the events of P5R have taken place. Not game breaking, but something to consider. The story itself is fine, if not a little predictable. It's welcome that the characters continue to develop past the P5 story. Hearing Haru refer to herself as 'Beauty Thief' again was welcome.

[u]Fighting when?[/u]

Persona 5 has a lot of story. Some of it is voice acted but a majority of it is reading conversations between The Phantom Thieves. Sometimes you just want to get back into the action, but you'll need to wade through the story elements first. I personally liked the story, but some people might not expect this much from a fighting game. Be warned.

[b]The Ugly.[/b]

[u]Eternal Bonds.[/u]

My only real criticism of the game came from my desire to 100% it. In particular, one Achievement stands out as egregious, and that is "Eternal Bonds'. To get this achievement, you need to raise your Bond level in game to 99. Raising your bond level happens as you play the game. Major story events, killing rare bounties and defeating bosses will all net you some bond level. However, I completed the game around the 48 hour mark. I then started new game plus and played through it again. Even after two complete playthroughs, I still didn't have enough. 
I grinded one particular rare bounty for about 10 more hours. In hindsight, I could have played NG+ on the hardest difficulty, but I did so up until completing Alice's Palace, but the progress on the bond levels didn't seem any faster.
So there's a reason only ~3% of all players have completed all of the Achievements. It's due to Eternal Bonds. If you plan on grinding bond levels, be prepared to do a lot of this:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0W0x5VNsTkQ 

In the end, I did 100% Persona 5 Strikers. It's one of the few games I've sought to do so with. I still maintain it's the best game I have played all year and I do recommend it.

author: 19700f4844205276b38c7a958d5cb465
content: This is by far the best Persona spin off, outshining even the Persona Q series. The game's fighting mechanics are really fun, and each of the playable characters have fun movesets. New features such as leveling up Personas using Persona Points feel right at home for the series. Plus, for the first time in Persona history, the game can actually be difficult. Hard mode is ACTUALLY hard! It almost feels like a real Shin Megami Tensei game in terms of difficulty. In terms of story, this works very well as a sequel to the original Persona 5. All of the characters are enjoyable (except for Morgana, rot in hell you little shit) and feel like they're the same characters that I got to know so well in the original. The new characters such as Sophia and Zenkichi are phenomenal additions to the cast. The only problem in terms of characters is that there's no Goro Akechi or Sumi Yoshizawa, but that makes sense. Atlus, just please include those two as DLC. All in all, I love this game, and I hope Atlus continues to add more to it!

author: f8038ff270785e21b45a5aef1a090542
content:
Persona 5 Strikers, while not like other games in the series, is still an incredible game in my eyes.
SPOILERS BELOW
-
-
-
-
-
-
-
In terms of gameplay, Strikers is akin to Hyrule Warriors, with the aspects of Persona gameplay mixed in. There are 4 difficulties; easy, normal, hard, and merciless, which is only available in NG+. Personally, I played on hard mode up until the Osaka jail, because by then, it took me around 30 minutes or so to clear out certain prison keeps. Normal is a good difficulty for people who are possibly new to the action format (such as myself) and I have not tried easy, but given that its easier than normal, its most likely forgiving. The aspects of normal Persona mixed with action style gameplay is interesting, but in my experience, it is very rinse and repeat. Honestly, I couldn't do too many of the special moves or master arts, because enemies always hit me down before I could finish them. It was much easier to charge Joker's gun, or just spam whatever the enemy was weak to. As for the requests and jails, it's a mixed bag for me. The requests are decent, and dont take much time to complete, but that's about it. The jails are interesting, but unlike Persona 5, they don't offer many hiding spaces for ambushes, causing you to have to either be ambushed, shoot an enemy from far away, or attempt a direct hit. However, they are more action packed in my opinion. Using the environment to do phantom dash attacks are quite nice and can create cool combos if you can use them correctly. All in all, the gameplay isn't bad, but it isn't spectacular either. My biggest complaints are that A. you can only see the telegraph for an enemy's attack if you are facing them, and B. you MUST be locked on if you want to quickly use a magic attack and keep the flow of your fight. I would, however, definitely play this over almost any triple A game made today.

As for the story, it essentially follows that of Persona 5. As a direct sequel (or spinoff? Royal makes things weird.), it takes place after the collapse of the Metaverse and after the Antisocial Force's semi-disbandment. Personally, I think that Strikers has a few loopholes that I won't go too deep into, but it does have some "aha" moments, but also some poorly instigated moments that just feel like a plot device. The story is still alluring, and I was invested the whole time, but some parts could have been a little fleshed out. The interactions between the Thieves were nice, however, which is one of the main things I like in Persona games.

The last part I'll probably talk about is formatting, graphics, ect. Frame cap is 60 fps which isnt the end of the world, but I did notice that Yusuke's showtime did lag out my computer occasionally, and sometimes when the camera pans out to a birds eye view or a showcase of the palace, there were glitched out portions of the screen, but that wasn't anything too bad. Nothing compared to the infinite loading screen I got on my rematch of the final boss :( But regardless, the game looks nice, obviously similar to that of the original Persona 5. The menus are nice, and the game has a lot of color.

All in all, I would still say this game is one of if not my favorite games on Steam, and for good reason. Every game has its flaws, but the world of Persona will always hold a special place in my heart.

Plus the music, too. Just buy the bonus content and listen to Counterstrike forever. Songs a banger.

A 100% faithful sequel to the JRPG King of Kings, Persona 5.

The new combat system takes some getting used to, however it fits right in with the overall theme of the games. 10/10

author: 67182b27f545595c8fda34c507d7fdfa
content:
I went into this game thinking I was going to play a Warriors game. What i got was a Persona game masked as Warriors game.

I love the Persona series, but it works way better in turn based combat than in this basically real time madness where enemies are many and their skills even more. I also love Warriors games but here I can't get that almost immortal superhero 1 vs 1000 feeling as I have to dodge around and make fights as easy as possible with ambush tactics. Until the game throws me a boss or a mini boss with multiple times the difficulty I've had for the last 2 hours or so.

I really wanted to like this game as it combines two of my favourites, but I can't really enjoy either side of it as is. It might be because of my expectations: I wanted more Warriors less Persona. I wanted to check my brain out and play hack 'n' slash game, but what I got was more of JRPG game with clunky gameplay.

If you enjoy the game, good for you. But I got more frustration than enjoyment and I would not recommend the game at this time. Maybe when I go back to the game at some point and just lower the difficulty to easy I can get something from it. At this moment, I just want to enjoy my evening and not get angry at a boss fight.
